Any idea what's the ETA on that?

thanks!

title: Weekly rule when first occurrence is the next day and hour before current hour
body:
Version 0.16.2 seems to have a problem when creating a weekly schedule when the first occurrence happens to be the next day and the hour_of_day is before the current hour of day.  When this happens, the next_occurrence is pushed out an extra week.  If the hour_of_day is equal to or after the current hour of day, it works fine.

This test works with 0.16.0 but not with 0.16.2
  

    test 'weekly_schedule_flow_next_day_before_hour_test' do

      schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.utc(2017, 7, 28, 20, 0, 0))

      schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly(1).day(:saturday).hour_of_day(19)

      result = schedule.next_occurrence(Time.utc(2017, 7, 28, 20, 0, 0))

      assert_equal Time.utc(2017, 7, 29, 19, 0, 0), result, "Should be #{Time.utc(2017, 7, 29, 19, 0, 0)} but got #{result}"

    end

Minitest::Assertion: Should be 2017-07-29 19:00:00 UTC but got 2017-08-05 19:00:00 UTC.

Expected: 2017-07-29 19:00:00 UTC
Actual: 2017-08-05 19:00:00 UTC

title: #399 serialize Date for until validations
body: Fixes #399

title: #398 Fix double DST occurrences
body:
Simplify the method we use for calculating time changes across DST boundaries by
performing arithmetic under UTC to get "absolute" values. This is a revert of
the "unrolling in pairs" method introduced in c93fa7e for fixing #189.

The method of converting to UTC and back for doing time arithmetic only applies
when DST needs to be taken into consideration. For rules with less than daily
intervals, both hours still need to occur. This distinction was added in the
original fix.

However, the method was not correctly tested for non-ActiveSupport times (local
system TZ) and the advancing of time to the next occurrence was validating both
the last DT hour (before fall back) and first ST hour (after fall back) causing
double occurrences for the "same" hour on the clock face.

title: Fix weekly realignment for `spans: true` option
body:
Clamp iteration to the schedule start time so the first iteration does not
appear to be a preceding day (or possibly week).

When using the `spans: true` option, reversing over the start time to cover the
entire duration can move the opening time into a previous day/week and cause
weekly realignment to jump into the next weekly interval.

Count whole days for realigning weekly offsets to prevent rounding down to the
previous day.

Fixes #394

title: Realign first wday validation to the selected week_start
body:
When using a non-zero (non-Sunday) week start, the rule validations need to
choose the first wday to align onto when jumping into the schedule. The first
wday needs to be based on the correct week start, since 0 (Sunday) then comes at
the end of the week and causes the next valid occurrence to be skipped.

Fixes #400

title: Add spec illustrating a probable bug - for ticket #400
Missing occurrences on weekly schedules with weekstart mondays
body:
If you add a schedule like this:
* week start set to monday
* start time on a monday
* weekly
* every day of the week except tuesday

then it will miss the first occurrences...I'll attach a pull request with a spec inn a minute.

title: Until on recurrence_rule not set after version > 0.14.0
body:
Hi, 

First of all, thanks for this gem! But i'm having an issue while updating from version 0.14.0 to 0.15.0. The same thing occurs when updating to 0.16.0 or 0.16.1. What's happening is that the `.until` on the `recurrence_rule` isn't set anymore. 

The difference: 
**0.14.0**
```ruby 
{:validations=>{:day=>[5]}, :rule_type=>"IceCube::WeeklyRule", :interval=>1, :week_start=>1, :until=>2017-07-21 23:59:59 +0200}
```

**0.15.0 (and above)**
```ruby 
{:validations=>{:day=>[5]}, :rule_type=>"IceCube::WeeklyRule", :interval=>1, :week_start=>1}
```

This has many consequences in my spec files, because I use `appointment.schedule.all_occurrences` (which would return all the dates) a lot to explicitly check the dates. The method `.terminating?` just returns false because the rule is not terminating anymore.

This is how i'm adding the recurrence rules

```ruby
self.schedule = Schedule.new(start_time, end_time: end_time) do |s|
  s.add_recurrence_rule(Rule.weekly(week_pattern, :monday).day(day_number).until(end_date))
end
```

Where the variables could be as followed: 
week_pattern = 1
day_number = 5
end_date = Time.zone.today + 4.weeks (it's a Date object, But Time object doesn't fix it)

Also setting the backwards compatibility towards 12, 13, 14 doesn't solve it. I can't see where or what PR changed this behaviour, am I doing something wrong? Help is greatly appreciated ðŸ‘

title: Monthly recurrence rule is generating 2 appointments on same day due to daylight saving change
body:
Hi,

I've found an interesting case on both v 0.12.1 and master where for a recurrence rule there are 2 appointments created on the same day `Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKST -09:00`.

I suppose this has something to do with daylight saving time.

The code to reproduce this issue is

```
      Time.zone = "UTC"
      
      r = Rule.monthly.day_of_month(5)

      ocurrences_date_from = Time.zone.parse('Fri, 05 May 2017 19:11:17 UTC +00:00')
      schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule r
      schedule.start_time = Time.zone.parse("Wed, 05 Oct 2016 09:00:00 UTC +00:00").in_time_zone('America/Nome')

      p schedule.occurrences_between(ocurrences_date_from, ocurrences_date_from +  16.months)
```

and the output is 

```
[Mon, 05 Jun 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Wed, 05 Jul 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sat, 05 Aug 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Tue, 05 Sep 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Thu, 05 Oct 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKST -09:00, Tue, 05 Dec 2017 01:00:00 AKST -09:00, Fri, 05 Jan 2018 01:00:00 AKST -09:00, Mon, 05 Feb 2018 01:00:00 AKST -09:00, Mon, 05 Mar 2018 01:00:00 AKST -09:00, Thu, 05 Apr 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sat, 05 May 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Tue, 05 Jun 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Thu, 05 Jul 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sun, 05 Aug 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Wed, 05 Sep 2018 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00]
```

As you can see there are 2 appointments on 5th of November: `Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKDT -08:00, Sun, 05 Nov 2017 01:00:00 AKST -09:00`

Any hints on why this could happen? Or how we can fix it?

title: occurrences_between not giving expected results for schedule
body:
First of all, thanks a lot for the gem, using it for some time, covers all of my needs !

Now for the bug, in version `0.15.0` works fine, as for `0.16.1` it fails. 

The setup:

```
def apply_arguments(rule, &block)
  days = ["monday", "tuesday", "wednesday", "thursday", "friday", "saturday", "sunday"]
  updated_rule = rule
  days.each {|value| updated_rule = yield(updated_rule, value) }
  updated_rule
end

rule = IceCube::Rule.weekly(1, :monday)

apply_arguments rule do |new_rule, value|
  new_rule.day(value.to_sym)
end

start_date = Date.new(2017, 5, 29)
end_date   = Date.new(2017, 5, 31)

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_date, {}) do |s|
  s.add_recurrence_rule(rule)
end
```

The thing is, when I try to run `occurences_between` for the dates between 29th of May and 31st of May, it works fine:

```
pry(main)> schedule.occurrences_between(Date.new(2017, 5, 29).to_time, end_date.to_time.change(hour: 23, min: 59))

=> ["2017-05-29T00:00:00.000+03:00", "2017-05-30T00:00:00.000+03:00", "2017-05-31T00:00:00.000+03:00"]
```

If I am doing the same for the last 2 days of the month, 30th of May and 31st of May, it gives me unexpected results:

```
pry(main)> schedule.occurrences_between(Date.new(2017, 5, 30).to_time, end_date.to_time.change(hour: 23, min: 59))

=> []
```
when it should give me 30th of May and 31st of May as a result :(


ALSO, another thing I observed while debugging this.

If I write `days = ["monday", "tuesday", "wednesday", "thursday", "friday", "saturday"]` (without sunday), it gives me my expected results - 30th and 31st days included.

Hope to get some replies, as I am stuck with this problem, had to downgrade in order everything to work fine.

title: Exrules are missing from `to_hash`
body:
We serialise a `Schedule` object to a hash using `Schedule#to_hash` so we can save it in our DB, but found that the `exrules` weren't being included in the hash which means when converted back they were lost. Digging into the code I see that they're only included when `IceCube.compatibility <= 11`, so we've just set that to 11 and it works fine apart from a deprecation warning here and there.

Is it supposed to behave this way? How are `exrules` meant to be handled in versions past 11?

title: [WIP] Fix #377 regression
body:
The recent refactor of the weekly rule realignment has raised an error. This PR adds tests to show the problem and an attempt to fix it (currently not working).

The problem is that the duration offset used to be applied to the initial time t1 in the enumerator after the realignment was applied, but it has now been pushed back to the rule, so the realignment was being done on the offset t1 rather than the original opening_time. See #377

(What makes things a little unclear, I think, is that this looks the same as `schedule.first(2)`. Maybe better would be to adjust the count from 3 to 4 on the number of days made before the exception above. Then all your examples work.)

title: Weekly rule misbehaving in 0.16.0
body:
Hi, after upgrading to 0.16.0 from 0.15.0 some failures have been introduced to unit tests for the module that we have used ice_cube for.

Ruby version: ruby 2.3.3p222 (2016-11-21 revision 56859) [x86_64-linux]

Given the following IceCube::Schedule:
`{
    :start_time => {
        :time => 2009-11-02 12:00:00 UTC,
        :zone => "America/Montreal"
    },
      :end_time => {
        :time => 2009-11-02 13:15:00 UTC,
        :zone => "America/Montreal"
    },
        :rrules => [
        [0] {
            :validations => {
                :day => [
                    [0] 1,
                    [1] 2
                ]
            },
              :rule_type => "IceCube::WeeklyRule",
               :interval => 3,
             :week_start => 0
        }
    ],
        :rtimes => [],
       :extimes => []
}`

The schedule should occur on

Mon, 02 Nov 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Tue, 03 Nov 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Mon, 23 Nov 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Tue, 24 Nov 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Mon, 14 Dec 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Tue, 15 Dec 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Mon, 04 Jan 2010 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
Tue, 05 Jan 2010 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
etc

However calling .next_occurrences(3, Time.utc(2009, 12, 28, 12)) on the schedule yields

[0] Tue, 29 Dec 2009 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
[1] Mon, 04 Jan 2010 07:00:00 EST -05:00,
[2] Tue, 05 Jan 2010 07:00:00 EST -05:00

Notice the schedule erroneously indicates it will occur on Tue, 29 Dec in this case.

title: Update gem soon?
body:
Hey guys, thank you so much for this library. It's been amazingly helpful to me.

Any chance you're going to update the gem soon? I want to get rid of the Fixnum deprecation warnings in Ruby 2.4 (that were fixed already in commit edd21ea).

title: 75 Minute Durations
body:
We are having a tough time figuring out the correct rule pattern for durations over an hour. We need to create a schedule that allows an event to be available every hour and X minutes and the next starting at the end of that. 1st occurrence would be 9am, next 10:15am, and so on throughout the day based on the time window. This will repeat each day throughout the week. 

What we are seeing in right now is the second day would start at **10:00am** instead of **9:00am**. This happens on each following day as it appears to be rolling. 

What we need is for it to be the same each day.  Once we hit the next day, it restarts at 9am and is the same available times as the day before. 

Can you provide a sample for this?

Example Problem:
Days: Monday to Friday
Hours allowed: 9a to 5p
Duration: 75 min

title: Exclude unsupported Rails/Ruby combinations from test matrix
Fix first weekly occurrences with non-Sunday week start
body:
This change corrects the wday offset to account for the week start option in weekly rules.

Some refactoring was done to avoid adding conditionals and more complexity into the Schedule class which was coordinating this:

- Rules no longer depend on a Schedule object to validate: to simplify, they only require Time objects and calculate the next time coordinate from them.
- Rules no longer have a second argument for `week_start` except for the Weekly rule that uses it. This is to avoid confusion about where this option is actually used.

Much thanks to #360 and #284 for spotting the core issue here.

title: Remove & replace iCal support with dependency on icalendar gem
body:
Our implementation of iCal parsing is untested and lacking features. There exists a solid maintained [icalendar gem][icalendar] that could support conversion to/from .ics format for us.

IceCube is useful for generating the occurrence times from defined schedules, so these two gems could work well together and allow each to focus on its strengths.

This dependency could be optional.

If anyone has experience with the icalendar gem, I'd like to hear your thoughts on this proposal.

[icalendar]: https://rubygems.org/gems/icalendar

title: Fix day of year with negative offsets
body: Correct off-by-one error when counting backwards from the end of year.

title: Update gem tooling
body: Reviewed warning messages in test suite and updated to use the gem development facilities provided by bundler instead of supporting our own.

title: Use Integer class to avoid Fixnum deprecation warnings in ruby 2.4
body: This looks good. Thanks @patrickjaberg!

title: Possible bug in IceCube::Schedule#first()?
body:
**Intended behavior:**

 * Create a schedule that has less than 100 occurrences (example below, for example, let's say it has 25).
 * Grab the first 100 recurrences of a schedule.
 * I would expect that calling `schedule.first(100).length` would return 25.
 * Instead, I get an array with a length of 100, which goes beyond the schedules time frame.

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
# This creates an array of legnth "100"
# It also adds dates that are beynd the `end_time` of the Schedule.
IceCube::Schedule.new(Date.today, end_time: Date.today + 1.hour) do |sch|
  sch.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.send(:hourly, 1)
end.first(100).length
```

Is this behavior intended? I originally wanted to use `occurrences_between(start_time, end_time)` but found that the array returned was too large to fit in memory. I thought I could get around it via `.first()` but hit this issue.

 * Is this behavior intended?
 * Are there better ways to do this?

Thanks for the great library!

title: Fixing biweekly realign when used with spans option.
body:
This PR fixes an edge case bug for the use of the spans option when the biweekly realign method comes into effect. The realign method was being called with the opening time with the duration shift, whereas it should always be using the pure opening time.

Thanks for all the work you've been doing on the gem recently! It's not gone unnoticed.

title: Hourly schedule respecting DST
body:
First of all, thnx for this library!

If I use the hourly rule with a TimeWithZone class from ActiveSupport, and try to overlap a DST, I get properly disjunct time entries, which is correct:

```ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.new(2017, 3, 25, 10, 0, 0, '+01:00')) # day before DST in Central Europe
schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.hourly(12))
```

The result is this:

```ruby
Time.new(2017, 3, 25, 10, 0, 0, '+01:00'),
Time.new(2017, 3, 25, 22, 0, 0, '+01:00'),
Time.new(2017, 3, 26,  11, 0, 0, '+02:00'), # Although I'd love if it was 10:00
Time.new(2017, 3, 26, 23, 0, 0, '+02:00'),
```

I realize that the library behaviour is correct, but is there a way to follow DST rules (and actually in this case advance by 11 hours, not 12).

title: Using PERIOD as values for RDATE in Schedule
body:
As mentioned [here](http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/rdate.html), `RDATE` can have value as DATE or [PERIOD](https://icalendar.org/iCalendar-RFC-5545/3-3-9-period-of-time.html). But currently, only DATE is supported.

Basically, I want to allow addition of new recurrence dates (using `add_recurrence_time`) with different `end_time`. Is there any other way to achieve this ?

- rules don't have `until` or `count`

`All recurrence rules must specify .until or .count to use 'all_occurrences'`

    def all_occurrences
      require_terminating_rules
      enumerate_occurrences(start_time).to_a
    end

Would it be a good idea to rewrite `all_occurrences` (and other methods which call `require_terminating_rules`) to something like the following?

    def all_occurrences
      @end_time || require_terminating_rules
      enumerate_occurrences(start_time, @end_time).to_a
    end

I've just started using IceCube in a project where I'm already using DateTime, and of course I've been giving IceCube DateTime objects and receiving the warning about DateTime support being deprecated.

I'm just wondering what the motivation behind this is? Why not just continue converting DateTime to Time internally? In my experience, other than speed (which is rarely a concern unless you're writing a library like IceCube), DateTime is typically much nicer to work with.

Adjacent schedules conflict when over DST
body:
I have two weekly recurring schedules that are adjacent. One ends on the end of the day (eg. every Tuesday from 00:00 till 24:00) and the seconds starts at the beginning of the next day(eg. every Wednesday from 00:00 till 24:00). So far, `schedule#conflicts_with?(second_schedule, 6.months.from_now)` works fine and returns `false`.

But when the testing period is over a DST switch the method returns `true`.

```
  it "does not conflict with another bordering schedule over DST" do
    # February 16th in 2010 is a Tuesday
    start_time = Time.utc(2010, 2, 16, 0, 0, 0)
    end_time   = Time.utc(2010, 2, 17, 0, 0, 0)
    schedule1 = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, end_time: end_time)
    schedule1.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:tuesday)

    schedule2 = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, end_time: end_time)
    schedule1.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:wednesday)

    expect(schedule1).to_not be_conflicts_with(schedule2, Time.utc(2010, 7, 23, 0, 0, 0))
  end
```

Am I using the start and end time wrongfully? Or is there a bug in IceCube?
I've tried to understand the behaviour in detecting conflicting occurrences but it is really hard to comprehend stuff in there - respect and props for this super helpful gem!

title: Rails: Make Schedule.load Behave Like Other serialize()'d Objects
body: Values that are serialized via [ActiveRecord's `serialize`](http://api.rubyonrails.org/v4.2.2/classes/ActiveRecord/AttributeMethods/Serialization/ClassMethods.html#method-i-serialize) return an instance of the serialized class if the attribute is `nil`.  [`IceCube::Schedule#load` returns `nil`](https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/d8709623b31fc6d4bb0e881dcbcb36883b18d6f5/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb#L393).

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(t0 = Time.local(2016, 5, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(15, -1).day(:monday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday)
schedule.first(2).each { |occurrence| p occurrence.strftime('%A') }

"Wednesday"

title: Full Timezone Support
body:
This adds full timezone support to ice_cube (when using ActiveSupport). It builds off of (and supercedes) #295 

The naming when discussing timezones gets confusing, there are named UTC offsets (such as PDT = UTC - 7 hours and PST = UTC - 8 hours) that are often referred to as timezones. There are also timezones that map to a geographical region and account for daylight savings time there, such as those specified in the [IANA Timezone Database](http://www.iana.org/time-zones) like "America/Los_Angeles". These are also referred to as timezones. The latter is much more useful, because you can represent things like 5 hours after midnight on the boundary of a daylight savings time border and get the right value.

Previously the `to_ical` method with timezones enabled uses "%Z" strftime which outputs timezone offsets like PDT, but it should instead output timezones from the IANA timezone database. This PR updates this.

The code in #295 for `from_ical` is already expecting the timezone to be of the latter format, so that code works as expected.

title: Inconsistant first occurrence
body:
Hi Guys,

The behaviour for the 'first occurrence' seems inconsistent between monthly and weekly schedules. Below is my output from the console

```
2.1.3 :063 > schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Date.new(2016,4,8))     
2.1.3 :065 > schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.send(:weekly, 4).day(:sunday)      
2.1.3 :066 > schedule.occurrences(Date.new(2016,9,1))   
 => [2016-05-01 00:00:00 +0100, 2016-05-29 00:00:00 +0100, 2016-06-26 00:00:00 +0100, 2016-07-24 00:00:00 +0100, 2016-08-21 0
0:00:00 +0100] 

2.1.3 :096 > schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Date.new(2016,4,8))   
2.1.3 :098 > schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.send(:monthly, 6)      
2.1.3 :099 > schedule.occurrences(Date.new(2017,9,1))                                                                        
 => [2016-04-08 00:00:00 +0100, 2016-10-08 00:00:00 +0100, 2017-04-08 00:00:00 +0100] 
```

as you can see the 'first instance' for something which repeats weekly, for every 4 weeks, is 4 weeks after the initial start date. Where the first instance for something that repeats every 6 months is the **start date** AND 6 months after the start date.

What are the rules around 'first occurrence'?

Thanks,

Ian

title: Rules can override schedule's duration
body:
fixes #322.

I added the possibility to override the duration of a schedule in a rule. This is made with a new validator (OverrideDuration) to keep the syntax as easy as `Rule.daily.override_duration(4.hours)`

I changed all the methods that make use of `schedule.duration` to give precedence to `rule.duration`

**About builders**
- `StringBuilder` was not affected because I see that `schedule.to_s` doesn't output schedule's duration either
- `HashBuilder` is used to store `:duration` in case the rule has a duration.
- `ICalBuilder` was not changed because adding 'DURATION' would bring to conflicts with schedule's duration or even with other rules. Maybe it's not an optimal solution, but I didn't see in the code a handling of the iCal property 'DURATION', so I didn't want to break anything.

I tested with these ruby versions: 1.9.3-p551, 2.0.0-p643, ruby-2.1.5, ruby-2.2.2, ruby-2.3.0 1.9.3

I didn't change or remove any old test and I just added new tests to fully cover all my changes. All tests pass in my machine.

Hope this may help

title: Fix day_of_year
body: Looks like a simple fix - i.e. `day_of_year(-1)` should refer to day 365 (in a non-leap year), but as written it'll result in 364 (-1 + 365, on line 34). This should fix #277.

title: Remove deprecation warning
body: We don't want to be warn if the `start_date` key is only present for retrocompatibility purpose.

title: Fix WEEKLY recurring when specifying non default WKST
Exception rules no longer serializing?
body:
First of all thanks for the great gem :raised_hands: We've created hundreds of schedules over the past year with great success. However we seem to be running into some issues lately :)

Most of our schedules look something like this:

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start = Time.utc(2015, 1, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.day(:wednesday, :saturday, :sunday)
schedule.add_exception_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.month_of_year(:february).day_of_month(7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)
schedule.add_exception_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.month_of_year(:december).day_of_month(25, 26)
schedule.add_exception_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.month_of_year(:january).day_of_month(1)
```

We store the result of `schedule.to_yaml` in our database. At some point in the last few weeks my coworker and I couldn't get exceptions to work anymore. I haven't been able to conclude as of why, but it seems exception_rules are no longer being serialised to to YAML (or Hash).
### Test case

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start = Time.utc(2015, 1, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.day(:wednesday, :saturday, :sunday)

schedule.occurrences(2.months.from_now).size
=> 201

schedule.to_yaml
=> "---\n:start_time: 2015-01-01 00:00:00.000000000 Z\n:rrules:\n- :validations:\n    :day:\n    - 3\n    - 6\n    - 0\n  :rule_type: IceCube::DailyRule\n  :interval: 1\n:rtimes: []\n:extimes: []\n"

schedule.add_exception_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.month_of_year(:february).day_of_month(7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)
schedule.occurrences(2.months.from_now).size
=> 193

schedule.to_yaml
=> "---\n:start_time: 2015-01-01 00:00:00.000000000 Z\n:rrules:\n- :validations:\n    :day:\n    - 3\n    - 6\n    - 0\n  :rule_type: IceCube::DailyRule\n  :interval: 1\n:rtimes: []\n:extimes: []\n"
```

As you can see the output of the `to_yaml` calls is identical.
### Env
- Ruby 2.2.2
- ice_cube 0.13.3
- Rails 4.2.5.1

However I'm experiencing the same issue on regular `irb` without Rails.

title: Duration (and end_time) assigned to Rules instead of Schedule
body:
Thanks for this gem, it's super useful and I like everything.

There's a feature I would like to implement though, but before starting I'd ask you what you think about it.

I suppose this gem is built with the convintion that the duration (or end_time) should be related to the schedule, but I think it's better to assign duration to the Rules. I explain why.

I'm creating a Rails booking engine, that should allow developers to implement a booking system for various use cases (hotels, apartments, shows, meeting rooms etc...). Let's take the MeetingRoom case.
I would create an IceCube::Schedule attribute into the MeetingRoom model, that represents the availability of the MeetingRoom. Let's say this MeetingRoom is available on mondays and tuesdays from 8AM to 10AM and from 2PM to 6PM.

the 8AM-10AM interval has a duration of 2 hours, while the 2PM to 6PM has a duration of 4 hours. Having the duration related to Rules would allow for keeping the whole availability of the MeetingRoom inside the same Schedule. This would be great for making occurrence queries once, instead of having a number schedules I should cycle everytime. 

I hope I explained the problem. I'm really interested in this gem, and it would be great to include it in my engine, but the single schedule thing is a costraint I need.

title: Travis: Update bundler before installing gems
body:
Some versions of bundler are affected by a bug that causes them to throw

```
NoMethodError: undefined method `spec' for nil:NilClass
```

during installation of the yaml_db gem. This bug was fixed in bundler@a0c90cd, but several of
Travis's Ruby environments are based on older affected versions. To resolve, we force an update.

title: I18n cleanup

- Use `date.day_names` and `date.month_names` keys directly rather than duplicating them under the `ice_cube` key
- Remove unused keys

  - `date.order`
  - `time`
- Make whitespace consistent across files, and consistent with Ruby's `to_yaml`

s.start_time = Time.now # 2016-01-22 01:17:20 +0530
s.next_occurrences(2)
=> [2016-02-09 01:18:01 +0530, 2016-03-09 01:18:01 +0530]
```

``` ruby
RRULE: FREQ=MONTHLY;INTERVAL=1;BYMONTHDAY=9;COUNT=10
Start Time: 2016-02-08 22:00:00 UTC
End Time: 2016-02-08 23:00:00 UTC

System Time Zone was in EST. It should give.

Start Time: 2016-02-08 17:00:00 EST
End Time: 2016-02-08 18:00:00 EST

But itâ€™s giving

Start Time: 2016-02-09 17:00:00 EST
End Time: 2016-02-09 18:00:00 EST

apply_ical= "DTSTART;TZID=PST:20160108T200000\nRRULE:FREQ=MONTHLY;BYMONTHDAY=9;COUNT=10"
s = IceCube::Schedule.from_ical(apply_ical)
s.next_occurrence(2)
# => [2016-02-09 20:00:00 +0530, 2016-03-09 20:00:00 +0530]
```

When we convert the rule into IST it should give 10th of every month. As IST ahead of +05:30.

did I miss something to convert the timezone for the rule. Are this is the way it works??

title: Duration of occurrence over DST boundary needs to be an exception
body:
Iâ€™ve got a three hour event scheduled every week from midnight to 3am Sunday morning, and another event scheduled from 3am to 6am every Sunday. Iâ€™m using durations of three hours each.

On March 13, the three hour event starting at midnight goes until 4am, causing a time conflict with the event starting at 3am. Is it possible for that one occurrence to be two hours long? Or to specify in some other way that it must end at 3am?

title: Parse incoming RDATE lines from iCal files, handle all-day RDATE and EXDATE
body: Howdy friends. I have been evaluating different options to enumerate occurrences between dates, given only an iCal file. I think ice_cube is great for it. However, I must support RDATE, and it seems this change is all I need to finally adopt ice_cube. I hope you find it useful, and it finds its way into the gem. Cheers.

title: i18n update should be a major version bump
body:
The latest version 0.13.1 (introduction of i18n) looks like a nice update. However, it breaks backward compatibility with custom validations. As such probably should have been a major version bump, IMHO. The following code no longer works:

``` ruby
        StringBuilder.register_formatter(:year) do |entries|
          "in #{StringBuilder.sentence(entries)}"
        end
```

Now requires invocation of i18n library.

Thanks!

title: Add i18n
body:
An amalgamation of:
- @tomoyuki28jp's https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/pull/259
- @dgilperez's work over at https://github.com/dgilperez/ice_cube
- @isaacseymour's work at https://github.com/dgilperez/ice_cube/pull/1

Specs should pass and this should be :ok_hand: to go...

title: Schedule as value object
body:
We're implementing support for models with duration in our rails backend with `IceCube::Schedule` and I wonder whether we could implement the `==`, `eql?` and `hash` methods so that we can determine the equality of two schedules.

So far, we have implemented them in our value object that wraps `IceCube::Schedule`, but it's less than ideal as it forces us to either deal with its internal state or serialize it and compare the resulting strings.

I would be more than happy to implement it myself, but what are your thoughts on this? have you considered it before?

title: #occurrences_between returning inconsistent times when passing through the DST time change
body:
We have seen that occurrences_between gives us different times given the same recurring event but with different start times. 

Note, this is using Rails 3's `ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone`.

``` RUBY
est_string = 'Eastern Time (US & Canada)'

before_dst = Time.new(2015, 10, 27, 5, 15, 0, 0).in_time_zone(est_string)
sched_before_dst = IceCube::Schedule.new(before_dst, duration: 603600)
sched_before_dst.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(2)
sched_before_dst.occurrences_between(3.weeks.ago, 3.weeks.from_now)

#=> [
# Tue, 27 Oct 2015 01:15:00 EDT -04:00,
# Tue, 03 Nov 2015 01:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 10 Nov 2015 01:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 17 Nov 2015 01:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 24 Nov 2015 01:15:00 EST -05:00
# ]

after_dst = Time.new(2015, 11, 03, 5, 15, 0, 0).in_time_zone(est_string)
sched_after_dst = IceCube::Schedule.new(after_dst, duration: 603600)
sched_after_dst.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(2)
sched_after_dst.occurrences_between(3.weeks.ago, 3.weeks.from_now)

#=> [
# Tue, 03 Nov 2015 00:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 10 Nov 2015 00:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 17 Nov 2015 00:15:00 EST -05:00,
# Tue, 24 Nov 2015 00:15:00 EST -05:00
# ]
```

Note that the only difference is that starting time which was before the DST change(Oct 27) vs after(Nov 3). Both are at 12:15AM and have a duration of 6 days, 23 hours and 40 min. Both have the same recurring schedule (weekly every Tuesday) and as you can see, they have the correct dates but very different hours. To note, in the schedule before the DST change, **Nov 10 becomes 1:15AM EST** but in the schedule after, **Nov 10 stays at 12:15AM EST**. These results can further be proven different by converting them to UTC. Logically, all these dates should be at **05:15AM UTC** but if you convert **Tue, 03 Nov 2015 01:15:00 EST -05:00** to UTC, it advances an hour to **06:15AM UTC**

Is there something we are doing wrong here? Or is it a legitimate bug?

title: fixed parsing of ical with multiple recurrence rules
body: Each new rule parsed from ical overwrote earlier ones.

title: Add validation to prevent nil rules
body:
Stumbled on this by accident but the `add_recurrence_rule` / `add_exception_rule` methods allow nil which later leads to errors like below when invoking various methods like `occurrences_between`:

`NoMethodError: undefined method`reset' for nil:NilClass`

Simple example:

``` ruby
s = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.now)
s.add_recurrence_rule(Random.new)
s.occurrences_between(Time.now, Time.now + 36000)
```

I was also thinking it could be a good idea to add a `is_a?(Rule)` validation as well since there are quite a few methods an object has to respond to in order to work as a Rule but I just left it at a simple nil check for now.

title: Suitable for users with different availability times?
body:
Hi guys, I'm trying to find out if this gem is suitable for a particular use case I have.

I want to set up an availability schedule where users can enter, for each day of the week, what hours of the day they are available and if there will be any exceptions when they are not available at a particular time.

For instance a user will say I am available on Mondays between 7am and 1pm and also between 4pm and 7pm (and so forth for the other days of the week). I also need to add particular exceptions so even if a user says they are free between 7am and 1pm on a Monday they can say I will not be free this particular Monday between 10am and 11am (the start and end times are important)

Is this gem suitable for this case? Looking into it so far it seems to do different availability times for different days of the week I will need to setup a new schedule for each day (would rather avoid this) and also that the exceptions don't support end times. Ideally I would want all this information in a single schedule hash stored on the user and then load that up when I need it.

Thanks

title: Fxes issue #303 preventing multiple rule parsing
body: See issue #303 for example, just a simple fix to add elements to an array in the hash key rather than assigning a new array every time a rule was processed.

title: iCal parsing doesn't process multiple rules
body:
iCal parsing is only handling the last rule processed, example:

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:monday, :tuesday)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly(2).day(:friday)

cal = schedule.to_ical
=> "DTSTART;TZID=CDT:20151005T195541\nRRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=MO,TU\nRRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;INTERVAL=2;WKST=SU;BYDAY=FR"

parsed = IceCube::Schedule.from_ical(cal)
parsed.recurrence_rules.size
=> 1

cal2 = parsed.to_ical
=> "DTSTART;TZID=CDT:20151005T195541\nRRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;INTERVAL=2;WKST=SU;BYDAY=FR"
```

title: Option to include prior occurrences with overlapping duration
body:
Adding an option on schedule methods to include occurrences whose duration intersects a time window. Issue #154

https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/issues/154

title: Range of time per days
body:
Hey guys,
I was wondering if it's possible to limit the recurrence of a rule to a specific range of time.
For example, I would like to generate occurrences every 30 minutes every days between 9:00AM and 6:00PM.
Is there a way to do that ? I tried a couple of times with different rules but without success.
If it's not, I think it could be a very nice add in my opinion.

Thanks.

title: Why does this library skip February?
body:
This line surprised me:

> Monthly rules will skip months that are too short for the specified day of month (e.g. no occurrences in February for day_of_month(31)).

I was thinking that was the whole point of this library. Doesn't really make any sense to provide a library for calculating recurring dates and then skip entire months, right? I don't see how it's useful with this limitation.

Has there been any discussion around adding this or any patches that will make it work?

title: Schedule with no recurrence rules creating an occurrence
body:
I have an application in which there may or may not be `IceCube::Rule.weekly` rules, and may or may not be `IceCube::SingleOccurrenceRule` rules. When there's no rule, or when there's only `IceCube::SingleOccurrenceRule` rules, the schedule creates an occurrence at the start time passed to its initializer (at `start_time` in `IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time)`).

Is this the expected behaviour or is it a bug? If it's its expected behaviour, how can I avoid the creation of this occurrence?

title: Rota weeks - i.e. Every 8 weeks on the Monday and Wednesday of weeks 2,3 and 5
body: Is this possible? I couldn't see any way to do this in the RFC5545 spec either. Duration, DTSTART etc. are all the same. I couldn't think of any rule combination that could be used as a workaround and creating 8 separate, nearly identical, schedules doesn't seem very DRY.

title: Weekly rule with no validations
body:
I'm having some trouble wrapping my head around the situation that a weekly rule with no validations has occurrences every week.  How do I discern that from a rule that has a validation on Saturday vs a calendar with no validations, but created on Saturday?

Trying to be more clear, a weekly rule has these occurrences within the next 21 days.
[Mon, 06 Jul 2015 20:33:20 UTC +00:00, Mon, 13 Jul 2015 20:33:20 UTC +00:00, Mon, 20 Jul 2015 20:33:20 UTC +00:00, Mon, 27 Jul 2015 20:33:20 UTC +00:00], even when no validations are added.

Is this a bug?  We have a situation where the user checks black out days, and if they check none, I'm having difficulty understanding what that means on a generic level.  For weeks it might be obvious, but how about hours, months, etc.

Thanks for any/all input!

title: Parse time zones when creating schedules from ICAL; fix DST test bug
Lower from warn to debug the log IceCube: :#{old_key} is deprecated, please use :#{new_key} at: #{ caller[0] } and similar
body:
In production is common to have a log level set to `warn`.

Having these logs in production causes:
- explosion of log size.
- performance issues.

We don't want to raise the log level to `error` in production neither we are able to quickly sanitize our serialized schedule fileds (_how can we do it quickly, BTW?_).

(_gem version_: **0.12.1**)

A business days is for me when there is no weekend and no bank holiday.

title: Adding namespacing to Rule in Readme to make it easier to run examples
body: While experimenting with this library with my team I ran into the inconvenience that some of the usages of Rule in the readme are namespaced to IceCube:: and some are not, so here is a PR. :space_invader:

title: Improvement: rule equivalent to BYSETPOS?
body:
From RFC2445:

```
The BYSETPOS rule part specifies a COMMA character (US-ASCII decimal
44) separated list of values which corresponds to the nth occurrence
within the set of events specified by the rule. Valid values are 1 to
366 or -366 to -1. It MUST only be used in conjunction with another
BYxxx rule part. For example "the last work day of the month" could
be represented as:

  RRULE:FREQ=MONTHLY;BYDAY=MO,TU,WE,TH,FR;BYSETPOS=-1

Each BYSETPOS value can include a positive (+n) or negative (-n)
integer. If present, this indicates the nth occurrence of the
specific occurrence within the set of events specified by the rule.
```

I don't think IceCube supports this right now. It would allow creating rules like the above "last work day of the month". Some ways to emulate this particular case are (as recurrence rules for Sidetiq jobs):
1. `monthly.day_of_month(-1, -2, -3)` and when ran, checking today's weekday
2. same, but excluding `daily.day(:saturday, :sunday)`. Not much better, can still occur more then once a month, when none of the last three days fall on a weekend.

Calling that hypothetical new rule `indexed` for now, one could write `monthly.day(:monday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday).indexed(-1)`. That rule would first evaluate to all weekdays in a month, and then restricted to the last one, whichever weekday that would be.

title: week_of_year support?
body: Is specifying a rule like "on the 25th week of the year" supported? I can't seem to find it. It corresponds to iCal's `BYWEEKNO` field.

2015-01-01 05:00:00 UTC
2015-01-01 05:00:00 UTC

true

Huh? I have no idea why `schedule.start_time.utc` changes the result. Does the call to `.utc` suddenly define what the time zone is?

title: occurrences_between gives results in unexpected time zone
body:
I'm creating a schedule with recurrence rules, and when I create one with a weekly recurrence rule, then I run `occurrences_between(begin, end)`, it gives me the results in the time zone of the `begin` value passed in. However, when I create a schedule with a daily recurrence rule, and I run `occurrences_between(begin, end)`, it gives results in UTC.

Relevant code:

```
def schedule(starts_at = nil, ends_at = nil)
  starts_at ||= scheduled_from
  ends_at ||= scheduled_to
  if duration > 0
    s = IceCube::Schedule.new(starts_at, end_time: ends_at, duration: duration)
  else
    s = IceCube::Schedule.new(starts_at, end_time: ends_at)
  end
  case repeats
  when 'never'
    s.add_recurrence_time(starts_at)
  when 'daily'
    if repeat_ends == 'never'
      s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily(repeats_every_n_days)
    else
      s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily(repeats_every_n_days).until(repeat_ends_on)
    end
  when 'weekly'
    days = repeats_weekly_each_days_of_the_week.map {|d| d.to_sym }
    if repeat_ends == 'never'
      s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly(repeats_every_n_weeks).day(*days)
    else
      s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly(repeats_every_n_weeks).day(*days).until(repeat_ends_on)
    end
    [...additional config irrelevant to this piece...]
  end
end
```

title: Fix WEEKLY recurring when specifying non default WKST
body: fixes a nasty edge case where we advance past the start of the opening_time and miss occurrences.

title: Serialize as UTC always & deserialize in local time zone
body:
Our users specify which time zone they want all of there dates/times to appear in the UI. Therefore, we need to store everything as UTC, which is handled by Rails. However when serializing the schedule into the DB, we want to keep those times as UTC. If we store `start_time` as UTC then `TimeUtil` does all of its calculations based on UTC and not the user's time zone.

To use the code as it stands now, we would have to serialize the `start_time` with the user's current time zone so that `TimeUtil` does the right thing. However, as soon as the user changes their time zone the serialized data is now wrong.

We used the following monkey patch to get the effect that we wanted:

```
module IceCube
  module TimeUtil

    def self.serialize_time(time)
      time.utc
    end

    def self.deserialize_time(value)
      case value
      when Hash
        hash = FlexibleHash.new(value)
        hash[:time].in_time_zone
      else
        if value.respond_to? :in_time_zone
          value.in_time_zone
        elsif value.respond_to? :to_s
          Time.zone.parse(value)
        end
      end
    end
  end
end
```

title: Implement (override) hash method and supply hash serializer
body:
IceCube::Schedule should implement the :hash method so that in-place modifications (rails) are sense, and can be saved.

https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/15458

Also, a native hash serializer would be nice. YAML is slower and (IMHO) not any easier to read than a hash.

```
  class IceCube::Hasher
    def self.dump(schedule)
      return {} if schedule.blank?
      schedule.to_hash
    end

    def self.load(hash)
      hash = {} if hash.blank?
      return IceCube::Schedule.from_yaml(hash) if !!(hash =~ /\A---/)
      IceCube::Schedule.from_hash(hash)
    end
  end
```

title: Rule from hash missing validations
body:
I'm not sure what's going one here, but it doesn't seem like `next_occurrences` is obeying this recurring rule logic:

``` ruby
hash = {"validations"=>{"day"=>[]}, "rule_type"=>"IceCube::WeeklyRule", "interval"=>2, "until"=>nil, "count"=>nil}
```

So I turn the hash into an IceCube rule...

``` ruby
$ rule = IceCube::Rule.from_hash hash
=> #<IceCube::WeeklyRule:0x007fb4b5bb39f8

 Tue, 24 Mar 2015 00:00:00 UTC +00:00,
 Wed, 25 Mar 2015 00:00:00 UTC +00:00,
 Thu, 26 Mar 2015 00:00:00 UTC +00:00]
```

What am I missing here?

What does it show a week of consecutive days?

title: Depend on ActiveSupport?
body: What's the reason ice_cube tries to avoid depending on ActiveSupport? It seems like a lot of ice_cube code replicates functionality that would be a gimme if ActiveSupport were made a dependency.

title: Week start option for week_of_month on monthly schedules
body:
Hello, this is more a question than an issue but i can't figure out how to build this schedule:

Let's say i have an event starting on saturday and ending on sunday. I want it to repeat on the first, third and fifth weekend on the month. The tricky part is that i consider the first weekend of the month to be the one where you have the first sunday. So the first occurrence of a month can start on the last day of the previous month.

Thanks in advance for the response !

Gil

title: Is it possible to link a Schedule to a Model for querying?
body:
Hi Guys, I've got an Event model that has a :schedule column to store my recurring rules for Ice Cube, like so:

```

---
:start_time: &1 2015-01-26 00:00:00.000000000 +00:00
:start_date: *1
:rrules:
- :validations:
    :day_of_month:
    - 1
  :rule_type: IceCube::MonthlyRule
  :interval: 1
:rtimes: []
:extimes: []
```

In that example I have an Event that recurs every month but I have another Event that recurs weekly. Is there a way I can list all of the occurrences for both of these Events using ice_cube?

The aim is to list all occurrences of Events happening for any particular month like this:

**January 2015**
- Monthly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event

**February 2015**
- Monthly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event
- Weekly Event

Ideally I'd like to be able to do something like this to return all occurrences:

```
@all_events = Event.occurs_between?(now, now + 1.month)
```

Is this at all possible with ice_cube?

Thanks,
Chris

title: ice_cube not selecting the last day of the year correctly?
body:
I was testing with this gem and noticed when I used:

the date returned was 12/30 and not 12/31.

my example:
[1] pry(main)> require 'ice_cube'
=> true
[2] pry(main)> last_day_of_year = IceCube::Schedule.new(now = Time.now) do |s|

title: Weekly rule occurring on multiple days of the week, every X > 1 weeks returns incorrect results for next_occurrences on some days of the week
body:
Given a schedule occurring every 3 weeks on Monday and Tuesday at noon,

The next occurrence on Monday will be omitted from the result set when calling next_occurrences with a date on a Monday of a non-occurring week, on or after the start time of the occurrence.

This can be exposed by doing the following

A schedule occurring every 3 weeks on Monday/Tuesdays starting on Nov 3. It should occur on Nov 3, Nov4, Nov 24, Nov 25, Dec 15, Dec, 16, Jan 5, Jan 6, ....

s = Schedule.new(Time.utc(2014,11,3,12))
s.add_recurrence_rule Rule.weekly(3).day(:monday, :tuesday)

On Monday Dec 29 at 12:00, our next occurrence is Tuesday Jan 6 (Should be Jan 5)

s.next_occurrences(3, Time.utc(2014,12,29,12))
 => [2015-01-06 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-26 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-27 12:00:00 UTC]

On Monday Dec 22 at 12:00, our next occurrence is Tuesday Jan 6 (Should be Jan 5)

s.next_occurrences(3, Time.utc(2014,12,22,12))
 => [2015-01-06 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-26 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-27 12:00:00 UTC]

On Tuesday Dec 23 at 12:00, our next occurrence is Tuesday Jan 5 (Correct)

s.next_occurrences(3, Time.utc(2014,12,23,12))
 => [2015-01-05 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-06 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-26 12:00:00 UTC]

On Monday Dec 29 at 11:59:59, our next occurrence is Tuesday Jan 5 (Correct)

s.next_occurrences(3, Time.utc(2014,12,29,11,59,59))
 => [2015-01-05 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-06 12:00:00 UTC, 2015-01-26 12:00:00 UTC]

I have reproduced this behavior on ruby 2.1.1p76 (2014-02-24 revision 45161) [x86_64-linux], ruby 1.9.3p545 (2014-02-24 revision 45159) [x86_64-linux] and ruby 1.8.7 (2013-06-27 patchlevel 374) [x86_64-linux](using backports). All in RVM on Ubuntu 12.04 LTS.

title: Infinity loop on next_occurrence method
body:
Hi,
There is a issue on the `next_occurrence` method when you add a recurrence rule with a invalid day of month it enters on a infinity loop.

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(now = Time.now)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_month(42)
schedule.next_occurrence
```

title: Allow strings to be passed in for day names
body:
This is to support a use case in which, for example, a rails form has checkboxes that correspond to the days of the week.

Developers might be tempted to call

``` ruby
params[:days_of_week].map { |day_of_week|
  IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(day_of_week.to_sym)
}
```

which is bad because it is a symbol table overflow vulnerability.

It seems that IceCube could help us out here by forgiving our strings.

body:
Hi there, 

I'm using IceCube to add schedules to an record. When adding an record like so: 

``` ruby
t.schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.now, end_time: Time.zone.now + 1.hour)
```

I get the following error:

``` ruby
IceCube: :start_date is deprecated, please use :start_time at: /opt/rubies/2.1.2/lib/ruby/gems/2.1.0/gems/ice_cube-0.12.1/lib/ice_cube/parsers/hash_parser.rb:11:in `to_schedule'
```

But when i'm doing it the 'right' way,  (with start_time - in the docs), like so: 

``` ruby

```

I'm getting the error, and will not save this schedule: 

``` ruby
NoMethodError: undefined method `utc?' for #<Hash:0x007fdf05392470>
```

Converting the Time.zone to UTC doesn't fix this problem .. 

Also the end_time (t.schedule.end_time) is always returning null, but I guess that I'm not saving the schedule properly and that the problem above is the actual problem.

title: Occurrences between
body:
Hi @seejohnrun 

Is it possible to return all the occurrences between a given timeframe? So let's say I want all the occurrences from 10 June until 12 June?

Just like the `occurrences` method but for dates. With the option for a start and end date.

``` ruby
# list occurrences until end_time (end_time is needed for non-terminating rules)
occurrences = schedule.occurrences(end_time) # [now]
```

Cheers.

title: Unexpected next_occurrence with interval
body:
When I have a schedule with a recurrence rule that has an interval, I get unexpected behaviour. This spec should hopefully show what I expect and what actually happens.

``` ruby
it "should calculate the next occurrence with an interval" do
  start_time  = Time.parse("03-11-2014")
  schedule    = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time)

  schedule.rrule(IceCube::Rule.monthly(2).day_of_month(1))

  schedule.next_occurrence.should == Time.parse("01-12-2014")
  # => Failure/Error: schedule.next_occurrence.should == Time.parse("01-12-2014")
  #   expected: 2014-12-01 00:00:00 +0000
  #   got:      2015-01-01 00:00:00 +0000
end
```

Is this behaviour intentional, or is this a bug?

title: serializable attribute of type IceCube::Schedule, and missing eql?
body:
Hello,
I am using IceCube as `serializable` attribute for an ActiveRecord : `serialize :schedule, IceCube::Schedule`

I have noticed that the [dirty module](http://apidock.com/rails/ActiveRecord/Dirty) for `ActiveRecord` is not working properly for me. Changes are not detected since the default equals operator is not enough.

I propose overriding the equals operator. Something like this is working for me;

```
module IceCube

  class Schedule

    def eql?(other)
      other.is_a?(IceCube::Schedule) &&
      (to_hash == other.to_hash)
    end

    def ==(other)
      eql?(other)
    end

end
```

-J-

---

P.D. Thanks for this great project

title: TimeWithZone loses time zone when serialized
body:
There is an issue with ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone where it converts everything to UTC before serializing via to_yaml(). This actually breaks recurrence rules in many instances, since things like weekly rules utilize the day of week. If the start_time or end_time or until_time changes day when converted to UTC, the rules will break.

I am going to try to fix this in my code by converting all TimeWithZone objects to standard Ruby Time objects (using to_time()) before passing them into IceCube. Since this bug has been biting my ass for a few weeks now, I don't have time to create any test cases or a git pull request, but if I have some time available in the next week or two and no one else has addressed it yet, I will give it a shot. The two solutions I can think of are to internally convert TimeWithZone objects to Time objects before serialization, or to update the rules classes to adjust themselves. Since the latter solution would actually change RRULES (and prevent them from being created in time zones other than UTC, since the time zone info is lost), I think internally converting to Ruby Time objects is probably the better solution.

Thoughts?

line #408 of the following is probably what's causing this, and I can't figure out the intention of this code.

schedule.rb

```
    403: def enumerate_occurrences(opening_time, closing_time = nil, &block)
    404:   opening_time = TimeUtil.match_zone(opening_time, start_time)

title: Inconsistent occurrences_between behaviour on weekly intervals
body:
Lots of head scratching going on here...

I have a rule for 3 days every other week and occurrences_between gives me the correct result when I look for occurrences +/- 7 days from an expected date and +/- 1 day but I get an incorrect result when looking +/- 5 or 6 days.

``` ruby
require 'ice_cube'
IceCube::VERSION # "0.12.0" 

start_date = Date.parse('2014-01-08')
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_date)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly(2).day([4,5,6])

expected = Date.parse('2014-07-24') # Thursday

schedule.occurs_on?(expected) # true

schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 7, expected + 7).include?(expected.to_time) # true
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 1, expected + 1).include?(expected.to_time) # true
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 6, expected + 6).include?(expected.to_time) # false
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 6, expected + 1).include?(expected.to_time) # false
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 5, expected + 6).include?(expected.to_time) # false
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 1, expected + 6).include?(expected.to_time) # true
schedule.occurrences_between(expected - 4, expected + 6).include?(expected.to_time) # true
```

I've forked ice_cube and added a failing spec (pr to follow).

``` ruby
describe 'weekly schedule with interval' do
  let(:schedule) {Schedule.new('2014-01-08'.to_date)}
  let(:expected_occurrence) {'2014-07-24'.to_date.to_time}

  before :each do
    schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.weekly(2).day([4,5,6])
  end
  it "should include the expected date" do
    expect(schedule.occurs_on?(expected_occurrence)).to be_true
    expect(schedule.occurrences_between(expected_occurrence - 7.days, expected_occurrence + 7.days)).to include(expected_occurrence)
    expect(schedule.occurrences_between(expected_occurrence - 1.day, expected_occurrence + 1.day)).to include(expected_occurrence)
    expect(schedule.occurrences_between(expected_occurrence - 6.days, expected_occurrence + 6.days)).to include(expected_occurrence) # fails here
    expect(schedule.occurrences_between(expected_occurrence - 5.days, expected_occurrence + 5.days)).to include(expected_occurrence)
  end
end
```

title: next_occurrences should respect the end_time
body: Not sure if this is intended behavior or a bug, but it seemed like a bug, so here's a patch ;)

title: HashParser defaults to a hash when passed a nil value
body:
When init-ing a `HashParser` with a nil value, the following error is thrown when calling `to_schedule`: `TypeError: can't dup NilClass`.

This PR fixes that by ensuring a hash value is initialized if a nil value is passed.

title: Iso8601 dates
body:
Add support for deserialisation of ISO8601 date strings.
Adding this makes it a lot easier to work with JSON representations of schedules, or schedules that have been saved in a postgresql json-typed column.

title: Fix blank YAML serialization
body:
When an ActiveRecord attribute has a default value of `nil` or `""`, this fixes it so that serializing it as a schedule does not wrap it in YAML, to avoid attempting to reload it as a schedule on the other end.

Blank values should remain untouched.

Fixes #231

title: CI test against Ruby 2.1.x
body: Ruby switched to semantic versioning as of 2.1, so the third version level is now just the patch level. Using just `2.1` will point to the latest patch level (that rvm knows about).

title: Fix a typo in the README
Chronic like input for Ice Cube
body:
I'm not sure if something like this exists or not, but I was wondering if there was any parser out there that took natural language and pushed it into an IceCube format.

Example: "daily"
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily

Example: "everytuesday"
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.weekly(1).day(:tuesday)

Example: "3pm"
... etc

Does something like this exist yet?

title: HashParser#schedule handles a nil value for @hash
body:
In a Rails application I'm serializing an attribute, `schedule`, using the `Icecube::Schedule` class. I'm unable to load any objects where the `schedule` has not been set, i.e. it has a `nil` value. This is due to a `TypeError` that occurs within `HashParser#to_schedule` method. 

When Rails attempts to load an ActiveRecord object that has a serialized `IceCube::Schedule` class it calls `IceCube::Schedule.load`, https://github.com/wallace/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb#L386.  The call chain eventually calls `HashParser#to_schedule`, https://github.com/wallace/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb#L343 with a `nil` value for `@hash` which results in a `TypeError` "can't dup NilClass" when `HashParser` attempts to normalize the keys.

This pull request ensures that `to_schedule` handles a `nil` value in the `@hash` by default to an empty hash when `@hash` is `nil`. I'd prefer to use `to_h` but that's not available in Ruby 1.9.3. :(

title: update rspec version and should syntax to expect
Shouldn't previous_occurrence return a date based on the recurrence rule instead of nil given the start time?
body:
based on [this spec](https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/f20184bcb016566a3e754d89d15a08440949b888/spec/examples/schedule_spec.rb#L433):

previous_occurrence returns nil if it is given a start date. I suggest that this should actually return a date based on the recurrence rule, so given a daily schedule that starts at "May 5, 2014", it should return "May 4, 2014". 

Am I missing another method that does this or is there an explanation why previous_occurrence has to return nil given the start date?

title: Deprecation message improvement
body: There are no functional changes in this request, it simply adds the caller to deprecation messages to aid in correction of deprecated use.

title: Fix the doc to include namespace
body: Making it easier for someone to copy paste and try the example as namespace is required

title: Issues/50 from ical
body: This is new, freshly rebased PR for continuing from_ical issue implementation -

title: Update doc
body: doc should reflect IceCube::Schedule and not Schedule when creating a Schedule object

title: correct descriptions of minutely and secondly
body: The `minutely` and `secondly` recurrences have nothing to do with hours. But the existing description for minutely ("by minute of hour") implies that `minutely(13)` would occur on the 13th minute of every hour, which is not the case.

title: Clarify that human-readable to_s is not provided for whole schedules.
body: NA

title: Fix gemspec and run transpec
body:
1. Fixed gemspec to load by using 'activesupport'
2. Updated gemspec to allow more recent versions of RSpec
3. Ran transpec to update specs to RSpec 3.x syntax

title: Add deprecations and settings for compatibility
body:
Changing :start_date to :start_time everywhere will take a while for some users due to serialized schedules that still have this key.

For now we'll export both start_time and start_date in serialized output but this duplication should be removed in the next version.

We will continue to read both :start_date and :start_time, with a preference for the new :start_time.

title: Fix: Occurrence#overnight? did not work for start times on the last day of a month
body:
When the `overnight?` method was called on an occurrence with a start time on the last day of a month, it threw an `argument out of range` exception.

```
[1] pry(main)> occurrence = IceCube::Occurrence.new Time.new(2014, 3, 31)
=> 2014-03-31 00:00:00 +0200
[2] pry(main)> occurrence.overnight?
ArgumentError: argument out of range
from /Users/phil/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.0.0-p353@iq/gems/ice_cube-0.11.3/lib/ice_cube/occurrence.rb:96:in `initialize'
```

title: Schedule alternating weeks?
body: Hello, I have a schedule that is Monday, Wednesday, Friday one week and Tuesday, Thursday the next. I've tried several combinations but have not found anything that works. Is this something supported by IceCube?

title: How to create a schedule summary?
body: Right now, `ice_cube` supports building hash or ical format from a schedule. How can i generate a schedule summary? I see `build_s` in validations, but there is no documentation how to use it.

title: day_of_week cannot be serialized as JSON
body:
Hi,

I am using IceCube to store schedules inside a MongoDB. I tried to serialize the schedule in a Hash field using `Schedule#to_hash`. Which means the Hash will be stored as JSON in the DB. Problem is that the DayOfWeek Validation uses an Integer as Hash key to identify the weekdays. In JSON this Integer will be a string, which Schedule#from_hash cannot handle.

Example:

``` ruby
require 'json'
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_week(monday: [1])
hashed = schedule.to_hash
# => ... {:day_of_week=>{1=>[1]}} ...
dumped = JSON.dump hashed
# => ... {\"day_of_week\":{\"1\":[1]}} â€¦
loaded = JSON.load dumped
# => ... {"day_of_week"=>{"1"=>[1]}} â€¦
IceCube::Schedule.from_hash loaded
# ArgumentError: Expecting Fixnum or Symbol value for weekday. No such weekday: "1"
```

In the meantime I use serialization to YAML, which works fine. The Hash would have some advantages. E.g. to query attributes like the start_time inside the schedule.

Thanks.

title: Schedule#occurs_at? with positive UTC offset
body:
Hi,

I noticed an issue when querying `occurs_at?` on a schedule with positive utc_offset. It seems the given time matches each occurrence as if the occurrence had no utc_offset. Strangely negative offsets seem to work fine.

``` ruby
time = Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 12).getlocal(7200)   # => 2014-02-07 14:00:00 +0200
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(time) {|s| s.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily}
schedule.occurs_at? time                         # => true
schedule.occurs_at? Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 12)     # => false (but same time)
schedule.occurs_at? Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 14)     # => true (should be false)

time = Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 12).getlocal(-7200)  # => 2014-02-07 10:00:00 -0200
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(time) {|s| s.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily}
schedule.occurs_at? time                         # => true
schedule.occurs_at? Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 12)     # => false
schedule.occurs_at? Time.utc(2014, 2, 7, 10)     # => false
```

I tested this without ActiveSupport. I am unsure wether a call with the correct UTC should or could match a timezoned schedule.

Thanks.

title: Support crontab expressions
body: It would be awesome to be able to create a schedule with a crontab expression.

title: Make `enumerate_occurrences` public (or alter `occurrences_between`)
body:
I'm currently calling the `enumerate_occurrences` private method to get the enumerator between a date range so I can apply a limit (using .take). There's no public method that covers this at the moment.

What would be better?
- Add a limit option to the `occurrences_between` public method.
- Make `enumerate_occurrences` public (or add a public wrapper method).

If you agree, let me know which you prefer and I'll make a pull request (unless you want to make the change yourself).

Thanks for the excellent work.

title: 0.11.1 ~> 0.11.2 sidekiq uses 100% cpu and stops working
body:
After updating my sidekiq (+sidetiq) workers from ice_cube `0.11.1` to `0.11.2`, all workers started consuming 100% cpu and stopped crunching tasks.

Reverting the update directly fixed the issue.

I use sidetiq with `recurrence { hourly.minute_of_hour(0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50) }` and
`recurrence { daily }`

Anything else I could provide to help fixing this issue?

Thanks,
Johannes

title: Wrong timezone in Schedule#occurrences_between
body:
Hi,

Schedule#occurrences_between uses the timezone of the dates given as arguments instead of the timezone of the schedule in some cases. I added two failing specs in this pull request that show the problem.

The strange thing is that it seems to depend on the termination condition of the rule: a daily rule with #count works as expected while #until and unterminated daily rules return wrong timezones.

title: minutely(5) causes high CPU idle in sidetiq with multiple jobs
body:
[Discussion thread](https://meta.discourse.org/t/sidekiq-cpu-load-since-latest-release/9515/22?u=riking) (Posts 16-end)

https://github.com/tobiassvn/sidetiq/issues/31

[Workaround commit in discourse](https://github.com/discourse/discourse/commit/1aee217a61643e972403c2258051a9d200de2f1f)

Would definitely be nice if this was fixed.

title: Made closing_time argument optional in occurrences
body: End time is optional for `occurrences` method. For instance if for a terminating schedule I call `schedule.occurrences`, it throws `wrong number of arguments (0 for 1)` which is ambiguous. It works if I pass `nil`. Since anyway, there is no check to prevent infinite looping incase of non-terminating schedules, I propose that this argument should be made optional.

title: Want to include last day of months
body:
Please check the below case.

I want to set monthly schedules for based on what month of day I am receiving parameters.

```
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_month(-1) if params[:day] == 31
# => [Tue, 31 Dec 2013 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Fri, 31 Jan 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Fri, 28 Feb 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Mon, 31 Mar 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Wed, 30 Apr 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Sat, 31 May 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Mon, 30 Jun 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00,
 Thu, 31 Jul 2014 09:04:49 UTC +00:00]
```

But in case of params[:day] == 30 which is also a last day of month but it skips feb 28th

```
# params[:day] = 30
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_month(params[:day])
# => [Mon, 30 Dec 2013 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Thu, 30 Jan 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Sun, 30 Mar 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Wed, 30 Apr 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Fri, 30 May 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Mon, 30 Jun 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00,
 Wed, 30 Jul 2014 09:04:08 UTC +00:00]
```

And I actually want ice_cube to include 28th of feb. Is there any way or hack to do that?

title: Is there a way to have a fortnightly recurrence with occurrences in both weeks?
body:
This is a question more than an issue but I can't find anywhere in the documentation or the source code how to make this kind of schedule e.g.

Week 1 : Mon, Wed, Fri
Week 2:       Tue, Thu
Week 3 : Mon, Wed, Fri
Week 4:       Tue, Thu
Week 5 : Mon, Wed, Fri and so on..

The only thing I can think of is to make 2 separate schedules with start dates a week apart and an interval of 2. For my purpose though I can only have one schedule.

Thanks!

title: start_date_override fails when given a Date or DateTime
body:
When creating a schedule from a serialized version (YAML or hash), if the :start_date_override option is given a Date or DateTime, the schedule is created without overriding the start_time on the schedule. The functionality that causes this behavior is in TimeUtil.deserialize_time. I'm not sure if this is the way it's supposed to work, but it certainly causes some subtle and confusing bugs when deserializing schedules.

For instance, if I create a schedule with a weekly recurrence today (2013/11/30), then recreate with 

```
Schedule.from_yaml(yaml, start_date_override: Date.new(2014, 1, 1))
```

and then get the next recurrence, it will get the next weekly recurrence from 2013/11/30, not from 2014/1/1

```
schedule.next_occurrence(Date.new(2014, 1, 1))
=> Jan 4, 2014 (expected Jan 8, 2014)
```

This can be verified by inspecting

```
schedule.start_time
=> Nov 30, 2013
```

title: Use Enumerator to model occurrences in Schedule
body: I've been encountering some use-cases where I need to deal with infinite lists of recurring events in a manageable way.  Using an Enumerator to do this in a less-eager fashion seems like a good way to approach the problem.  I replaced find_occurrences() in Schedule with enumerate_occurrences() and rewrote all the calls to find_occurrences() accordingly.  Additionally, I added two methods that emit the underlying enumerator so one can use an enumerator to manage a (potentially infinite) list of occurrences.

I was wondering about "real life" happenings and how they can be handled with this library, or not. For example: can rescheduling an occurrence to the following day be handled gracefully with a combination of `#add_exception_time` and adding a single extra occurrence?

And a long shot... any frontend (javascript/html) libraries that play nice with this gem, using a similar chaining format for specifying recurrence? Do you imagine this gem taking parameters straight from a Rails controller and creating `Schedule` rules in this way? Any examples?

This works fine to reset the start_date.

But was wondering is there any way to update the end_time of a schedule ?

For example, in dummy application, user might need to change the start_date and end_time and regenerate the schedule with the existing rules but the start_date and end_time would change.

Any pointers/suggestions will be helpful to update the end_time in a schedule but not the rule itself.

Thanks.

title: TimeUtil.now should use Time.zone.now by default
body:
This method gets invoked by `IceCube::Schedule`'s initialize method to
set the `@start_time` instance variable, and when this happens it's not
taking the user's time zone into account.

Currently, if I have a schedule set to start at 10:00 BST (GMT +1), after 27th October (when DST stops) all occurrences start at 09:00 (GMT +0). While this is "correct", it's not the behaviour I desire.

Is it possible to ignore the change in DST? I.e. keep the start time at 10:00.

title: Monthly (by day of month) not working on short months
body:
On readme there is the following information
Monthly rules will use the nearest day at the end of the month if the month is too short (e.g. February 28 for day_of_month(31))

but trying this at console:

``` ruby
[2] pry(main)> schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.now)                                                                                                                                                          
=> August 30, 2013
[3] pry(main)> schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(31)                                                                                                                                 
=> [Monthly on the 31st day of the month]
[4] pry(main)> schedule.first(12)                                                                                                                                                                                  
=> [2013-08-31 20:26:13 -0300,
 2013-10-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2013-12-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2014-01-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2014-03-31 20:26:13 -0300,
 2014-05-31 20:26:13 -0300,
 2014-07-31 20:26:13 -0300,
 2014-08-31 20:26:13 -0300,
 2014-10-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2014-12-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2015-01-31 20:26:13 -0200,
 2015-03-31 20:26:13 -0300]
```

You could say to use **day_of_month(-1)** but when you are trying to recur on day 30 and use **day_of_month(-2)** other months will recur on day 29.

So, the behavior described on README is not what is actually happening.

Sorry if its a dup, I'm new to ice_cube, just reporting ;)

thank you ;)

title: Move ::Deprecated under the IceCube namespace
body: I find it a little odd that the ::Deprecated constant hangs out in the top-level namespace. I think we should move it under IceCube::Deprecated to be polite and tidy.

title: Transformations to supported formats
body:
(the title for this issue is stupid, couldn't think of a better one)

It seems that [Apple Calendar doesn't support RDATE](http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/68535/does-os-x-calendar-nee-ical-support-rdate), which makes publishing calendars for that client somewhat difficult. 

On mobile the [situation seems even worse](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13360431/searching-for-an-icalendar-recurrence-format-that-works-across-devices). 

So the proposal here is, can we make a method for IceCube Schedules that would transform the rules into a format that would be readable by all calendar applications?

If not, then can there be methods for transformation into at least particular platforms (although I understand that covering all platforms is probably beyond the scope of this project)?

---

Example:

``` ruby
s = Schedule.new 
s.add_recurrence_time Date::civil(2013, 4, 2)
s.add_recurrence_time Date::civil(2015, 5, 12)
puts s.to_ical(:apple)
```

would produce:

``` ical
DTSTART:20130425T183000Z
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;BYMONTH=4;BYMONTHDAY=2;UNTIL=20140403T225959Z
RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;INTERVAL=2;BYMONTH=5;BYMONTHDAY=12;UNTIL=20150513T225959Z
```

title: How to retrieve information about a Rule
body:
This is not an issue really, just a question (still getting familiar with this library).

If I have a rule:

``` ruby
rrule = IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(1, 2, 3, 4)
```

What is the "correct" way to retrieve that rule's data, in a way that I can then use/display that information?

The two ways I've found both feel like I'm using the internal API, but they do work:

``` ruby
rrule.to_hash[:validations][:day]      #=> [1, 2, 3, 4]
rrule.validations_for(:day).map(&:day) #=> [1, 2, 3, 4]
```

Are either of these the suggested means of retrieving this information? What I'm really looking for is something like:

``` ruby
rrule.days #=> [1, 2, 3, 4]
```

Thanks!

title: bug next occurrence with start_time = Date.today.beginning_of_year
body:
I've noticed a wrong behavior with just one date. If I set as start_time Date.today.beginning_of_year and I try to get the next yearly (but also monthly) occurrence of 01/29/2013 I don't have 01/01/2014 as result but 01/30/2013.

If I try with start_time = Date.today.beginning_of_year + 1.day it works.

Here below the test to replicate the issue 

``` ruby
it 'should calculate a current date even on 01/29/2013' do
    schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new()
    schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.yearly
    schedule.start_time = Date.today.beginning_of_year
    date = schedule.next_occurrence(Date.new(2013,1,28)) #correct
    date.year.should == 2014
    date.month.should == 1

    date = schedule.next_occurrence(Date.new(2013,1,30)) #correct
    date.year.should == 2014
    date.month.should == 1

    date = schedule.next_occurrence(Date.new(2013,1,29)) #bug: return 01/30/2013
    date.year.should == 2014
    date.month.should == 1

  end
```

title: #occurs_between? does not function as implied.
body:
