If not, I think it make sense to change the name of this method to #starts_between? because it overlooks the end_time in determining whether it occurs between the specified period.

title: Add integration with Occurrence to Arel
body:
Changing to use the IceCube::Occurrence class as a wrapper for times means having to map them back to times when using with ActiveRecord & Arel:

```
Model.where("time IN ?", schedule.occurrences)
# => TypeError (Cannot visit IceCube::Occurrence)

Model.where("time IN ?", schedule.occurrences.map(&:to_time))
# => [#<Model id: 1, time: ...>]
```

It would be nice to have Occurrences work transparently as Time objects. Need to investigate further... Can we override `#class` without making bad stuff happen?

Adding this workaround in a rails initializer makes it work for now:

```
class Arel::Visitors::ToSql
  def visit_IceCube_Occurrence(value)
    quoted(value.to_time)
  end
end
```

title: schedule.occurrences.include?(newly_created_occurence with identical time in occurrences array) returns false
body:
```
    Loading dev_mysql environment (Rails 3.2.9)
    1.9.3dev :001 > start = Time.now
     => 2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :002 > schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start, end_time: start + 24.hours)
     => April 27, 2013
    1.9.3dev :003 > schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.hourly.count(2))
     => [Hourly 2 times]
    1.9.3dev :004 > schedule.all_occurrences
     => [2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530, 2013-04-27 19:05:21 +0530]
    1.9.3dev :005 > first_occurrence = schedule.all_occurrences[0]
     => 2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :006 > second_occurrence = schedule.all_occurrences[1]
     => 2013-04-27 19:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :007 > new_first_occurrence = IceCube::Occurrence.new(first_occurrence.start_time)
     => 2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :008 > new_second_occurrence = IceCube::Occurrence.new(second_occurrence.start_time)
     => 2013-04-27 19:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :009 > schedule.all_occurrences.include? new_first_occurrence
     => true
    1.9.3dev :010 > schedule.all_occurrences.include? new_second_occurrence
     => true
    1.9.3dev :011 > nfo_using_parsed_time =  IceCube::Occurrence.new(Time.parse("2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530"))
     => 2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :012 > nso_using_parsed_time =  IceCube::Occurrence.new(Time.parse("2013-04-27 19:05:21 +0530"))
     => 2013-04-27 19:05:21 +0530
    1.9.3dev :013 > schedule.all_occurrences.include? nfo_using_parsed_time
     => false
    1.9.3dev :014 > schedule.all_occurrences.include? nso_using_parsed_time
     => false
    1.9.3dev :015 >
```

As can be seen above **schedule.all_occurrences.include? new_first_occurrence**
returns **true**, however, **schedule.all_occurrences.include? nfo_using_parsed_time** returns **false**, where 

```
new_first_occurrence = IceCube::Occurrence.new(first_occurrence.start_time)
```

and

```
 nfo_using_parsed_time =  IceCube::Occurrence.new(Time.parse("2013-04-27 18:05:21 +0530"))
```

wherein new IceCube::Occurrence instances are created using identical datetime there in the Schedule Occurrences array.

Is this expected behaviour? I mean is include? behaving as expected? I don't think so.It should not matter how I created the Time instance i.e. by parsing a string date or some other way.But having an occurrence instance with identical datetime in another Occurrence instance its comparison should return true.

```
1.9.3dev :016 > first_occurrence == new_first_occurrence 
 => true 
1.9.3dev :017 > first_occurrence.eql? new_first_occurrence 
 => true 
1.9.3dev :018 > first_occurrence == nfo_using_parsed_time 
 => false 
1.9.3dev :019 > first_occurrence.eql? nfo_using_parsed_time 
 => false 
1.9.3dev :020 > 
```

Thanks,
Jignesh

```
  1.9.3dev :007 > schedule.occurs_at? ctime1
   => false
  1.9.3dev :008 > schedule.occurs_at? ctime2
   => false
  1.9.3dev :009 > schedule.occurs_at? ctime3
   => false
  1.9.3dev :010 > schedule.occurs_on? ctime1
   => true
  1.9.3dev :011 > schedule.occurs_on? ctime2
   => true
  1.9.3dev :012 > schedule.occurs_on? ctime3
   => true
  1.9.3dev :013 > schedule.occurring_at? ctime1
   => false
  1.9.3dev :014 > schedule.occurring_at? ctime2
   => false
  1.9.3dev :015 > schedule.occurring_at? ctime3
   => false
  1.9.3dev :016 >
```

This behaviour has stuck me in moving ahead in my application wherein I want to perform some recurring scheduled tasks in the background using Sidetiq which uses ice_cube DSL for defining schedules.

I would like to know your inputs on this and whether this is a bug or I violated any rules in the creating and using the Schedule.

I found a similar problem referred at: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13788926/single-occurrence-event-with-ice-cube-gem-using-start-time-and-end-time

Thanks,
Jignesh

title: ICUI
body:
This is really not a bug, but I just wanted to let people know, that I wrote a client side library for exposing IceCube to the client.

You can find it here: https://github.com/gampleman/icui

It's written in clear CoffeeScript and is designed to be fairly easy to hack. From an UX point of view it is currently less polished then [Recurring Select](https://github.com/GetJobber/recurring_select), but exposes more of the power of IceCube rules (e.g. it can handle arbitrarily complex rules), it is also entirely client side, so will work with any serverside  setup.

title: Add example for using arrays as parameters
body:
I had a problem with the dynamic creation of recurrence rules for more that one day a week. 

If you build an array with all days in which an event should occur, you cannot use the array directly as parameter to some methods, eg. Rule.weekly(2).day([:monday, :friday]). Instead, you have to splat the array - Rule.weekly(2).day(*[:monday, :friday]).

In my opinion, it would be better if the methods would accept arrays too. But at least the readme should contain an example for that (probably frequent) case. So, I have added some lines to the README.md.

title: Consider not polluting namespace
body: Schedule and Rule caused conflicts in our code. Perhaps a single global namespace for the library would avoid this issue. Another possibility is to rely on a custom defined class (or model) and then make the methods local to it. Geocoder offers some good conventions https://github.com/alexreisner/geocoder for this.

title: Documentation Improvement
body: I would recommend being more explicit regarding what datatype/migration to use when persisting the serialized hash. how long can the string be?

title: "occurring_at?" may incorrectly return false if test time tz doesn't match schedule tz.
body:
If the timezone of the test time used when calling "occurring_at?" does not match the timezone of the times contained in the schedule, then a 'false' may be returned even if the time 'truly' does fall within the scheduled times. True should be returned if the test time falls in the schedule regardless of timezone.  
May be related to Issue #152.

Example:

``` irb
irb(main):001:0> require 'ice_cube'
irb(main):002:0> require 'active_support/time'
irb(main):003:0> require 'active_support/core_ext'
irb(main):004:0> schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.at('2013-04-15 11:00:00 -05:00'.to_time.to_i), :duration=> (60*60*8) )
=> April 15, 2013
irb(main):005:0> schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:monday, :tuesday).until(Time.at('2013-04-16 23:59:59 -05:00'.to_time.to_i))
=> [Weekly on Mondays and Tuesdays until April 16, 2013]
irb(main):006:0> schedule.all_occurrences.each { |o| puts o.to_s }
2013-04-15 11:00:00 -0500 - 2013-04-15 19:00:00 -0500
2013-04-16 11:00:00 -0500 - 2013-04-16 19:00:00 -0500
irb(main):009:0> t = Time.at(('2013-04-16 22:00:00 UTC').to_time.to_i)
=> 2013-04-16 17:00:00 -0500
irb(main):010:0> tutc = t.utc
=> 2013-04-16 22:00:00 UTC
irb(main):012:0> puts schedule.occurring_at?(t)
false
irb(main):013:0> tlocal = Time.at(t.to_i)
=> 2013-04-16 17:00:00 -0500
irb(main):015:0> puts schedule.occurring_at?(tlocal)
true
```

title: How could I store a recurrence rule in database?
body:
I might save a schedule in db
repeats = schedule.to_hash 
or repeats = schedule.to_yaml

then use it from db
schedule = repeats.from_hash 

But I need to know which rule. For example, if it is repeated weekly, how could I store a rule in db or how could I know rule from schedule? Is it some methods for serialize/deserialize rules?

title: Recalculate the interval value
body:
I have trouble with interval. If I try to setup interval after initialization, it still use first interval.
But the string of the rule is right.

``` ruby
rule = Rule.daily.until(Date.new(2013,5,1)) # => Daily until May  1, 2013
rule.interval(3)                            # => Every 3 days until May  1, 2013 
schedule = Schedule.new(Date.new(2013,4,1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule rule # => [Every 3 days until May  1, 2013]

schedule.all_occurrences # => [2013-04-01, 2013-04-02, 2013-04-03, 2013-04-04, 2013-04-05, 2013-04-06, 2013-04-07, 2013-04-08, 2013-04-09, 2013-04-10, 2013-04-11, 2013-04-12, 2013-04-13, 2013-04-14, 2013-04-15, 2013-04-16, 2013-04-17, 2013-04-18, 2013-04-19, 2013-04-20, 2013-04-21, 2013-04-22, 2013-04-23, 2013-04-24, 2013-04-25, 2013-04-26, 2013-04-27, 2013-04-28, 2013-04-29, 2013-04-30, 2013-05-01]
```

Added patch for `DailyInterval`, because I do not understand the logic to use several intervals for one Rule.

Solution without this patch is to use next:

``` ruby
rule = Rule.daily.until(Date.new(2013,5,1)) # => Daily until May  1, 2013
rule.replace_validations_for(:interval, [])
rule.interval(3)                            # => Every 3 days until May  1, 2013 
```

title: fix double WEEKLY string in to_ical result
body:
Hello :)

I was trying to generate iCal format from schedule which I earlier loaded from yaml. I stumbled across `FREQ=WEEKLY,WEEKLY` results from to_ical. They are incompatible with google calendar to which I tried to import my calendar, and probably with RFC (I didn't check that).
After a bit of digging I found that WeeklyRule has doubled `interval` values which happens while loading yaml. I wrote a test and fixed it, let me know if it needs refactoring :)

title: next occurence for 1 count?
schedule relative to end_date versus start_date?
body:
Apologies if this is not the right forum for this type of discussion

I was thinking of cases where I'd want to be able to specify an end time and have a schedule trigger based on that; such as schedule end_time is 9AM today, and I want a rule to trigger an hour before that for 2 occurrences. 

I've been poking around the codebase; but I still haven't figured out how I would implement this behavior. SO I thought i'd ask; how difficult would this be? I have no concept of how complicated this would be to implement, i gather I would have to adjust how next_ occurrence is determined and have some logic for when to use start_date and when to use end_date. Is this more or less a feature implementation, or would I be trying to unhinge a fundamental design of ice_cube?

title: Find occurrences whose duration intersects a time window
body:
We have `occurrences_between`, but this only covers start times in the range, not all occurrences whose duration intersects the window (those that already started before, and are presently counted by `occurring_between?`).

I vote for adding `open_occurrences_between(t0, t1)` to cover the question from #153.

Or is there a better name for this?

```
occurrences_with_duration_between
occurrences_occurring_between
occurrences_intersecting_between
?
```

title: Discrepancy in behavior of methods occurring_between? and occurrences_between
body:
Events which span over multiple days should be returned by `occurrences_between`.
`occurring_between?` behaves as I'd expect.

``` ruby
require 'ice_cube'
require 'time'

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.parse('2013-03-04 16:00:00 +00:00'), end_time: Time.parse('2013-03-07 14:00:00 +00:00'))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly

lower_bound = Time.parse('2013-03-05 00:00:00 +00:00')
upper_bound = Time.parse('2013-03-06 00:00:00 +00:00')

schedule.occurring_between?(lower_bound, upper_bound)
# true

schedule.occurrences_between(lower_bound, upper_bound)
# []
```

ice_cube 0.10.0 / Ruby 1.9.3

title: Time zone issue when dealing with occurrences
body:
I stumbled upon a time zone issue when dealing with Rails TimeWithZone and the occurrence finding methods (e.g. `next_occurrence` and `occurrences_between`).

Example: I create a schedule with `starting_time` in UTC and I'm calling the `next_occurrence` method with the `opening_time` argument set to a time in another time zone (e.g. GMT+1). The returned occurrence is not as the doc describes in the `starting_time` time zone (UTC), but in the time zone I supplied via the argument (GMT+1). More severe is that the time is wrong.

The example below reproduces the problem (ice_cube 0.10.0, Ruby 1.9.3 + Rails 3.2.12)

``` ruby
require 'ice_cube'
require 'active_support/time'
require 'active_support/core_ext'

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new('2013-03-01 00:00:00 +00:00'.to_time)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily
# schedule.start_time is 2013-03-01 00:00:00 UTC

reference_time = Time.new(2013,3,4).in_time_zone('Bern')
# reference_time is Fri, 01 Mar 2013 00:00:00 CET +01:00

p schedule.next_occurrence(reference_time)
# Tue, 05 Mar 2013 00:00:00 CET +01:00 (wrong time zone, wrong time)

p schedule.next_occurrence(reference_time).utc
#2013-03-04 23:00:00 UTC (wrong time)

p schedule.next_occurrence(reference_time.utc)
#2013-03-04 00:00:00 UTC (correct)
```

My first impression is that the `find_occurrences` function should make sure that the zones of `opening_time` and `closing_time` match the zone of `starting_time`.

title: Drop Ruby 1.8.7 support
body:
Where do we stand with supporting 1.8.7 going forward?

CI has been turned off for that version for a while now. There are some failures on my end around cases with time zones and segfaults around yaml, although those could just be my environment.

It does still seem to "mostly" work as I've done my best to keep everything compatible, but it probably makes sense to commit to a cutoff for ice_cube 1.0.

On the positive side, everything's all green in ruby-2.0.0.

title: Occurrences in DST change hour get skipped
body:
I found that a 2AM rule would get skipped as it traverses the DST boundary:

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.local(2013, 3, 9, 2, 0, 0))
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily
schedule.first(2)
# => [2013-03-09 02:00:00 -0800, 2013-03-11 02:00:00 -0700]
```

The occurrence on March 10th gets skipped. Instead of skipping a day because there's no 2AM there, It should validate the nearest hour (3AM). This applies to all recurrence rules.

When `hour_of_day(2)` is specified as an override to the schedule start time it seems that it should also consider DST changes and use the nearest hour, based on [section 3.3.5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.3.5) and referenced in 3.3.10 for BYHOUR on [page 45](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#page-45).

title: count and next_occurence?
body: Maybe I don't understand the theory of operation well enough, but, I created 2 rules: every 4 seconds for 4 occurences, and every 2 days for 2 occurences. but next_occurence returns nil regardless. Is this not how it's supposed to work? to limit the number of times an otherwise endless loop would run?

title: Handling Holidays
body:
I am wondering if someone can give me a few pointers as I am banging my head trying to model this correctly for a few days. I am working on a small school app.  

Scenario: School is closed on standard holidays and also for vacation (christmas, summer etc.)  

I am storing the class schedule in a schedules model (RoR app).  For Holidays, I am storing the holidays in the Holidays model. Holiday can be a single day or multi-day. I use a HolidayCalendar model to store the actual Holiday ice_cube schedule.  The Holidays model is used to store the exception dates such that they be interacted by the user.  Everytime a holiday is created or update, I use after\* filters to update the HolidayCalendar schedule.  Since ice_cube does not store ranges to be in confirmity with ical, I basically convert the range to extimes and store it as such. 

Problem: When a user updates a individual holiday, I remove the old date extime and add the new date extime.  This mostly works except in cases like - say a user added Dec 25 as an individual holiday. Say they added another range from Dec 23 - Jan 1 as Christmas Break. Since I am storing all dates as extimes, when a user deletes the Dec 25 individual holiday, it gets deleted from extimes. However, it should still be an extime as it is a part of the Dec 23 - Jan 1 rule.  I know this is all by ice_cube design by I am wondering if someone can point me as to a better way to handle this. I am sure handling holidays with ice_cube is a common enough usecase that others may have handled it.

``` ruby
  def add_holiday_to_calendar
    start_date = DateTime.strptime(self.start_date.to_s,"%Y-%m-%d")
    end_date = DateTime.strptime(self.end_date.to_s,"%Y-%m-%d") unless self.end_date.blank?
    icecube_schedule = self.holiday_calendar.icecube_schedule
    if self.is_multi_day? || self.is_multi_day == "1" # multi-day
      extimes = icecube_schedule.occurrences_between(start_date, end_date)
      extimes.each { |t| icecube_schedule.add_exception_time(t) }    
    else # single day
      icecube_schedule.add_exception_time(start_date)
    end 
    self.holiday_calendar.update_column(:schedule_yaml, icecube_schedule.to_yaml)
  end
```

``` ruby
  def update_holiday_in_calendar
    current_icecube_schedule = self.holiday_calendar.icecube_schedule
    new_icecube_schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(current_icecube_schedule.start_time)
    new_icecube_schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.daily)
    if self.start_date_changed? || self.end_date_changed?
      if self.is_multi_day_was # was multi-day
        extimes = new_icecube_schedule.occurrences_between(DateTime.strptime(self.start_date_was.to_s,"%Y-%m-%d"), DateTime.strptime(self.end_date_was.to_s,"%Y-%m-%d"))
        extimes.each { |t| current_icecube_schedule.remove_exception_time(t) }   
      else
 current_icecube_schedule.remove_exception_time(DateTime.strptime(self.start_date_was.to_s,"%Y-%m-%d"))
      end
      self.holiday_calendar.update_column(:schedule_yaml, current_icecube_schedule.to_yaml)
      yield
      add_holiday_to_calendar
    end
  end
```

Problem 2: My thought when I can get the HolidayCalendar schedule working properly is to use the exrules from the HolidayCalendar to append to the individual class schedules before generating the occurrences for individual class events. However, this seems like an overkill to do for every class schedule change. But this seems necessary to what I am trying to accomplish. Is there a better way for handling this?

Thank you. I know this is not an issue but a discussion but I couldn't find a better forum to post this.

title: `occurs_between?` misses start time when duration is zero
body:
The comment says "inclusive" but it actually excludes the start time when duration is zero:

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.utc(2013, 1, 1))
t1, t2 = Time.utc(2013, 2, 10), Time.utc(2013, 2, 11)
schedule.add_recurrence_time t1

schedule.occurring_between?(t1, t2) # => false
schedule.duration = 1
schedule.occurring_between?(t1, t2) # => true
```

title: Yield schedule for configuring it
body:
Using a block for configuring seems like it would be an obvious interface improvement:

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new do |s|
  s.start_time = Time.utc(2013, 2, 10)
  s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly
end
```

title: Allow for passing symbol arg to `day_of_week`
body:
The `day_of_week` validation requires an Array argument even when passing a single weekday. This seems like it should just work:

```
Rule.weekly.day_of_week(:sunday)
```

We should splat args to allow for either array or single value(s).

title: Warn on use of DateTime and convert to Time
body: Follow-up to #114, we should remove internal support for DateTime and convert all incoming DateTimes to Time with a warning.

title: 'duration' no longer works as expected when 'end_time' specified
body:
I use schedules to support scheduling meetings that have a duration, recur more than once, but the schedule ends at a different time than the meeting. The use case is (among other uses) something like "Every day for one hour for ten days." I need to be able to check if a meeting is currently in progress. In version 0.6.12, I was able to use duration to indicate the length of a meeting (one hour) and end_time to indicate the end of the recurrences (10 days). In the current version it seems end_time marks the end of the meeting and duration is implicitly end_time minus start_time. The end_time parameter seems to have changed from meaning the end of the recurring schedule to meaning the end of the meetings duration. I ran tests using 0.6.12 and version 0.9.3. Both tests use ruby 1.9.3p327 and rails  3.2.11. 
To maintain backward compatibility occurrence duration needs to be independent of schedule end_time. 
This seems to be in conflict with issue #128.
Please see the differences (marked with test "<--- DIFFERENT" between the irb test runs below using 0.6.12 and 0.9.3.

``` irb

VERSION 0.6.12

-> gem install --version '0.6.12' ice_cube
Fetching: ice_cube-0.6.12.gem (100%)
Successfully installed ice_cube-0.6.12
1 gem installed
-> irb
irb(main):001:0> require 'active_support'
=> true
irb(main):003:0> require 'active_support/time_with_zone'
=> true
irb(main):004:0> require 'ice_cube'
=> true

### Creating a meeting that starts now and runs for an hour
irb(main):005:0> schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new Time.now, :duration => 3600, :end_time => Time.now+(10*24*60*60 )
=> until February 18, 2013
### The one hour meeting repeats every day.
irb(main):006:0> schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily
=> [#<IceCube::RuleOccurrence:0x9d436c8 @rule=Daily, @start_date=2013-02-08 16:47:24 -0600, @end_time=2013-02-18 16:47:24 -0600, @date=nil, @index=0>]
irb(main):007:0> t = Time.now
=> 2013-02-08 16:48:23 -0600
irb(main):009:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t)
=> true
irb(main):011:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t+3600)
=> false <--- DIFFERENT, correctly reflects meeting duration and time falls between start_time and end_time
irb(main):012:0> oneday = 24*60*60
=> 86400
irb(main):013:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t+oneday)
=> true
irb(main):014:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t+oneday+3600)
=> false <--- DIFFERENT, correctly reflects meeting duration
irb(main):015:0> quit


VERSION 0.9.3

-> gem install ice_cube
Fetching: ice_cube-0.9.3.gem (100%)
Successfully installed ice_cube-0.9.3
1 gem installed
-> irb
irb(main):001:0> require 'active_support/time_with_zone'
=> true
irb(main):002:0> require 'active_support'
=> true
irb(main):004:0>  require 'ice_cube'
=> true

### Creating a meeting that starts now and runs for an hour
irb(main):005:0> schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new Time.now, :duration => 3600, :end_time => Time.now+(10*24*60*60 )
=>
### The one hour meeting repeats every day.
irb(main):006:0> schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily
=> [Daily]
irb(main):007:0> t = Time.now
=> 2013-02-08 16:52:20 -0600
irb(main):008:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t)
=> true
irb(main):009:0> schedule.occurring_at?(t+3600)
=> true <--- DIFFERENT, fails to reflect duration value, 
irb(main):010:0> oneday = 24*60*60
=> 86400
irb(main):011:0>  schedule.occurring_at?(t+oneday)
=> true
irb(main):012:0>  schedule.occurring_at?(t+oneday+3600)
=> true <--- DIFFERENT, fails to reflect duration value
irb(main):013:0> quit
```

title: Check if one continuous occuring exists, for a given timerange?
body:
Is it possible to check, if a given timerange is inbetween an occuring?

For example Bob's opening hours are from 8am to 11am and 1pm to 5pm.

Alice wants to check if she could get an appointment starting at 7am till 6pm.

occurring_between?(7am, 6pm) and occurs_between?(7am, 6pm) would return true.
But these aren't valid opening hours.

![ice_cube2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2071241/135766/ae5f56dc-7132-11e2-88eb-a90bbb45ea27.png)

title: Tests fail in Australia and Japan
body:
Tests all pass with TZ set to any of:
- UTC
- America/New_York
- Europe/Amsterdam

The 15 tests for ActiveSupport times and 1 other fail with TZ set to any of:
- Australia/Adelaide
- Australia/Sydney
- Australia/Hobart
- Japan

I'll do some more testing shortly.

``` text
rspec ./spec/examples/schedule_spec.rb:496 # IceCube::Schedule occurs_on? with a single recurrence time starting from an ActiveSupport::Time should determine if it occurs on the day of a given ActiveSupport::Time
```

title: Improve ActiveSupport interplay - avoid "uninitialized constant ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone"
body:
If ActiveSupport is present in an app but ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone is not loaded then calling .to_hash on an ice_cube schedule gets you into trouble. A workaround is to require 'active_support/time_with_zone' but a better approach would be to improve detection in ice_cube's code, perhaps? 

I'll attempt a pull request to address this.

Here's an example error when running cucumber tests in a branch of the flapjack project - https://github.com/jessereynolds/flapjack/tree/55_notification_rules

``` text
  uninitialized constant ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone (NameError)
  ./features/steps/events_steps.rb:274:in `block (3 levels) in <top (required)>'
  ./features/steps/events_steps.rb:269:in `each'
  ./features/steps/events_steps.rb:269:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
  ./features/steps/events_steps.rb:262:in `each'
  ./features/steps/events_steps.rb:262:in `/^user (\d+) has the following notification rules:$/'
  features/notification_rules.feature:19:in `And user 1 has the following notification rules:'
```

title: Validations 'day' method failing to raise an exception
body:
Apologies if this has already been addressed, but I just noticed that passing in string values and arrays into the `Validations::Day day` method does not raise an exception and quietly proceeds with a corrupted state. I was attempting to extract an array of checkbox values for days of the week, forgetting they would be stringified ints. Nevertheless, it passed and I didn't notice until trying to inspect the `first(10)`, whereupon I received a `NoMethodError: undefined method '<' for [1, 3, 6]:Array`.

I see now that I was mistakenly passing in the Array object instead of the variable-length argument list, but IceCube didn't seem to care until it came time to use the derelict object. I then probed some more to find that it's perfectly content with string values as well, giving an `ArgumentError: comparison of String with 0 failed`.

I'm brand new to IceCube and so far it looks like a complete life saver for my current project, so I just wanted to do my part and call out this bad smell. Fail early, fail fast!

Thanks to everyone contributing!

Here is the code that was effectively run, by the way:

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(@event.starts_at)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(params[:days].values)
```

And with string:

``` ruby
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day("smelly")
```

title: Better way to handle timezones?
body:
I wanted to see if there's a better way to handle time zone offsets than what I'm doing.

I have form elements (@weekdays, @hour, @minute, @second, @ampm) to allow a user to schedule events on a weekly basis (start time + day of week).  User model has time_zone.

I have an event model method to build a Rule.weekly from these form elements & instantiate @schedule.  These form elements & @schedule.to_hash are all stored in the event model:

```
    self.schedule_hash = {
      :weekdays => @weekdays,
      :hour => @hour,
      :minute => @minute,
      :ampm => @ampm,
      :schedule => @schedule.to_hash
    }
```

(I store them all this way so I can easily generate an edit form with the event's current schedule populated.)

My problem is the rule is nominally built in the user's timezone, but I need to generate a @schedule.next_occurrence in UTC (to store in an indexed column for future processing).  

Right now I do this:

```
nextTime = self.schedule.next_occurrence(startTime)
return nil unless nextTime 
# next_occurrence doesn't have a TZ associated with it. Need to change the offset to match the user/default TZ 
Time.use_zone(@time_zone) do
  nextTime.to_datetime.change(:offset => (Time.zone.utc_offset/(60*60)).to_s).to_time
end
```

Seems pretty messy!

Is there a better way?  
My first thought is a feature request to allow a timezone to be supported in Rule.weekly -- does that exist / is that possible?

title: Runaway process from invalid input?
body:
I'm still fairly new to Ruby/Rails, so forgive me if I'm missing something obvious here!

If you submit bad input to ice_cube (see below), it seems like it gets trapped in an infinite loop.  Obviously the best solution is to not pass in invalid data :) but could/should there be input validations to at least prevent the process from running away?

irb(main):003:0> rule = IceCube::Rule.weekly
=> Weekly
irb(main):004:0> rule.hour_of_day(24)  
=> Weekly on the 24th hour of the day

title: occurrences for one time event schedules and using add_recurrence_time
body:
The initial start_time should be an occurrence, at least assuming that occurrences should mirror the to_ical display of occurrences. This is important for 1 time events (which have no occurrences) and when using add_recurrence_rule (which drop the initial occurrence),

```
irb(main):014:0> s = IceCube::Schedule.new
=> 
irb(main):015:0> s.start_time = Time.local(2013, 1, 1, 16)
=> 2013-01-01 16:00:00 -0800

=> "DTSTART;TZID=PST:20130101T160000\nDTEND;TZID=PST:20130101T200000"
irb(main):018:0> s.all_occurrences
=> []
```

title: method schedule.terminating return always true
body:
here a sample : gem version 0.9.3, ruby 193

```
require 'ice_cube'
now = Time.now
p "current time #{now}"

# without rule
start_time = now
end_time =  start_time + IceCube::ONE_DAY
schedule_not_terminating = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, :end_time => end_time)
p "without rule schedule_not_terminating => start time #{schedule_not_terminating.start_time}, end time #{schedule_not_terminating.end_time} terminating ? #{schedule_not_terminating.terminating?}"

start_time = now - 2 * IceCube::ONE_DAY
end_time =  start_time + IceCube::ONE_DAY
schedule_terminating = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time , :end_time => end_time)
p "without rule schedule_terminating =>  start time #{schedule_terminating.start_time}, end time #{schedule_terminating.end_time} terminating ? #{schedule_terminating.terminating?}"

# with rule
start_time = now
end_time =  start_time + IceCube::ONE_DAY
schedule_not_terminating = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, :end_time => end_time)
schedule_not_terminating.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.until(end_time)
p "with rule schedule_not_terminating => start time #{schedule_not_terminating.start_time}, end time #{schedule_not_terminating.end_time} terminating ? #{schedule_not_terminating.terminating?}"

start_time = now - 2 * IceCube::ONE_DAY
end_time =  start_time + IceCube::ONE_DAY
schedule_terminating = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time , :end_time => end_time)
schedule_terminating.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.until(end_time)
p "with rule schedule_terminating =>  start time #{schedule_terminating.start_time}, end time #{schedule_terminating.end_time} terminating ? #{schedule_terminating.terminating?}"
```

result : 

```
"current time 2013-01-10 09:26:38 +0100"
"without rule schedule_not_terminating => start time 2013-01-10 09:26:38 +0100, end time 2013-01-11 09:26:38 +0100 terminating ? true"
"without rule schedule_terminating =>  start time 2013-01-08 09:26:38 +0100, end time 2013-01-09 09:26:38 +0100 terminating ? true"
"with rule schedule_not_terminating => start time 2013-01-10 09:26:38 +0100, end time 2013-01-11 09:26:38 +0100 terminating ? true"
"with rule schedule_terminating =>  start time 2013-01-08 09:26:38 +0100, end time 2013-01-09 09:26:38 +0100 terminating ? true"
```

title: Add start_time information to Schedule.to_s() method
body:
Hi,

This is a small patch to add start date information to the `IceCube::Schedule.to_s()` method. Essentially, it adds information on the timeframe when a recurring schedule is relevant. For example, rather than stating that a schedule is "Weekly," `to_s()` would output "Weekly, starting on December 12th 2012."

Please let me know if you have any comments on this (especially on the style, etc.) or if this isn't the type of change that you're looking for. Also, thanks for maintaining this library, it's really helpful!

Best,
Kevin

title: Rule Groups
body:
As a follow up to #79, I'm using this pattern successfully in my [schedule_attributes](https://github.com/avit/schedule_attributes):

``` ruby
schedule.rrules = [
  Rule.daily.month_of_year(11, 12, 1, 2, 3)
]
schedule.exrules = [
  Rule.daily.month_of_year(11).day_of_month(*1..14),
  Rule.daily.month_of_year(3).day_of_month(*16..31),
]
# effectively: Daily from November 15 to March 15 every year
```

The only problem is that because this pattern is represented by 3 rules, I need to treat them as one logical "rule group" to extract the "yearly start day" and "yearly end day" for the UI, and this makes it hard to have any other rules within the same schedule without getting them mixed together when going back/forth from the UI.

I envision having something like "groups" for rules, or maybe just give each rule a "tag" so I can identify rules that belong together. Any thoughts on this idea?

title: Match start_time subsecs when finding occurrences
body: Fixes #89

title: Add an Occurrence class for end_times on individual occurrences
body: This is a point of discussion for #119. Let me know your thoughts on this approach.

title: Make duration dependent on end_time
body:
- schedule.end_time attribute controls duration.
- preference is given to :end_time over :duration for initializing.
- to_ical outputs only DTEND instead of DURATION.
- to_hash outputs only :end_time.

Fixes issues #116 and #120

title: Conflicting Recurrence Rules and Exception Rules run indefinitely
body:
If I have conflicting rules and call next_occurrences, it will loop indefinitely, regardless of end_time.

For instance:

``` ruby
schedule = Schedule.new("2012-12-1".to_time, :end_time => "2012-12-10".to_time)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily
schedule.add_exception_rule Rule.daily
schedule.next_occurrences(20)
```

This will just loop on forever. In the next_time function, it will always find a new value:

``` ruby
if res = rule.next_time(time, self, closing_time)
  if min_time.nil? || res < min_time
    min_time = res
  end
end
```

And then break out of the loop because it finds an occurrence:

``` ruby
if exception_time?(min_time)
  time = min_time + 1
  min_time = nil
  next
end
```

It should consider the end date for when it hits a scenario like this, and perhaps have a max loop iteration limit when it finds no match, or at least an arbitrarily far off end date if one isn't supplied.

title: Rendering rules
body:
I'm having a hard time rendering rules once I generate them and save them to database.

I've got a form to recreate a recurring event. Specifically for the weekly and monthly types, I'm finding it difficult to render out which weekdays and week numbers are repeated.

For the weekdays that are repeated, I run this ugly looking line:

Schedule.from_yaml(self.schedule).all_occurrences.collect{|a| Date::DAYNAMES[a.wday]}.uniq

This renders and array of weekdays that are part of the specific rule. I.E. ["Monday", "Wednesday", "Friday"]. Is there a better way to do this? 

Also, how would I grab the numbered weeks out of a rule? For example, I have a rule "Monthly until December 31, 2012 on the 2nd Monday when it is the 3rd Monday / Monthly until December 31, 2012 on the 2nd Wednesday when it is the 3rd Wednesday". This rule is for the 2nd and 3rd Monday and Wednesdays of a month. How would I render out that it is the 2nd and 3rd iterations of the day? I need to populate the edit form.

Sorry if this is confusing. If so, I can try to explain better. Thanks for the help. Love the gem...just having a rough time rendering out specific parts of a rule.

Matt

@bitboxer, please review for your purposes too?

```
1.9.3p125 :036 > i = IceCube::Schedule.new

1.9.3p125 :037 > i.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(1, 7)
 => [Weekly on Mondays and s] 
1.9.3p125 :038 > i.to_s
 => "Weekly on Mondays and s" 
```

Seems like there is a small bug with the word Sunday

title: Monthly Schedule misses items which match the rule
body:
Scenario:

``` ruby
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.utc(2011, 10, 25, 21, 0, 0))

schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly(3).day_of_week(:monday => [1])

schedule.all_occurrences

=> [
  [0] 2012-01-02 21:00:00 UTC,
  [1] 2012-04-02 21:00:00 UTC,
  [2] 2012-07-02 21:00:00 UTC,
  [3] 2012-10-01 21:00:00 UTC,
  ...
]
```

I would have expected the first occurrence to be:

``` ruby
2011-11-07 21:00:00 UTC
```

due to the fact that 11/7/2011 is the closest "first Monday of the month" to 10/25/2011.  It seems that IceCube is saying "I don't see a 'first Monday' in October so I'm going to go forward 3 months and then get the first Monday there."  I believe this to be erroneous.

Thoughts anyone?

title: EXDATE should be a comma separated list
body: `schedule.to_ical` does not output correctly when there are multiple exception times. Rather than separate `EXDATE:` listings, there should be one followed by a comma separated list of times.

title: Add ability to set recurrence exceptions as Dates
body:
Right now, you must set the exact occurrence time in the exceptions or else the exceptions will be ignored. Schedule should support setting Dates as exceptions, and all occurrences that occur on those dates should be excepted.

This is particularly useful when you want to change the start_time of a Schedule. Currently, all exceptions will become invalid. If recurrence exceptions can be dates, then you are free to change the start_time of a Schedule and still retain the exceptions on a day-granularity.

title: Should not allow setting both duration and end_time
body: Schedule should not allow setting both duration and end_time.

title: Add way to get end_time for occurrences
body:
Right now, when you specify a duration, there's no simple way to get the end_time for all occurrences. You have to calculate it yourself, and that's error-prone for all-day events (especially across daylight saving changes). Even more error prone is when the user provides end_time instead of duration, and the user wants to calculate the end times for other occurrences.

I propose Schedule#end_time_for_occurrence(occurrence) that will automatically return the end_time for a given occurrence, taking into account duration or end_time.

title: Rule#until should support dates
body:
Right now, Rule#until() only supports arguments with the granularity of Time. It will accept a Date object without error, but it will naively convert it to the 00:00:00 local time of that date, which wrong.

Right now, I'm working around this by explicitly converting Date objects to Time objects that give the desired result:

``` ruby
(date + 1).to_time - 1
```

Ideally, ice_cube would properly handle Date objects for until.

title: Add last_occurrence
body:
We want to store schedules in the database, and require a way to quickly query whether a schedule (and all its occurrences) overlaps a certain time span. In order to do this, we want to store the beginning/end boundaries of the schedule.

Getting the beginning boundary is easy, since it's just the `schedule.start_time`, but there is no way to get the last occurrence (our non-performant workaround is to do `schedule.all_occurrences.last`). It would be great to have a `schedule.last_occurrence`.

title: conflicts_with? should take end_time into consideration
body: Right now, conflicts_with? supports duration, but not end_time. It should also support detecting collisions when end_time.

title: IceCube has TimeZone issues
body:
Somehow the TimeZone information is lost during scheduling of events:

First I created a new Time in the GMT Timezone

```
time = Time.new(2012, 10, 10, 20, 15, 0, 0)
p time
#2012-10-10 20:15:00 +0000
p time.getlocal
#2012-10-10 22:15:00 +0200
```

Currently I am not im GMT but in CET and now I create the IceCube Schedule

```
s = IceCub::Schedule.new(time)
s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily
p s.next_occurrence
#2012-11-11 20:15:00 +0100
```

Now the next occurrence is not created with the correct time zone information. It should be 20:15:00 +0000.

title: Rules with interval 1 are not found with the occurrences_between after the first month
body:
For example

```
new_schedule = Schedule.new(DateTime.now)
new_rule = Rule.daily.day(:friday)
new_schedule.add_recurrence_rule new_rule
```

Hash looks like this:

```
:start_date:
  :time: 2012-11-05 15:30:00.000000000 Z
  :zone: UTC
:rrules:
- :validations:
    :day:
    - 5
  :rule_type: IceCube::DailyRule
  :interval: 1
:exrules: []
:rtimes: []
:extimes: []
```

now we try to grab all instances of this schedule for the month it was created in:

```
occurrences = schedule.occurrences_between(DateTime.now.beginning_of_month,
DateTime.now.end_of_month)
```

This works, occurrences is populated with all occurrences.

However if we go one month ahead:

```
start = DateTime.now.change(month: month, year: year).beginning_of_month
finish = DateTime.now.change(month: month, year: year).end_of_month

occurrences = schedule.occurrences_between(start, finish)
```

occurrences is now empty. This is true for both weekly and daily rules.

The strange things is if the interval is 2 for either daily or weekly rules the `occurrences_between` function returns all the correct instances regardless of what month in the future you set.

Am I just misunderstanding the way this is supposed to work? Sorry for the lack of specs to prove this, I'm a little crunched for time.

title: Validations based on Orthodox Pascha
body:
I don't really expect this to be accepted, since I assume it doesn't have really mainstream appeal, but for an app I'm doing I needed to calculate dates of Orthodox holidays, out which a significant proportion are defined in terms of an offset from the day of Pascha (Orthodox Easter; the date of which changes every year and has a rather crazy definition including first full moons after equinoxes and such stuff).

So this pull adds a validation `offset_from_pascha` which accepts a numerical offset from the day of Pascha that year.

It could be pretty easily extended for other religions simply by having a parameter that changes the algorithm used for calculating the base day.

title: Address comment warning to avoid future breaks
body: I noticed your warning comment in the method while refactoring. I _think_ this should solve it.

title: Minor Cleanup
body:
Hey,

This is mostly whitespace cleanup (tabs -> spaces, trailing whitespace, etc).
Also included a quick syntax upgrade for rspec, as any failing tests where taking up quite a few lines explaining that the syntax should be changed.

title: Refactoring the ValidatedRule#next_time method
body: Just a little cleanup on one of the more confusing methods.

title: Infinite Loop on occurrences_between
body:
Hey there,

I just came through an infinite loop problem.

The following spec reproduces it:

``` ruby
  it 'should not infinite loop' do
     schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new Time.new(2012,04,27, 0, 0, 0)
     schedule.end_time = Time.new(2013, 4, 27, 0, 0, 0)
     schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:monday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday, :saturday, :sunday).hour_of_day(0).minute_
     schedule.duration = 3600 
     start_time = Time.at(1350702000) # 2012-10-20 00:00:00 -0300 
     end_time = Time.at(1350788399)   # 2012-10-20 23:59:59 -0300
     schedule.occurrences_between(start_time, end_time).first.should == start_time
   end
```

title: Build schedule/rules from user-submitted params
body:
I'm adding a new feature to an existing project that will allow users to set a schedule for a recurring event. ice_cube looks like it will be perfect for implementing the logic for this feature.

I'm wondering if anyone has built something that takes params submitted by a user (via, let's say, a HTML form) and converts it to a Schedule. If not, is this something that anyone would find useful? I'm not sure if it would belong in this gem or a separate one, but the idea would be to develop a standard structure/naming for a params hash that the gem would convert into a schedule. For example, `{schedule_attributes: {weekly: {day: [:wednesday]}}}`  could be sent to a`schedule_attributes=` method that would take the hash and build a schedule with the rule`Rule.weekly.day(:wednesday)`.

Does this sound interesting to anyone? Is this even a good idea for this library? I don't have much experience w/ ice_cube yet so it could be that there are too many options for building a schedule and that this is really best implemented on a project-by-project basis. Looking forward to hearing what you guys think.

title: Monthly recurrence not giving the right date
body:
[1] pry(#<StepRecurrence>)> schedule
=> Monthly
[2] pry(#<StepRecurrence>)> schedule.next_occurrence
=> Wed, 31 Oct 2012 17:35:29 UTC +00:00
[3] pry(#<StepRecurrence>)> schedule.next_occurrences(2)
=> [Wed, 31 Oct 2012 17:35:29 UTC +00:00, Mon, 31 Dec 2012 17:35:29 UTC +00:00]

The schedule is set to a monthly rule, but the next occurrence is in two months.

When changing the until time for a rule to "nil" and then calling for example "occurrences_between" I get a nil comparison exception.

Please see the specs for more information.

I'm stilling hitting this infinite loop, as per issue #98 or #53 (not sure if it's the same problem). Included is a failing spec to help.

Forrest

title: Automatically convert date and datetime to time or raise an exception
body:
So right now to get the occurrences or any other such I have to for instance first convert a date to time. I would like ice_cube to either raise an exception or automatically convert the date to a time.

I can add this functionality myself but I want to know which path you would like to take. If you for instance only see ice_cube used in scenarios where there is a time then you would probably want the user to be told about this by raising an error.

If you however prefer the path of least resistance which might not be such a bad thing in case someone wants to know if something is scheduled today and just send a date in maybe that could be converted to time for these but not for scheduling.

Please report back with your thoughts so that I can start implementing this (we ran into some issues with not getting occurrences back because of sending date or datetime in)

title: Single Occurrence With Multiple Times For a Day
body:
I found this question on [StackOverflow ](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7374715/ruby-ice-cube-exclude-whole-day-for-hourly-recurring-event) that shows how you can have multiple occurrences of a schedule on a single day using the hour_of_day and minute_of_hour methods on a rule.

This works great for weekly, and daily recurrences, but I couldn't seem to find a way to make a non repeating schedule that occurs multiple times in a day. For example I want a schedule that looks like:

5 am
6 am
5pm
On October 15th

I tried using daily and hourly rules with a 0 interval but this just throws a division by zero error on getting occurrences.

title: use UNTIL instead of DTEND to determine last instance of recurrence; fixes #99
body: I believe this better conforms to the RFC. The tests that depended on the non-conforming behavior had to be modified to pass.

title: Schedule#end_time (DTEND) should define the time when an event ends, not its recurrence
body:
Before creating a pull request for this I want to confirm that my understanding of the RFC is correct. When creating a recurring event, the `start_time` and `end_time` of  an instance of `IceCube::Schedule` refer to [DTSTART](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.2.4) and [DTEND](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.2.2) respectively. According to the spec, these properties refer to the _event_. A recurrence rule's last recurrence can be specified by UNTIL. `IceCube` correctly creates the event and recurrence rule with the following example:

```
irb(main):001:0> start_time = Time.new(2012,10,4) + 9 * 60 * 60
irb(main):002:0> end_time = Time.new(2012,10,4) + 17 * 60 * 60
irb(main):003:0> schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, end_time: end_time)
irb(main):005:0> schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.until(Time.new(2012,10,7))
```

`schedule.to_ical` correctly outputs

```
DTSTART;TZID=CST:20121004T090000
RRULE:FREQ=DAILY;UNTIL=20121006T160000Z
DTEND;TZID=CST:20121004T170000
```

But the occurrences are incorrect:

```
irb(main):006:0> schedule.all_occurrences
=> [2012-10-04 09:00:00 +0800]
```

The event lasts from 9AM to 5PM (according to DTSTART and DTEND) and should repeat until 3 days from now (according to UNTIL). But `IceCube` only shows one occurrence, presumably because it follows the date in DTEND rather than UNTIL.

The correct behavior would be to return the following:

```
irb(main):006:0> schedule.all_occurrences
=> [2012-10-04 09:00:00 +0800, 2012-10-05 09:00:00 +0800, 2012-10-06 09:00:00 +0800]
```

I have confirmed that this is the correct behavior in both Google Calendar and Mozilla Thunderbird (with the Lightning calendar plugin) by creating a recurring event and exporting/importing it. The above `schedule.to_ical` generated iCalender event is correctly recognized by both Google Calender and Mozilla Thunderbird.

title: Something terrible happens when count is set to nil.
body:
I found myself needing to remove the count validation from a rule. I attempted to do this by calling:

rule.count(nil)

However, this does not remove the count validation. Instead it sets the count value to nil. If I then try to call a method like occurrences_between after doing this, I get an exception (because count is nil).

Is there a better way to remove a count validation from a rule?

title: from_hash expects keys to be symbols - serialized data normally string keys
body:
I have been having some issues with the `from_hash` method.
My data is serialized into json and stored in the database - then fetched out as a string and parsed to a hash.
This breaks `from_hash` because it is expecting symbols as keys.
There would be a simple fix to throw on a `symbolize_keys` but unfortunately there are nested hashes inside the serialized hash.  This makes me have to write my own handler to recursively symbolize keys in the nested hashes which seems excessive.

It seems like **the** common use case to serialize the schedule into a string and then parse it (probably more often than not from a JSON encoded string).
Is there a good reason for the default behavior?  Am I doing it wrong?
I will provide examples upon request.

Thank you! 
I don't know what I would do without this project :)

title: Schedule find_occurrence when interval is greater than 1 won't use the start date causing invalid results
body:
I found when the `find_occurrences` function is called in `Schedule` that it wants to start from the `opening_time` when looping to find the occurrences between the `begin_time` and `end_time` when the interval is greater than 1. When the interval is > 1 I believe it should begin looping at the `start_time` to make sure when it gets to the `opening_time` and the `closing_time` that it knows that the occurrence falls in the range.

I added `@interval` in daily_interval.rb, weekly_interval.rb, monthly_interval.rb, and yearly_interval.rb to allow `Rule` to have access to it. Then I altered the `full_required?` method to check the interval and make sure it exists and if > 1 to return true.

``` ruby
# Whether this rule requires a full run
def full_required?
  !@count.nil? || (! @interval.nil? && @interval > 1)
end
```

title: conflicts_with? performance fix?
body:
`conflicts_with?` will be one of the key points of my application.
It is unfortunately incredibly slow.
It seems like it may be able to short circuit by asking a couple simple questions about the object being compared
Is it the same time/duration?
Does it fall on the same day?
On the same month?
Same year?
Ok... let's compare every occurrence then.
I think this could turn multiple second queries into multiple millisecond queries.
But I don't know the best way to do this - or if it is even possible.
Any feedback appreciated - and if this is a pain point, I will do my best to code up a solution.

title: Occurrences between breaks on the first exception
body:
Suppose I have a Daily rule which occurs on all days except one day of a week and I invoke occurrences_between, the returned dates are only those till we have the exempted DAY. 

```
require 'rubygems'
require 'ice_cube'
require 'active_support/all'
require 'pp'
include IceCube

schedule = Schedule.new(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily.day(:sunday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday, :saturday)
occurrences = schedule.occurrences_between(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 19), DateTime.new(2012, 05, 24))
occurrences.each do |o|
    puts 'Occurring on ' + o.to_s 
end
```

The expected output is 19th May, 20th, 22nd, 23rd and 24th. But the actual output is only 19th and 20th. Since 21st is not allowed, the logic inside 'find_occurrences' of schedule.rb will break upon the 'res' being NULL. 

For the same reason, invoking schedule.next_occurrence('20th May') will return year 2248 rather than 22nd May.

title: Rule.monthly generates weird results in occurrences_between on the 31st day of the month
body:
Consider the following code:

d = Date.parse("31 March 2012")
s = IceCube::Schedule.new(d)
s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.monthly
list = s.occurrences_between(d, d + 6.months)

If you run this code, list will contain only the following elements:

3/31/2012
5/31/2012
7/31/2012
8/31/2012

It does not include the last days of either April or June as there are not 31 days in these months.  This feels like a bug - and in fact is causing a bug for me - as what I really want is for IceCube to simply pick the last day of the month in this situation.

Is this a bug or is there a better way to handle this?

title: [PATCH] Weekly interval: handle alternate week start.
body:
Make sure ice_cube exports WKST as Sunday to iCal, and allow for alternative week starts.

From the iCal specification:

The WKST rule part specifies the day on which the workweek starts.
Valid values are MO, TU, WE, TH, FR, SA and SU.
This is significant when a WEEKLY RRULE has an interval greater than 1,
and a BYDAY rule part is specified.
This is also significant when in a YEARLY RRULE when a BYWEEKNO rule part is specified.
The default value is MO.

``` ruby
 => {:start_date=>2012-01-29 18:18:53 +0100, :rrules=>[{:validations=>{:day_of_month=>[1]}, :rule_type=>"IceCube::MonthlyRule", :interval=>1}], :exrules=>[], :rdates=>[], :exdates=>[]}
```

It seems to understand only DateTime and only with a specific format, but I can't understand which. I'm trying to set start_date from a form only setting the date (not time) but I'm not able to save this attribute...

title: Psych on Heroku
body:
After updating ice_cube to 0.7.6 I'm getting the following error in production (Heroku):

``` bash
no such file to load -- --- 
:start_date: 2012-01-20 20:00:00 +00:00
:rrules: 
- :rule_type: IceCube::WeeklyRule
[â€¦ YAML CONTINUES â€¦]

vendor/bundle/ruby/1.9.1/gems/activesupport-3.1.1/lib/active_support/dependencies.rb:234:in `load'

```

I've tracked this problem down on the ice_cube side to https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb#L261 . It seems that in production Psych is used as YAML parser and tries to load a file rather than accepting the YAML as string.

It seems _something_ called Psych is defined, but it's `#load` method tries to load a file.

**I got around this by explicitly defining a gem dependency `gem 'psych'` for production.**

I'm assuming that this is not necessarily a ice_cube issue, but maybe something could be done to secure the situation?

Anyway, the gem's super-awesome: if you're not doing the from_ical parsing in the near future, I'll probably take a stab at that as well.  

Cheers

title: bug in occurs_at in combination with recurrence_dates
body:
When adding dates using recurrence_dates, the occures_at returns a wrong value:

```
require 'ice_cube'

s = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.new(2011,10,1, 18, 25))
s.add_recurrence_date(Time.new(2011,12,3,15,0,0))
s.add_recurrence_date(Time.new(2011,12,3,10,0,0)) 
s.add_recurrence_date(Time.new(2011,12,4,10,0,0))

p s.next_occurrences(12)

# Will return false, but it should return true
p s.occurs_at?(Time.new(2011,12,3,15,0,0))
```

This is because the method find_occurrences that is called in the occurrences method does only filter the rules, not the recurrence dates.

title: What's the best approach on Rule creation?
body:
Hello! I've being trying ice_cube for a couple days now, and I got stuck on what would be best when defining a rule... 

Imaging I need to define the schedule a dentist usually works. In plain text might be something like:

```
"Every Monday, Tuesday and Friday from 8:00 to 12:00, each session lasting 60 minutes"
```

I came up with a kinda weird approach, and I'd be glad to get some feedback on: :)

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new Time.now
schedule.duration  = 60
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.minutely(60).day(:monday, :tuesday, :friday).hour_of_day(8, 9, 10, 11)
```

This way, I can define which slots of time will be available...

Thanks!

title: This fixes month-skipping problems that my previous fix did not fully address.
body:
My previous fix did not correctly handle situations where the DST switch happened more than a day
before the "closest" date match of the DayOfWeekValidation.

Basically, if DST cutover forced you an hour back, the check_date adjustment wouldn't happen after incrementing two or more days.

I fixed the unit test to correctly identify this situation.

``` ruby
  it 'should occur on every first day of a month at midnight and not skip months when DST ends' do
    start_date = Time.local(2011, 8, 1)
    [:sunday, :monday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday, :saturday].each_with_index do |day, index|
      schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_date)
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_week(day => [1])
      last_date = nil
      schedule.first(100).each do |current_date|
        # should be the correct day of week
        current_date.wday.should == index
        # should be midnight
        current_date.hour.should == 0
        if last_date then
          month_interval = (current_date.year * 12 + current_date.month) - (last_date.year * 12 + last_date.month)
          # should not skip months
          month_interval.should == 1
        end
        last_date = current_date
      end
    end
  end
```

title: Rule.from_yaml didn't work with timezone data

Any hint is most welcome!

title: Proposed fix for https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/issues/29
body:
DST is causing us to lose a day for monthly schedules when moving out of DST for schedules that start at midnight.
This fixes it.  Also, added a test case to test for this issue.

This is my proposed fix for https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/issues/29

title: day_of_week is broken under some circumstances
next_occurrences / next_occurrence broken with exception dates
body:
Given the simple rule of "Weekly on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays / not on December 25, 2011 / not on December 26, 2011", calling
`schedule.next_occurrences(3, Time.new('2011', '12', '24')) +0100]` returns [2011-12-27 00:00:00 +0100, 2011-12-28 00:00:00]

Much worse: `schedule.next_occurrence Time.new('2011', '12', '24')` returns nil

What I think happens in find_occurrences when you call next_occurrences(3):
1. The next 3 matching dates are calculated
2. The exception dates are calculated
3. The exception dates are subtracted from the matching dates

What I think should happen:
1. The exception dates are calculated
2. The next (3 + number_of_exception_dates) matching dates are calculated
3. The exception dates are subtracted from the matching dates

Sadly, I can't figure out how to code this well.

title: Generated YAML seems to be incompatbile with syck
body:
Not sure whether this is a syck issue or an ice_cube issue.

Given the simple schedule_yaml of 
"---
:start_date: 2011-08-09 14:52:14.597283858 +02:00
:rrules:
- :rule_type: IceCube::WeeklyRule
  :interval: 1
  :until: !!null 
  :count: !!null 
  :validations:
    :day:
    - 1
    - 2
    - 3
    - 4
    - 5
:exrules: []
:rdates: []
:exdates: []
:duration: !!null 
:end_time: !!null 
"

syck chokes with an error of
NoMethodError: undefined method `<' for #<Syck::PrivateType:0xcd3078c @type_id="null", @value="">
    from /home/nl/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-p180@phonostar_app/gems/ice_cube-0.6.13/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb:17:in`initialize'
    from /home/nl/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-p180@phonostar_app/gems/ice_cube-0.6.13/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb:61:in `new'
    from /home/nl/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-p180@phonostar_app/gems/ice_cube-0.6.13/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb:61:in`from_hash'
    from /home/nl/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-p180@phonostar_app/gems/ice_cube-0.6.13/lib/ice_cube/schedule.rb:71:in `from_yaml'

I solved the problem by using psych to parse the schedule, but syck is apparently the default now in rails?

title: Fix daily rule occurrences
body:
Fixed daily rule so that occurrences can properly continue on into a new year. 

Previously #yday was being used in math operations but this caused issues because two odd yday numbers can occur back to back:

> > Date.parse('2011-12-31').yday
> > => 365
> > Date.parse('2012-1-1').yday
> > => 1

I also noticed a comment of "TODO repair" on line 5 of daily_rule.rb, I'm not sure of the purpose of the comment but you may want to remove it if my fix is the "repair".

title: 0.6.12: Changing start_date doesn't change internal use of start_date
body:
When the start date is changed, the Schedule instance seems to use the old start_date when calculating occurring_at?().  Rebuilding the object "x = Schedule.from_hash(x.to_hash)" clears the issue and uses the new start date internally. For my test case "occurring_at?()" goes from a 7 second calculation to about a millisecond (depending on cpu capability of course). 

Thanks for your efforts in creating and maintaining this library!

As a side issue, and not a bug per se, when a start_date is significantly before a time being tested, the calculation can take a long time. However, I believe the code only needs to test in the range ("t - self.duration" through time t) to determine if occurring_at?(t) is true. Duration would default to one day if not specified (?). 

A simple test program:
ruby 1.8.7 (2010-12-23 patchlevel 330) [i686-linux]
ice_cube (0.6.12)

```
#!/usr/bin/ruby
require 'rubygems'
require 'ice_cube'

tbegin = Time.local(0,0,0,10,12,1970,nil,nil,true,'CDT')
t      = Time.local(0,1,1,10, 8,2011,nil,nil,true,'CDT')
tend   = Time.local(0,0,0,10,12,2037,nil,nil,true,'CDT')

schedule  = IceCube::Schedule.new(tbegin, :end_time => tend, :duration => (60*60*24))

days = [0,1,2,4,5,6]
rule1 = IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(*days)

schedule.add_recurrence_rule(rule1)

# test time to calculate occurring_at?() with starting date in 1970
t_a0 = Time.now
occurs_a = schedule.occurring_at?(t)
t_a1 = Time.now

# change the start date to just be one day ahead
schedule.start_date = t - (60*60*24)

# test time to calculate occurring_at?() with
# starting date in 2011 just by changing 'start_date' value
t_b0 = Time.now
occurs_b = schedule.occurring_at?(t)
t_b1 = Time.now

# convert the schedule to a hash and then rebuild it from the same hash
schedule2 = IceCube::Schedule.from_hash(schedule.to_hash)
# schedule2 should be exact logical copy of schedule

# Test how fast occurring_at?() is calculated now.
t_c0 = Time.now
occurs_c = schedule2.occurring_at?(t)
t_c1 = Time.now

puts "Test occurring_at? start_date in 1970:    t_a_delta=#{t_a1-t_a0}" # slow
puts "start_date set to 2011 using method:      t_b_delta=#{t_b1-t_b0}" # slow
puts "to_hash() passed directly to from_hash(): t_c_delta=#{t_c1-t_c0}" # fast
```

My results:

> [root@conf1 lance]# ./icecube
> Test occurring_at? start_date in 1970:    t_a_delta=11.53168
> start_date set to 2011 using method:      t_b_delta=12.15053
> to_hash() passed directly to from_hash(): t_c_delta=0.001712

title: More examples
body:
Hello,

I find the syntax of your library to be very nice and readable. However, I'm more interested to know what kinds of things can be done with your library. For example, I'm working on displaying a weekly schedule of activities. I will need to create a form for creating the recurrence rules. The activities occur on the same day(s) every week, so there is no need for me to save an actual date in the database. I'm more concerned with saving the time of day, and day of the week. So I am wondering if your library can help we with that. So far I'm just saving the day as a number (0-6) and the time as a string (i.e. 8:00am), but I'm looking for a more elegant solution.

Can your library help me with that? What other use cases could this library be used for?

title: Intervals and how they work
body:
Hi John,

This isn't necessarily an issue, just wanted to know what your thinking is behind intervals.

It looks like when you do a fortnightly rule, like:
IceCube::Rule.weekly(2).day(2) #recurring every other tuesday.

The weeks that the occurrences recur on is based on the week number in the year, rather than the number of weeks from the start date of the schedule.

For example, if my schedule starts on 2010-01-05, the first 3 occurences are:
2010-01-12, 
2010-01-26
2010-02-09

where I would have expected:
2010-01-05
2010-01-19
2010-02-02 
(i.e. fortnightly from the start date).

I appreciate either behaviour makes sense depending on the particular application, but is the former behaviour what you expect?

Hope I have made sense!

Incidentally, schedule.first(n) with a fortnightly rule gives you 5 rather than 10 occurences (i.e. the first 10 weeks of occurences, rather than the first 10 occurences).

Cheers,
Philip Roberts

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.parse("2010-08-30"))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.monthly(6)
puts schedule.occurrences_between(Time.parse("2010-07-01"), Time.parse("2010-09-01"))
```

Spec:
    --- a/spec/examples/dst_spec.rb
    +++ b/spec/examples/dst_spec.rb
    @@ -210,6 +210,13 @@ describe Schedule, 'occurs_on?' do
         schedule.first(3).should == [Time.local(2010, 3, 12, 19, 0, 0), Time.local(2010, 5, 12, 19, 0, 0), Time.local(2010, 7, 12, 19, 0, 0)]
       end

```
+  it "local - should make dates on monthly (day of week) inverval over dst" do
+    start_date = Time.local(2010, 3, 7, 12, 0, 0)
+    schedule = Schedule.new(start_date)
+    schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_week(:sunday => [1])

```

title: Daily rules stop working after daylight savings time starts
body:
Daily rules that start in standard time seem to stop generating occurrences after daylight savings time starts. Occurrences seem to resume after daylight savings time ends.

Here is a spec:

```
--- a/spec/examples/daily_rule_spec.rb
+++ b/spec/examples/daily_rule_spec.rb
@@ -21,5 +21,16 @@ describe DailyRule, 'occurs_on?' do
     dates.size.should == 3
     dates.should == [DAY, DAY + 2 * IceCube::ONE_DAY, DAY + 4 * IceCube::ONE_DAY]
   end
-     
+
+  it 'should produce the correct days spanning daylight savings time' do
+    Time.zone = "Eastern Time (US & Canada)"
+    schedule = Schedule.new(Time.zone.parse("Mar 12 2010 19:00"))
+    schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily(3)
+    dates = schedule.occurrences(Time.zone.parse("Mar 19 2010"))
+    dates.size.should == 3
+    dates.should == [Time.zone.parse("Mar 12 2010 19:00"),
+                     Time.zone.parse("Mar 15 2010 19:00"),
+                     Time.zone.parse("Mar 18 2010 19:00")]
+  end
+ 
 end
```

P.S. Sorry if I submitted this multiple times, github is being really strange for me.

title: Another Fix for #68 #76 - Add new devices type
body:
According to the NetworkManager documentation:
https://developer.gnome.org/NetworkManager/stable/nm-dbus-types.html#NMDeviceType

There is 4 new device type:
```
NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WPAN      = 27 - a IEEE 802.15.4 (WPAN) MAC Layer Device
NM_DEVICE_TYPE_6LOWPAN   = 28 - 6LoWPAN interface
NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIREGUARD = 29 - a WireGuard interface
NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIFI_P2P  = 30 - an 802.11 Wi-Fi P2P device (Since: 1.16)
```

This changes add contants and classes for these devices and add them
in the device_class dict.

Fix #68 #76
See also #80

title: Added WifiP2P type, Fixes #76
body: Fixes #76

title: Fix for Issue 68 - device_class default return value
body: It appears that some devices do not have a device type that `python-networkmanager` understands. The old code would cause exceptions and refuse to run if you had such a device on your system. I simply changed the lookup for device types to return a "Generic" device in the event that the type was unknown.

title: KeyError: dbus.UInt32(30, variant_level=1) again
body:
It appears that fix is not in the latest 2.1:
 WIFI_P2P devices #72

One of the suggestions I would make is making sure that a dictionary lookup doesn't crash like so:

def device_class(typ):
    return {
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_ADSL: Adsl,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BOND: Bond,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BRIDGE: Bridge,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_BT: Bluetooth,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_ETHERNET: Wired,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_GENERIC: Generic,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_INFINIBAND: Infiniband,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_IP_TUNNEL: IPTunnel,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MACVLAN: Macvlan,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MODEM: Modem,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OLPC_MESH: OlpcMesh,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_TEAM: Team,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_TUN: Tun,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VETH: Veth,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VLAN: Vlan,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_VXLAN: Vxlan,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIFI: Wireless,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_WIMAX: Wimax,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_MACSEC: MacSec,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_DUMMY: Dummy,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_PPP: PPP,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_INTERFACE: OvsIf,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_PORT: OvsPort,
        NM_DEVICE_TYPE_OVS_BRIDGE: OvsBridge
    }.get(typ,None)

Of course, I did realize something else needed a good value, so i had to change the following routine to catch error (Can't use None as an object):

    def __new__(klass, object_path):
        if klass == Device:
            # Automatically specialize the device
            try:
                obj = dbus.SystemBus().get_object(klass.dbus_service, object_path)
                klass = device_class(obj.Get('org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.Device', 'DeviceType', dbus_interface='org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties'))
                return klass.__new__(klass, object_path)
            except ObjectVanished:
                pass
            except TypeError:
                return None
        return super(Device, klass).__new__(klass, object_path)

title: Registering on device OnPropertiesChanged signal, register on the wrong interface.
body:
After registering on a device, obtained using GetDevices function, the key on which the callback is registered is:
   ('org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.**Device.Statistics**', 'PropertiesChanged')
While it should be
   ('org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.**Device**', 'PropertiesChanged')

* this is a degradation from a previous version, although not sure how previous.

Example:
In [1]: import NetworkManager
In [2]: NetworkManager.NetworkManager.GetDevices()
Out[2]: 
[<NetworkManager.Modem at 0x7f4a8b3c1710>]
In[3]: device = NetworkManager.NetworkManager.GetDevices()[0]
In[4]: device.OnPropertiesChanged(lambda:None)

body:

title: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown if NetworkManager service restarts
body:
If NetworkManager service restarts, it gets a new dbus unix process id. The python-networkmanager remains with the old id. since this process doesn't exist any more, a org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown exception is thrown.

The parameter follow_name_owner_changes can be used in get_object() calls to prevent this.

title: Wrong enum mapping for connectivity state flags
body:
The NM_CONNECTIVITY_* flags are mapped incorrectly.
The correct definition is: 
https://people.freedesktop.org/~lkundrak/nm-docs/nm-dbus-types.html#NMConnectivityState

however the values defined in the api are 0 indexed:
https://github.com/seveas/python-networkmanager/blob/master/NetworkManager.py#L751-L755

title: React to activating/deactivating a connection
body:
I want to execute my code after a connection is enabled and before it gets disabled. (Similar to the NetworkManager-Dispatcher events `up` and `pre-down`.
In addition i want the Connection object of the changing connection. (i need to compare the uuids).
How can i accomplish this?
`NetworkManager.NetworkManager.OnStateChanged` does not contain information which connection changed.
Furthermore how could i do something like `pre-down`, as the NetworkManager API doesn't seem to have a signal/event like this?

title: invalid literal for long() with base 10: 'fec0::1'
body:
Hey, trying to add an IPv6 connection like this:

```
connection = {
      '802-3-ethernet': {'mac-address': mac_address,
                         'mac-address-blacklist': a_blacklist},
      'connection': {'autoconnect': True,
                     'id': 'myid',
                     'type': '802-3-ethernet',
                     'uuid': some_UUID},
  }
addr1 = dbus.Dictionary({
    'address': 'fec0::1',
    'prefix': dbus.UInt32(64)})
connection['ipv6'] = dbus.Dictionary({
       'address-data': dbus.Array([addr1], signature=dbus.Signature('a{sv}')),
       'gateway': '::',
       'method': 'shared'})
NetworkManager.Settings.AddConnection(connection)
```

But I'm getting the following:
`ValueError: invalid literal for long() with base 10: 'fec0::1'`

Can someone please tell me where is my mistake here? Thanks!

When installing I get this error:
```

Requested 'dbus-1 >= 1.8' but version of dbus is 1.6.18
```

title: NetworkManager.DeviceRemoved doesn't get invoked
body:
While other signals work fine (`PropertiesChanged` and `DeviceAdded` among others) I was not able to get a notification for `DeviceRemoved`. My sample code is a modified `listener.py` example:


```python
import dbus.mainloop.glib
from gi.repository import GObject, GLib
import NetworkManager
import time

def out(msg):
    print("%s %s" % (time.strftime('%H:%M:%S'), msg))

def statechange(nm, interface, signal, state):
    out("State changed to %s" % NetworkManager.const('STATE', state))

def adddevice(nm, interface, signal, device_path):
    try:
        out("Device %s added" % device_path.IpInterface)
    except NetworkManager.ObjectVanished:
        # Sometimes this signal is sent for *removed* devices. Ignore.
        pass

def removedevice(*args, **kw):
    out("removedevice: {} {}".format(args, kw))

def main():
    dbus.mainloop.glib.DBusGMainLoop(set_as_default=True)
    NetworkManager.NetworkManager.OnStateChanged(statechange)
    NetworkManager.NetworkManager.OnDeviceAdded(adddevice)
    NetworkManager.NetworkManager.OnDeviceRemoved(removedevice)

    loop = GObject.MainLoop()
    loop.run()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

```

title: Bug fixes
body:
Hi Dennis,
With NM 1.4.4 and python 2.7 I was facing some issues. Hope this helps.

One more detail: commit 7453a4b6e0c3a71d7062e4971a56cac1857368e3 "Add dependencies to setup.py" leads to a python egg installation, at least on Yocto. Without this commit NetworkManager.py(c) is installed as expected. Is this related to my setup or is an egg the preferred installation for python-networkmanager?

title: Add missing Statistics Interface for Devices
body: The Statistics interface is available for Network Manager Devices since Network Manager version 1.4.6. With this patch the corresponding properties will be available for every device.

title: LICENSE
body: I've noticed the project is missing a license. I'm interested in using python-networkmanager, but can't, unless it has an explicit license file.

title: Added additional handler to_dbus() fixup
body:
Specific fixup for settings.connection.address-data fields, as
these resulted in the following error:

dbus.connection: unable to set arguments ... according to
signature 'a{sa{sv}}': <class 'TypeError'>: Expected a string
or unicode object

Fixes issue #40.

title: Added 6 new device types (in NM_DEVICE_TYPE_..)
body:
The following device types/classes where missing:

    MACSEC
    Dummy
    PPP
    OVS_INTERFACE
    OVS_PORT
    OVS_BRIDGE

This pull request adds them all.

title: Need to set up DBusGMainLoop before importing networkmanager when connecting signal
body:
currently I think you need to do this, initialise the dbus main loop before importing network manager:
```
from dbus.mainloop.glib import DBusGMainLoop
from gi.repository import GLib
DBusGMainLoop(set_as_default=True)
import NetworkManager
def callback(*args, **kwargs): pass
loop = GLib.MainLoop()
NetworkManager.NetworkManager.connect_to_signal('PropertiesChanged', callback)
loop.run()
```
I guess this is because some GBus logic is already initialized during import. if you don't set up the dbus main loop before the network manager import an error is raised:

```
RuntimeError: To make asynchronous calls, receive signals or export objects, D-Bus connections must be attached to a main loop by passing mainloop=... to the constructor or calling dbus.set_default_main_loop(...)
```

title: Manual IPv4 setup does not work
body:
**Description of problem:**
When adding a new connection with manual IPv4 settings it fails because of invalid type. However, according to nm-settings documentation I'm using it right (correct me if I am wrong). "Array of IPv4 addresses. Each address dictionary contains at least 'address' and 'prefix' entries, containing the IP address as a string, and the prefix length as a uint32."

**Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):**
python-networkmanager (2.0.1)
Python 3.4.5

**How reproducible:**
Always

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Create a connection with manual IP address settings:
```python
'ipv4': {
    'method': 'manual',
    'address-data': [{'address': '192.168.1.1', 'prefix': 24}]
}
```

Fails with "TypeError: Expected a string or unicode object"

**Expected results:**
Creates a connection with static IP.

```python
[root@localhost ~]# python3
```
