title: Python error when using update_rib_firmware
body:
While attempting to upgrade the ILO firmware with the CLI tool, I consistently get a python error:

```
$ hpilo_cli localhost update_rib_firmware filename=/tmp/ilo4_132.bin
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/hpilo_cli", line 267, in <module>
    main()
  File "/usr/bin/hpilo_cli", line 183, in main
    results = [getattr(ilo, method)(**params)]
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 1496, in update_rib_firmware
    self._upload_file(filename, progress_)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 252, in _upload_file
    sent += written
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +=: 'int' and 'NoneType'
```

title: Permit the use of & characters in passwords
body:
As per the comments, the HP iLOs support '&' in passwords, whereas this is a special character in XML. ElementTree escapes the & character into & which causes a 'login failed' error.

The closest actual reference I can find from HP on this is in HP advisory document c03221572.

title: Making hpilo_ca work for ilo4
body:
Is there any reason why hpilo_ca only allows ilo2+3 currently? It seems to work fine for ilo4 as well by just adding:

```
138c138,139
<         elif fw_version['management_processor'] == 'iLO3':

---
>         elif ((fw_version['management_processor'] == 'iLO3') ||
>               (fw_version['management_processor'] == 'iLO4')):
```

title: Misnamed global setting ipmi_dmci_over_lan_enabled
body:
Likely a typo, but the code tries to set 'ipmi_dmci_over_lan_enabled' when it should be 'ipmi_dcmi_over_lan_enabled'. 

~~dmci~~ versus dcmi

title: Adding new params to mod_network_settings and mod_global_settings
body:
Added these to mod_global_settings:
- ipmi_dcmi_over_lan_enabled
- remote_syslog_enable
- remote_syslog_port
- remote_syslog_server_address
- snmp_access_enabled
- snmp_port
- snmp_trap_port

Added these to mod_network_settings:
- dhcpv6_dns_server
- dhcpv6_rapid_commit
- dhcpv6_stateful_enable
- dhcpv6_stateless_enable
- dhcpv6_sntp_settings

> download and use the latest firmware

title: progress argument in update_rib_firmware()

title: insert_virtual_media should default to device type CDROM
body:
It would be great if the first argument insert_virtual_media would default to device type 'CDROM'. Everytime I have to look at the syntax which case the device types are written. At the moment these are:

'floppy' -> lowercase 
'CDROM' -> uppercase

Also I do not see a future benefit of using floppy virtual images...
Perhaps a wish for the next major...

title: TypeError: zip argument #1 must support iteration
body:
I tried some code as follows against an iLO3 interface, and while it seemed to execute, it threw this error inside hpilo.py (in code below I leave out the specific settings of the arguments):

$ python test.py 
/home/sparksa/python-hpilo-2.1/hpilo.py:424: IloWarning: Server being reset.
  warnings.warn(child.get('MESSAGE'), IloWarning)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 18, in <module>
    resp = ilo.call_delayed()
  File "/home/sparksa/python-hpilo-2.1/hpilo.py", line 608, in call_delayed
    for message, processor in zip(message, self._processors):
TypeError: zip argument #1 must support iteration

ilo = hpilo.Ilo(hostname, login=username, password=password,
                timeout=5, protocol=hpilo.ILO_HTTP, delayed=True)

ilo.activate_license(license_key)
ilo.insert_virtual_media(device='cdrom', image_url=VM_URL)
ilo.set_vm_status(device='cdrom', boot_option='boot_once')
ilo.reset_server()

resp = ilo.call_delayed()
for r in resp:
  print r

When performing get_ahs_status() against a iLOv2 machine i get the following exception:

```
ilo.get_ahs_status()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>

    return self._info_tag('RIB_INFO', 'GET_AHS_STATUS')

    header, message = self._request(root)

    message = self._parse_message(data)

    raise IloError(message, status)
hpilo.IloError: Syntax error: Line #0: syntax error near "" in the line: ""
```

```
>>> ilo.get_fw_version()
{'license_type': 'iLO 2 Advanced', 'firmware_version': '2.15', 'management_processor': 'iLO2', 'firmware_date': 'Jan 17 2013'}
```

Using hpilo -> commit 7aa2d46bf9802f89789febfb27c17a90dba7b522

title: Actions using hpilo quite slow
body:
I don't know if there's anything that I can debug or change to improve this, but any action using python-hpilo is quite slow. It might be due to HTTPS (and the self-signed certificate) or maybe the iLO interface is in itself slow to respond, I don't know.

Is there something I can do or test to see if we can speed up python-hpilo ? What we typically do is get facts from iLO (like interfaces, mac-addresses, hardware) and order a reboot with a specific virtual media over HTTP.

The modules that implement this are available from:
- https://github.com/ansible-provisioning/ansible-provisioning/blob/master/library/hpilo_boot
- https://github.com/ansible-provisioning/ansible-provisioning/blob/master/library/hpilo_facts

title: File "<string>", line 85, in XML: SyntaxError: syntax error: line 1, column 49
body:
Connecting (accidentally) to the enclosure instead of the blade, I got the output below. Whereas I was expecting some exception during the connection, hpilo seems to fail at some later stage during ilo.get_host_data().

The authentication step should have failed as the login/password we use for the blades do not work for the enclosure.

We are using hpilo 1.4

Here is the output:

```
  File "/root/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1354270344.48-220488112890304/hpilo_facts", line 799, in <module>
    main()
  File "/root/.ansible/tmp/ansible-1354270344.48-220488112890304/hpilo_facts", line 110, in main
    data = ilo.get_host_data()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 639, in get_host_data
    header, message = self._request(root)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 126, in _request
    message = self._parse_message(data)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 359, in _parse_message
    message = etree.fromstring(data)
  File "<string>", line 85, in XML
SyntaxError: syntax error: line 1, column 49
```

The code only does:

``` python
    ilo = hpilo.Ilo(host, login=login, password=password, protocol=protocol)
    data = ilo.get_host_data()
```

and is available from: https://github.com/ansible-provisioning/ansible-provisioning/blob/master/library/hpilo_facts

Add release tarballs to Github files interface
body: It would be useful if the releases are available from Github's files interface.

title: hpilo_ca Certificate Signing Request output is mangled, preventing signing
body:
Hi, I'm trying to use hpilo_ca to sign ilo2 fw2.07 certs. My CA is setup and working fine from the command line. When using hpilo_ca I get this error: 
(3/5) Signing certificate
Using configuration from /path/to/openssl.cnf
Error reading certificate request in /path/to/CA/certs/usorla7lp201x.csr
140222387644232:error:0906D066:PEM routines:PEM_read_bio:bad end line:pem_lib.c:797:
When I examine the csr file retrieved, the formatting is off at the end, making it invalid. 
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----
MIIB+zCCAWQCAQAwgZQxCzAJBgNVBAYTAlVTMQ4wDAYDVQQIEwVUZXhhczEQMA4G
[ snip ]
2fpqDfsUAg+HtTRloC+/nco+jFtBG0PYvDirxR9PSLvcIy71SGIThu+32QH1A2Rn
RKnwhzFJ2ms4hnRrjzAHJAyr1fEPMpmq0j9VBXeNmA="="-----END CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----
Signing it manually with openssl fails with the same error as above. Fixing the formatting manually, I'm able to sign it with openssl. Using HP's sample ILO scripts the CSR is returned from the ILO formatted properly, so I don't think the problem is coming from the ILO. I'm using python-2.6.6-29.el6.x86_64 Thanks for any help.

title: useful to you?
body:
I added a few bits and bobs that I wanted to use to python-hpilo, mainly network setup on the iLO. I also tested get_one_time_boot (and made persistent work, though it's not fully tested yet). Hopefully it's of some use to you as well.

-James

title: Added --port option to hpilo_cli to allow for non-standard iLO settings.
body:
I added a --port option to hpilo_cli so that I can use SSH port-forwarding to access my iLO's.
I used '-o' for the short option flag as '-p/--password' and '-P/--protocol' were already used.

Thanks for your work! From my limited testing (mainly read-only operations) it seems to work rather well.

Hardware tested:
- HP SL390s G7
- HP SL335s G7
- HP DL380 G7

Andrew

title: Shorten markdown to md
body:
- Shorten README extension for markdown to "md"
- Fix Known Issue: On generation of the Markdown, the initial title does not linefeed before the header sequence.

title: `rake build` gives an error in Git Bash on Windows 10
body:
Hi,

I am running on the latest version of jeweler: 2.3.9 on Windows 10 in Git Bash.

When I run `rake build` in a jeweler project (tried multiple projects that work fine on the Mac), I get this error:

```
rake aborted!
Git::GitExecuteError: git '-c' 'color.ui=false' version   2>&1:git: ''-c'' is not a git command. See 'git --help'.

Tasks: TOP => build
(See full trace by running task with --trace)
```

Git is working fine. Running on this version: "git version 2.27.0.windows.1"

Help would be appreciated.

title: Reset $SAFE to 0 for ruby 2.6
body:
Before ruby 2.6, $SAFE was global to a thread, so setting it in a
separate thread would not affect main thread.

Since ruby 2.6, $SAFE is global to the process:
https://bugs.ruby-lang.org/issues/14250. This leads to unexpected
SecurityError occuring with ruby 2.6. The recommended approach is to
restore $SAFE to 0.

This should fix #304

title: Upgrade github_api dependency to 0.16.0 to relax dependency on nokogiri
body:
Wanting to upgrade nokogiri to 1.7.1 to [fix latest libxml2 vulnerabilities](https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/issues/1615), this was not possible due to dependency to github_api 0.11.0 which depends on nokogiri ~> 1.6.0.

Upgrading to github_api 0.16.0 fixes this issue as nokogiri dependency was removed in 0.13.1.

title: Failing builds on dependent projects due too strict Ruby version requirement
body:
After the update for the `dependencies_for` that I have PRed the new Jeweler version has instated a constraint on my code that

> Gem::InstallError: jeweler requires Ruby version >= 2.2.2.

This broke tests for all libraries that work perfectly fine with 2.1 and 2.2 < 2.2.2. This was not expected TBH. Is there a specific reason this threshold was chosen?  I do see a7de79e6ef3c9f2f54b07bdef48a5da23c12affa but there is no explanation why this compatibility threshold needed raising. Maybe there is just some specific dependency that is playing up?

title: Merging Jeweler and Juwelier
body:
Currently, I am putting a lot of new features into Juwelier, but maintaining 2 code bases can be a bit cumbersome, so eventually I want to merge both. However, the name space issue looms large, and I may have to do some nasty tricks to make it work, because I do NOT want to abandon those using Juwelier, and many are still using Jeweler.

So what I might wind up doing is, after the merge, I will simply do simultaneous releases to both places. I am open to suggestions on better approaches. RubyGem does not appear to have a "transitional package" option like apt-get does. 

Any thoughts and criticisms are welcome. I won't begin on this until I clear out the outstanding issues with both code bases.

title: Update repo description with current status
body:
The description currently reads

> Opinionated tool for creating and managing Rubygem projects. Unmaintained, see https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/issues/283 for jeweler's future (if there is one)

Where #283 is now closed, and [README](https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/blob/master/README.markdown) states that

> Jeweler maintenance has now shifted to Fred Mitchell. I am now maintaining both Jeweler and its fork, juwelier. I will keep Jeweler at least functional with the latest Ruby releases, but put new features in Juwelier. Your input on this is more than welcome.
>   
>   <snip>
>   
>   PLEASE NOTE that if you are starting afresh, please use the successor [Juwelier](https://github.com/flajann2/juwelier) I (Fred Mitchell, flajann2) will be maintaining both Jeweler and Juwelier, but will be adding new features to Juwelier, and eventually "merge" this one into Juwelier after some namespace issues are dealt with.

Could the repo description be updated to explain that the project is currently maintained, and perhaps that the project will be merged into Juwelier at some point?

body:
Hello,

When I try to start a new gem project with `jeweler hello-world`, I'm greeted with the following message:

```
Encountered an error while adding origin remote. Maybe you have some weird settings in ~/.gitconfig?
/home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/git-1.3.0/lib/git/lib.rb:937:in `command': git '--git-dir=/tmp/hello-world/.git' '--work-tree=/tmp/hello-world' remote 'add' '--' 'origin' 'git@github.com:pixelastic/hello-world.git'  2>&1:fatal: remote origin already exists. (Git::GitExecuteError)
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/git-1.3.0/lib/git/lib.rb:688:in `remote_add'

        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/lib/jeweler/generator.rb:279:in `block in create_version_control'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/lib/jeweler/generator.rb:258:in `chdir'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/lib/jeweler/generator.rb:258:in `create_version_control'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/lib/jeweler/generator.rb:129:in `run'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/lib/jeweler/generator/application.rb:34:in `run!'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/gems/jeweler-2.0.1/bin/jeweler:9:in `<top (required)>'
        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/bin/jeweler:23:in `load'

        from /home/tim/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.2.3/bin/ruby_executable_hooks:15:in `<main>'

```

I do have something related to the `origin` remote in my `~/.gitconfig`:

```
[remote "origin"]
  prune = true
```

(This allow [auto pruning of deleted remote branches when doing a pull](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18308535/automatic-prune-with-git-fetch-or-pull))

Still, `jeweler` seems to be choking on it because it is trying to create a remote that already exists. Removing the config from my `.gitconfig` lets me use the gem correctly.

I'm using git v2.8.0.rc1

title: Shouldn't allow to do rake install unless version is specified
body:
When I'm developing a new gem and forget to set the initial version and then I run `rake install`, the gem installs into a rubygem dir under `gem_name-` which prevents rubygems from working correctly. I end up reinstalling ruby completely.

There should be a check not allowing to perform `rake install` unless the version is set.

title: Future of jeweler
body:
I don't use jeweler anymore, and haven't done any active work on it in a few years. I could say I don't have time for it, but that's not quite true, but it's definitely a matter of not being a priority for me.

I see a couple possibilities:
- mark the repository as abandoned, and recommend alternatives
- find the most active fork, and make them the 'canonical' fork

For the latter, there have been forks that take on different names. I'd be happy to let one of those be the canonical fork, but I'd just like to see either:
- deprecate their forked name (ie give a warning), update to rename back to jeweler
- deprecate jeweler, and direct to the renamed fork so there's an upgrade path

I might have cared about the 'jeweler' legacy at some point and it staying attached to my name, but at this point I'd be just happy to see it actively maintained and in new, caring hands.

cc https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/issues/280 https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/pull/281 @steakknife @flajann2

title: --rspec option not respected on gem creation
body:
With the following options (in 2.0.1) :

```
jeweler --rspec --shoulda  --user-name dgmora --user-email david@somewhere.com --github-username dgmora --git-remote heythere --create-repo --yard heythere
```

rspec folder is not created, TestUnit is used instead:

```
create  .gitignore
create  Rakefile
create  Gemfile
create  LICENSE.txt
create  README.rdoc
create  .document
create  lib
create  lib/heythere.rb
create  test
create  test/helper.rb
create  test/test_heythere.rb
```

If I **swap** `--rspec` and `--shoulda` options, the rspec folder is generated as expected.

title: Is Nokogiri really required?
body:
So this is a long shot, but I thought I will try. I still have lots of gems that have to be usable on 1.8.7 (and they are actually used by people in that context, because most of them use older Linux). For instance, I have committed to keep the entire dependency graph of https://gemnasium.com/gems/tracksperanto 1.8.7-compatible. This is actually very easy to do for me (I just keep adding Travis configs for the new Ruby versions and move on), and has provided great longevity for the releases.

I do have problems with Jeweler requiring Nokogiri starting with 1.8.5. Currently I have more than 10 gems I had to lock down to Jeweler 1.8.4 because highline will not build on older Rubies at all. Plus, build times go up if gems are not cached.

However, locking down to 1.8.4 is currently problematic because I get this when I try to release:

```
rake aborted!
LoadError: cannot load such file -- rubygems/builder

Tasks: TOP => release => gemcutter:release => build
```

So I would love to update mto a newer Jeweler, but I can't because then I kill 1.8.7 compatibility just because Jeweler has to go up.

I was wondering: is there actually a reason Nokogiri became a dependency, while everything worked fine off of REXML? Was there a reason a switchover to Nokogiri was _that_ necessary after all? 

Bear in mind: I love Jeweler and it is an essential part of my workflow, and I still [endorse it](http://live.julik.nl/2014/11/why-stick-to-jeweler) - just that particular problem has been nagging me for quite a while.

title: Workflow with git-flow
body:
I just tried to find the right workflow using Jeweler in combination with [git-flow](https://danielkummer.github.io/git-flow-cheatsheet/) for my [db_clustering](https://github.com/Dschee/db_clustering) project. In git-flow I'm used to start a release branch (e.g. `release/1.1.2`), do my release there so run `rake version:bump:patch` and `rake release` and merge the release branch with the git-flow scripts (which will merge it to master and develop and checkout the develop branch).

The problem is that `rake release` automatically creates a `.gemspec` file and uses the `master` branch (instead of the current branch) to do the release â€“ which is not what I was expecting since I was in a different branch. This leads to the re-release of the old `master` branch code under the new version tag. Also simply doing the `gem version:bump:patch` in the release branch and running `rake release` after merging it to the master branch didn't seem right since this will prevent the `.gemspec` file from being updated within the `develop` branch and I have to manually prevent the merging to the master branch in git-flow from creating a `1.1.2` flag.

For now I have stopped using git-flow within that library until I'm sure how to do it the right way. Are there any thoughts on how to use git-flow alongside jeweler?

Thanks in advance for any help.

title: Extract duplicate code in version_helper to private method
body: Hey there! I was browsing around on Code Climate for some OSS libraries to contribute to and I came across Jeweler, which I've used often - so thanks a lot for all of your awesome hard work! Code Climate didn't find many issues with your code but did point out this bit of duplication that I extracted to a private method. I also added the Code Climate badge to the repo's README. Thanks again!

title: Add support for a '.gemignore' file
body:
We've done this on a bunch of gems lately, it would be cool to see it supported in jeweler as an alternative approach to the exclude/includes configuration:

https://gist.github.com/l8nite/18e1aa073d4c758bf440

The advantage with this approach is that the syntax/etc utilizes .gitignore syntax while applying the results to which files are included in your gem.

title: Alternative implementation of a --no-github option
body:
This PR adds support for a `--no-github` option to the `jeweler` command, which enables a user to create a gem project using Jeweler without requiring GitHub for a remote repository. When the `--no-github` flag is not set, the functionality of the `jeweler` command is unchanged; this PR does not introduce any breaking changes.

Unlike #186, this PR does not conflate 'no GitHub' and 'no Git.' Thus, using the `--no-github` option will still create a Git repo. Adding support for a `--no-git` flag could be added separately, as discussed in #186.

Usage:

``` sh
jeweler --no-github the-perfect-gem
```

which will create a new gem project `the-perfect-gem` with an initialized Git repo, without a remote repository configured.

This PR also includes several tests for the new functionality.

title: Permissions are not corrected during ```rake release```
body:
My user account operates with `umask 067` which means that files created with such user are not public readable by default, which leads to gems released through `jeweler` not working, due to the fact that the file permissions are mirrored from my file system.

`jeweler` chases ownership of the files it puts into the zip archive that comprises the gem from local user to `root`, but it fails to change their permissions bits to be publicly readable (which is necessary for normal functioning of gems installed in public gem directories).

Modified the following files as indicated:

> `test/helper.rb`

``` ruby
SimpleCov.configure do
  clean_filters
  # load_adapter 'test_frameworks'
  load_profile 'test_frameworks'
end
```

``` ruby
# require 'test/unit'
require 'minitest/autorun'
require 'shoulda'
```

``` ruby
# class Test::Unit::TestCase
# end
class MiniTest::Test
end

MiniTest.autorun
```

> `test/test_{GEM_NAME}.rb`

``` ruby
# class Test{GEM_NAME} < Test::Unit::TestCase
class Test{GEM_NAME} < MiniTest::Test
```
## Conclusion

It fired right up! I hope this helps someone else who is stuck on that set of errors!
- Pierce

title: Can't enhance gemspec task
body:
I have enhanced the gemspec task to include platform specific patches, but "rake release" generates a new gemspec file ignoring the enhanced task.

```
Rake::Task["gemspec"].enhance do
  spec = "opine.gemspec"
  text = File.read(spec)
  text.gsub!(/^(.*<cocoa>.*)$/, '\1 if RUBY_PLATFORM =~ /darwin/')
  text.gsub!(/^(.*<stench>.*)$/, '\1 if RUBY_PLATFORM =~ /cygwin|mingw|mswin|windows/')
  File.open(spec, 'w') { |file| file.write(text) }
end
```

title: Should use user.name in ~/.gitconfig if github.user is not specified
body:
I can use github successfully without ever setting github.user, instead relying on the standard user.name.

Jeweler should fall back to user.name if github.user is not specified.  Most people do not have github.user set.

Thanks

title: introduce coveralls

title: Update nokogiri to latest version (1.6.0) or make dependency softer (>=, for example).
body: Is there any particular reason why you strictly stuck with `1.5.10` of `nokogiri`?

title: rake release accepts remote and branches
body:
`rake release` accepts remote(default: `origin`), local branch (default: `master`)
and remote branch(default: `master`)as optional arguments.

```
$ rake release[upstream,critical-security-fix,v3]
```

This will tag and push the commits on your local branch named `critical-security-fix`
to branch named `v3` in remote named `upstream` (if you have commit rights on `upstream`)
and release the gem. This is useful in scenarios where releases keep happening from
older version branches, like in Rails.

title: Replace RCov
body: It doesn't work with 1.9. I think SimpleCov is widely used.

title: Fix version:bump commands.
body:
This fixes the issue documented in #245.

Asides from the test changes, I confirmed that `rake version:bump:patch` works with this patch.

Thank you very much for Jeweler!

title: Can't version bump
body:
Trying to version bump results in `undefined method '[]' for #<Pathname:VERSION.yml>`

I tracked it down to the git gem not dealing with Pathname objects, see https://github.com/schacon/ruby-git/blob/master/lib/git/base.rb#L263

In jeweler, you are passing a Pathname object to Git::Base.add, and since it is not a String, it is trying to `git add .` and assuming the Pathname object is an options Hash, which it is not. Simply calling .to_s on the Pathname here https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/blob/master/lib/jeweler/commands/version/base.rb#L25 fixes the problem, but I am not sure how widespread this problem might be.

title: Fix URL of build status badge
body: Removed the stray `]` in the build status badge URL

title: Use a version of timecop that supports Ruby 1.8.7 and wasn't yanked :/

```
jeweler -v
```

it reports 1.8.4. This can be very confusing when trying to debug things (it left me installing and uninstalling a few different versions before I realised the problem).

title: Nokogiri version in gemspec conflicts with that required by latest github_api
body: The latest github_api requires nokogiri 1.6. The Jewler Gemfile conditionally requires nokogiri 1.5.10 for ruby < 1.9.2, but the gemspec explicitly requires 1.5.10 (presumably because it was generated on a system with ruby < 1.9.2) even though my system is running ruby 2.0. Hence I get a version conflict.

title: Feature/support ruby2.0.0
body:
Fix travis test and support ruby-2.0.0.
I merged https://github.com/emilsoman/jeweler/commit/109c92d67baf5f55a627588a2cc16db171888ae5, so this pull request includes #237.

title: Use Gem::Package.build(spec) instead of Gem::Builder.new(spec).build
body:
Jeweler can't build gems after RubyGems 2.0.0 update. 

From RubyGems ReleaseNotes : 

> - Merged Gem::Builder into Gem::Package. Use Gem::Package.build(spec)
>   instead of Gem::Builder.new(spec).build

title: Add shebang ruby to hide warning from bin/jeweler
Ruby 2.0.0 ifying
body:
Jeweler 1.8.4 has lots of trouble working in the newly released ruby2.0. The biggest problems is that 2.0's rubygems uses Gem::Package instead of Gem::Builder, so I changed that in build_gem (in lib as well as in test) to reflect this change. In addition, ruby2.0 must use the newest bundler 1.3.0.pre for function correctly.

In addition, as there is currently no working debugger for ruby2.0 yet, I removed the debugger from the gemfile. Finally, I should mention I had to do some shenenigans with simplecov and rcov with conditionals in the gemfile to be able to properly use the rake and whatnot features of jeweler.

title: "stack level too deep" raises on Windows
body:
Hi.

I used JewelerTask  on Windows. Then, some jeweler's tasks couldn't be executed.

```
$ rake version -t
** Invoke version (first_time)
** Invoke version_required (first_time)
** Execute version_required
rake aborted!
stack level too deep
D:/ruby/lib/ruby/1.9.1/gems/jeweler-1.8.4/lib/jeweler.rb:155
```

I think that following code can't work on Windows. Because, Windows root is not "/".

``` ruby
  def git_base_dir(base_dir = nil)
    if base_dir
      base_dir = File.dirname(base_dir)
    else
      base_dir = File.expand_path(self.base_dir || ".")
    end
    return nil if base_dir==File.dirname("/")
    return base_dir if File.exists?(File.join(base_dir, '.git'))
    return git_base_dir(base_dir)
  end    
```

(from jeweler.rb, line 154 - 163)

I suggest following fix.

Before:

``` ruby
return nil if base_dir==File.dirname("/")
```

After:

``` ruby
return nil if Pathname.new(base_dir).root?
```

title: No github.user found -- no github token because github API moving!!
body:
when i call:
jeweler newproject
output:
"
No github.user found in ~/.gitconfig. Please tell git about your GitHub account (see http://github.com/blog/180-local-github-config for details). For example: git config --global github.user defunkt
"

then,in page ":https://github.com/blog/180-local-github-config":
$ git config --global github.user defunkt
$ git config --global github.token 6ef8395fecf207165f1a82178ae1b984

but! In github help document:http://help.github.com/set-your-user-name-email-and-github-token/
Previous versions of our API used token authentication, but weâ€™re removing support for that soon, see our GitHub API Moving On blog post for details.
If you are using a 3rd party tool that is asking for your token, you should contact the maintainer and ask them to update to our latest API as the old API will stop working soon.
Please note you do not need the API Token to work with git.

title: todo file in windows results in TODO file in gemspec
body:
Hello.
Noticed with this gem (built with jeweler):
https://github.com/rdp/sane

that if I have a file named "todo" in the root, it causes the gemspec to look like this:

  s.extra_rdoc_files = [
    "ChangeLog",
    "README",
    "TODO"
  ]
s.files = [
  "ChangeLog",
  "todo"
 ...
]

on windows.  This results in the gem itself including two (2) files -- one called TODO and the other todo.  which I'd guess isn't expected?
Thanks.
-roger-

title: Versionflex
body:
This makes parsing VERSION more flexible so if other information is in there it shouldn't cause any problems.

This is an old patch back from 2010. So it probably wont merge cleanly at this point. But at least if you think it's worthy you can have a look at its code and apply by hand. It's not very complicated.

See issue #116, where I originally brought this up.

title: Simplecov for Ruby 1.9 test coverage

title: Support for annotated release tags with Git

The Git gem doesn't currently support this, but if/when it does then having a config option for specifying that you want to create annotated/signed tags would be nice.

title: Jeweler emits Rubygems deprecations

title: Eliminated use of deprecated Gem.activate.
body:
The use of Gem.activate is now deprecated. The preferred approach is now to find the specification using Gem::Specification.find_.... methods, and then ask the specification to activate itself.

Jeweler was issuing deprecation warnings; this patch fixes them. All tests pass.

title: Support for absolut paths in project name
body:
This patch allows the user to create project by supplying an absolut path:

`jeweler /tmp/my-project`

The target_directory option will be automatically applied if this pattern is recognized. 

Note: using this style the --directory option may get deprecated (which leads [IMHO] to a better ux)

title: Optional github integration (--[no-]github support)
body:
This patch allows the user to create a jeweler project structure without having any git(+hub) integration. I've added the option in a way the tool still behaves in the original way and tries to add fully github support, so it should provide full backward compatibility.

To disable github support the user just has to apply the --no-github option.

title: Fix undefined method sh
body:
Fix issues
https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/pull/182
https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/issues/181

title: Commands refactoring using Executor superclass
body:
All commands should inherit from this Executor class. Each command class should have a #run method. The ouput is set to $stdout when calling super. The method #print will print out to console and #system_exec is in charge of executing system commands. This all makes for a much cleaner and DRY design and makes it easy to add new Commands. 
class Jeweler
  module Commands
    class Executor
      attr_accessor :output

      def initialize
        self.output = $stdout
      end      

      def run
        raise "Must be implemented by subclass"
      end
      
      protected

      def print msg
        output.puts msg
      end

      def system_exec command
        print "Executing #{command.inspect}:"
        Kernel::system command
      end
    end
  end
end

title: git_base_dir false positives
body:
Background: I keep my home dir in git, which means that I have a ~/.git dir.  But not all the dirs under my home dir are in git (many subtrees of my home dir are excluded in ~/.gitignore).  Some ruby projects under my home dir are in mercurial, some are bare dirs.

In Jeweler::Specification, set_jeweler_defaults will always chdir to git_base_dir, assuming that is the root of the ruby project.  So unless my ruby project is in git, git_base_dir will find my home dir, with predictably useless results.

As a resolution, I guesst that there should be some way when invoking Jeweler::Tasks.new from a Rakefile to set the actual base dir and to disable the git support.

title: Jeweler::Tasks insists on regenerating the gemspec, even when it is given a custom gemspec.
body: It appears that even when `Jeweler::Tasks.new` is passed a custom `Gem::Specification` object as an argument, it still re-generates the project gemspec. Is there some way to disable the re-generation of the `project.gemspec` file?

title: Misleading dependency information in default Rakefile
body:
The default Rakefile generated by jeweler contains the lines:
    # Include your dependencies below. Runtime dependencies are required when using your gem,
    # and development dependencies are only needed for development (ie running rake tasks, tests, etc)
    #  gem.add_runtime_dependency 'jabber4r', '> 0.1'
    #  gem.add_development_dependency 'rspec', '> 1.2.3'

This is highly misleading as dependencies should be defined in the Gemfile instead.
Also, helper.rb uses Bundler.setup(:default, :development) to load dependencies and Bundler only looks into Gemfile to find dependencies.
In my opinion the above part of Rakefile should be replaced with a remark to specify dependencies in Gemfile.

title: Accidental Comment Duplication

```
  if Gem::Version.new(Gem::VERSION) >= Gem::Version.new('1.2.0') then

    s.add_development_dependency(%q<rake>, [">= 0"])

    s.add_dependency(%q<jeweler>, [">= 0"])

else

  s.add_dependency(%q<rake>, [">= 0"])
  s.add_dependency(%q<rspec>, ["~> 2"])
  s.add_dependency(%q<jeweler>, [">= 0"])
end
```

title: Generating gem.has_rdoc = 'yard' when --yard option was given.
body:
I suggest to add the following code in the generated Rakefile, if --yard option was given.

```
gem.has_rdoc = "yard"
```

So, when users do 'gem install', the YARD gem plugin will generate YARD document, and suppress generating RDoc. 
#### References

RubyGems Integration with YARD 0.2.3.1 (gnuu.org)
http://gnuu.org/2009/06/13/rubygems-integration-with-yard-0-2-3-1/

File: README ( in changelog )
http://rubydoc.info/docs/yard/file/README.md

title: The Bundler way and Jeweler
body: # This is not a bug just a reminder or documentation I had doubts regarding how to use jeweler and how to make sure I get everything that jeweler provides, this are the bumps I had to go through. - I didn't know about the existence of options for jeweler, so I didn't know I could do this: ``` jeweler --rspec your_gem ``` You can learn about all the options available to you with just: jeweler or jeweler -h And the default is: jeweler --shoulda --rdoc --bundler your_gem same as: jeweler your_gem If you have git installed, its going to pickup your information automatically. - Weird enough, when I created a gemset for the new gem, somehow rake wasn't there. Maybe add rake to the generated Gemfile, would do the trick, but this is a default gem for any gemset, don't know why it wasn't there. It is on my global gemset. - _Bundler says to put gemspec in your Gemfile, DO NOT DO IT_. It causes a lot of trouble. - All your dependencies goes into your Gemfile only, remove all dependencies listings from your Rakefile. - The meta information you provide in your Rakefile, isn't the same thing as your_gem.gemspec . After you've done setting it up on Rakefile, remember no dependencies here, just run: ``` rake gemspec ``` Jeweler generates your gemspec. - If you run into problems while executing rake tasks from jeweler, make sure you got jeweler installed (in case you create a new gemset), make sure you don't have gemspec in your Gemfile, and make sure Rake gem is there.

title: The Bundler way and Jeweler
body:
==This is not a bug just a reminder or documentation
I had doubts regarding how to use jeweler and how to make sure I get everything that jeweler provides, this are the bumps I had to go through.

First I would like to say that I couldn't find easily the options that the generator accepts, one of those is:  jeweler --rspec your_gem 

Second, weird enough, when I create a gemset for the new gem, somehow rake wasn't there. Maybe add rake to the generated Gemfile.

Third, Bundler says to put gemspec in your Gemfile, DO NOT DO IT. It causes a lot of trouble.

Fourth, all your dependencies goes into your Gemfile only, remove all dependencies listings from your Rakefile.

Fifth, The meta information you provide in your Rakefile, isn't the same thing as your_gem.gemspec . After you've done setting it up, just run rake gemspec.
Jeweler generates your gemspec.

Sixth, If you run into problems while executing rake tasks from jeweler, make sure you got jeweler installed (in case you create a new gemset), make sure you don't have gemspec in your Gemfile.

title: In certain situations, 1.5.1 adds duplicate dependency declarations to the gemspec
body:
If 1.5.1 sees a Gemfile, it puts the dependencies found in the `:production` and `:development` groups into the generated `.gemspec`. However, if those same dependencies are also declared in a Rakefile inside a `Jeweler::Tasks.new` definition, jeweler ends up listing the same dependencies twice in the `.gemspec` file it generates.

The workaround is to only put the dependency declarations into one place for now. So if the project has a Gemfile, the easiest thing to do is to just remove the dependency declarations from the Rakefile.

title: Rcov: don't test coverage of gem dependencies by default
body:
Hello brother Technical,

Currently the Rcov task (for Test::Unit, I don't know about others) includes coverage of gem dependencies complicating the output and making it much slower to run. Adding the following will stop this:

```
test.rcov_opts << '--exclude "gems/*"'
```

One of the comments on this page http://thelucid.com/2007/08/24/using-rcov-to-measure-the-test-coverage-of-rails-plugins/ suggests a PLATFORM check but I can't tell you about that!

Anyway this works for me (Mac), maybe some other peeps can give it a go on other platforms.

Ben

title: Jeweler should provide top-level methods for listing files in the project.
body: Considering that gemspecs are used to generate the actual raw `metadata.gz` within gems (actually GZiped YAML), I can see why many individuals want to hand edit a minimal gemspec. To facilitate this, Jeweler should provide top-level methods for querying information about the repository, such as `lib` or `data` files. This would prevent developers from including hardcoded boilerplate code which called `Dir.glob` or `git ls-files`.

title: Multiple Version Requirements support
body:
Heya

Have been updating TS 1.x to support Rails 1.2.6 up to 2.x, and then TS 2.x will support Rails 3 - but for the former, my dependency on ActiveRecord is as follows:

```
gem.add_dependency 'activerecord', '>= 1.15.6', '< 3.0.0'
```

The check_dependencies rake task doesn't handle multiple version arguments, but RubyGems does. This small patch fixes things so everyone's happy. Couldn't find any appropriate tests - but the test suite didn't break.

Cheers
## 

Pat

title: Jeweler doesn't seem to write version in gemspecs.
body:
After using jeweler to create a new gem, the version number written to the gemspec is nil rather than the value present in VERSION.  Please see this output:

```
    $ jeweler test
        create  .gitignore
        create  Rakefile
        create  LICENSE
        create  README.rdoc
        create  .document
        create  lib
        create  lib/test.rb
        create  test
        create  test/helper.rb
        create  test/test_test.rb
    Jeweler has prepared your gem in test

    $ cd test
    $ rake version:write
    (in /Users/Tim/test)
    Updated version: 0.0.0

    $ cat VERSION
    0.0.0

    $ rake gemspec:debug
    (in /Users/Tim/test)
    # Generated by jeweler
    # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE DIRECTLY
    # Instead, edit Jeweler::Tasks in Rakefile, and run the gemspec command
    # -*- encoding: utf-8 -*-

    Gem::Specification.new do |s|
      s.name = %q{test}
      s.version = nil
    ...
```

Notice that version is nil in the gemspec.

I can add the line
        version = File.exist?('VERSION') ? File.read('VERSION') : ""
to the Rakefile and the gemspec will get the correct version, but it seems like this should be present in the Rakefile by default.

I'm running jeweler-1.4.0 on Mac OS X 10.6.4 with Apple's ruby 1.8.7.

title: Defer to Bundler for dependency mgmt

```
require 'bundler'
Gem::Specification.new do |s|
  s.add_bundler_dependencies
end
```

It would be nice if jeweler would look for a Gemfile and, if found, generated that code instead requiring a separate redundant list of dependencies in the Rakefile.

title: Something's not right with --git-remote
body:
Based on the help, I assumed that passing --git-remote would set the remote origins to the url passed to it. However, this does not seem to be the case.

```
$ jeweler --git-remote git@github.com:kiafaldorius/somerandomrepo.git tester
$ cd tester
$ git remote -v
origin  git@github.com:kiafaldorius/tester.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:kiafaldorius/tester.git (push)
```

So...is this how it's supposed to function or is that a bug? If it is the former, is there a way to set the remote repo?

Thanks.

title: Created a lib template
body:
After received the e-mail because my pull request here is what I did.

I've changed it a little bit and added a lib template like [newgem](http://github.com/drnic/newgem/) has. So it will create the following: 

```
    create  .gitignore
    create  Rakefile
    create  Gemfile
    create  LICENSE
    create  README.rdoc
    create  .document
    create  lib
    create  lib/example
    create  lib/example.rb
    create  test
    create  test/helper.rb
    create  test/test_example.rb
    Jeweler has prepared your gem in example
```

And the header inside lib/example.rb is the following:

```
    $:.unshift(File.dirname(__FILE__)) unless
    $:.include?(File.dirname(__FILE__)) || $:.include?(File.expand_path(File.dirname(__FILE__)))
```

I'm quite new using ruby, this is my first time so any mistakes that I did please tell me so I can learn and avoid doing it again. Thanks.

title: deprecation warnings introduced by current rubygems
body:
Those Warnings appear three times:

Warning: Gem::Dependency#version_requirements is deprecated and will be removed on or after August 2010.  Use #requirement

Patch:

From 71d2fefe8e2fa8cc2220148c2cb2a258d5853291

 lib/jeweler/commands/check_dependencies.rb |    2 +-
 lib/jeweler/specification.rb               |    4 ++--
 2 files changed, 3 insertions(+), 3 deletions(-)

was:

```
Gem.activate dependency.name, dependency.version_requirements.to_s
```

should be:

```
Gem.activate dependency.name, dependency.requirement.to_s
```

title: Installation Problems - Path and Rubygit Dependency
body:
- After installing the jeweler gem, the jeweler command was not in my path. In other words, I had to add `/var/lib/gems/1.8/gems/jeweler-1.4.0/bin/` to my path in order to run jeweler.
- Installing jeweler did not install the rubygit gem dependency. Therefore when trying to run jeweler I would get an error in generator.rb: `no such file to load -- git (LoadError)`
- Even after manually installing the rubygit gem I continued to get this error message. The only way around this was to manually edit generator.rb and add `require 'rubgems'` to the first line.

**System:** Ubuntu 10.4
**Gem command version:** 1.3.5

title: Depricated Methods
body:
Jeweler uses Gem::Dependency#version_requirements, which is deprecated and will disappear in, I think, August. The deprecation notice recommends using #requirement instead.

The Rakefile references Jeweler::GemcutterTasks, but there's a notice when you run rake that you should just be using Jeweler::Tasks.

title: in specification.rb set_jeweler_defaults with a nil values causes an error
body:
if blank?(files) && repo
          base_dir_with_trailing_separator = File.join(base_dir, "")

```
      self.files = (repo.ls_files(base_dir).keys - repo.lib.ignored_files).map do |file|
```

the above for em-synchrony returns an array with a nil value which causes the following line
 File.expand_path(file).sub(base_dir_with_trailing_separator, "")
to error

I sent a pull request to add compact to the line as follows
self.files = (repo.ls_files(base_dir).keys - repo.lib.ignored_files).compact.map do |file|

title: removed dreprecation warning
body:
I made a small change in check_dependencies command. In fact the change is removing the deprecation warning. Take a look here: http://github.com/gr4y/jeweler/commits/master/ 

Maybe you want to pull this change.

title: Source code clean up.
body:
I've scanned through the source-code and removed excess white-space. Also, I split out any extension code into the `lib/jeweler/core_ext` directory. Cherry pick as needed.

http://github.com/postmodern/jeweler/commit/42c320ddf18492ae2bd15ef1b88fc7cccbd965f6
http://github.com/postmodern/jeweler/commit/b6779140613d824d134b1527f10211e8374bc436

title: rake console task
body:
I've added a basic `rake console` task, which essentially runs `bundle exec irb -Ilib`.

http://github.com/postmodern/jeweler/commit/209f7818aec5ffcd655dca50e5b80bc010df4a1e

title: Jeweler --help (and other commands I assume) fail if ~/.gitconfig doesn't exist
body: Delete your .gitconfig file in your home directory and try to run jeweler --help. The workaround is to `touch ~/.gitconfig` but Jeweler should probably handle .gitconfig missing.

title: spec_helper should require all files in spec/support/ and its subdirectories
body: It's a practice I like from rspec-rails. I just submitted a pull request. Let me know what you think.

title: ghpages:relase task
body:
Hi !

Back in issue 92, TechnicalPickles suggested that there might be room in the jeweler api for a new `rake documentation:release` rake task.

I just wanted to offer to implement that, based on defaulting to gh-pages release of (either yard or rdoc). So the intended behaviour is for no clumsy setup, and to use grancher to push the docs up to github. (takes the pain away).

Please see next comment for justifications as to why we might want this.

title: New fork with Rspec 2 support and creation of executable stubs and their gem config
body:
http://github.com/kristianmandrup/jeweler

See changelog.

title: Error when building gem in subdirectory when parent directory is the git root
body:
Create a gem that is a subdirectory in an already existing git repo. Assume a directory structure that looks something like this: 
/main-repo
  ./bin
  ./client (the gem)
    ./lib
    ./test
  ./lib
  ./test
Now attempt to generate the client gem. Any files in the parent's lib, bin, and test directory will be pulled into the gemspec automatically, which of course breaks it.

title: rubyforge.doc_task = 'doc:app' support needed for Rails defaults
body:
Hi.  In order to support the default configuration for a Ruby-on-Rails web application, where RDoc is generated with 'rake doc:app' and the results are placed in the project's 'doc/app' directory, I've added to my local fork of jeweler in rubyforge_tasks.rb, as follows:

```
   local_dir = case self.doc_task.to_sym
           when :rdoc then 'rdoc'
           when :yardoc then 'doc'
           when 'doc:app'.to_sym then 'doc/app'      # <<<<< new
           else
             raise "Unsure what to run to generate documentation. Please set doc_task and re-run."
           end
```

title: Rspec 2 support
body: Would be nice with an option to generate the jewel or use with Rspec 2. I will fork it for now to provide this little enhancement ;)

title: LICENSE has hard-coded year
body:
Noticed when generating a new project that its not 2009.
Wrote a quick patch to fix.
http://github.com/quirkey/jeweler/commit/8e27d61c1a2cfc72f9ab7b77e77c0874e9e7a4d9

title: 'rake release' automatically publishes to gemcutter
body:
I accidentally published a private gem because the Jeweler README says that all 'rake release' does is push your commits and tags to your git repository. I ran 'rake release' and ended up creating and publishing a brand new gem to gemcutter. What is the intended behavior here? Are the docs out of date, am I using the wrong version, or is this a bug? How do I keep gems from being published whenever someone (intentionally or accidentally) runs 'rake release' on my code?

Thanks.

title: Jeweler should support a non-rubyforge publish_docs task.
body: Now that the rubyforge tasks are slowly being deprecated, Jeweler should provide a task for publishing documentation along with the release of a version. At the minimum a `publish_docs` task might accept a host, port and path to `rsync` the documentation directory to. This `publish_docs` task should be invoked along with the `release` task, so that the published documentation is coupled to the released version.

title: Add Distribution Specific Dependency
body: jRuby, Rubinius & MRI all allow for ffi, however jRuby comes bundled with it's own ffi implementation. For those of us who develop for ffi (specifically to improve cross-compatibility) this can be a major problem when we distribute with a dependency on ffi as it causes jRuby installation to fail. Would it therefore be possible to implement a system within jeweler that either adds distribution specific dependencies or produces multiple distribution specific gems upon release?

title: depend on grit, rather than git
body: schacon's git gem is horribly outdated, and [is deprecated](http://wiki.github.com/schacon/ruby-git/) in favor of [grit](http://github.com/mojombo/grit).  While updated forks exist, there are still many issues with any one you choose, and it makes trying to use any project that depends on git a headache.

title: Use jeweler without Git
body:
Perhaps this isn't a frequent request, but it would be nice to be able to use jeweler without Git. I installed jeweler and tried to create a new gem and it blew up because Git wasn't on the path. I couldn't even run 'jeweler --help' without Git on the path.

Once I installed Git, jeweler still complained ... i didn't have a "~/.gitconfig" file. I created that and it finally started working.

title: Development dependencies are set to github gems that are unavailable
body: mhennemeyer-output_catcher && devver-construct are not available via github gems any more and thusly the test suite cannot be run.

title: --git-remote command line option
body:
The command line option --git-remote does not seem to work. When I use `jeweler --git-remote my.git.host:/path/to/repo` the git config still points to github for the origin. It seems the command line option never makes it to the generator. 
I made a simple fix available at http://github.com/jellehelsen/jeweler .

title: Jeweler should support creating markdown or textile formatting README files.
body:
YARD supports using documentation markup other than RDoc (SimpleMarkup), such as MarkDown or Textile.

Since Jeweler already supports adding YARD to projects, it should also allow creating MarkDown or Textile formatted README files.

I've added the --markdown and --textile options to Jeweler::Generator::Options, and modified the generator to use the README.md or README.tt templates. I also made sure to specify the --markup option with YARD::Rake::YardocTask.new when using MarkDown or Textile.
http://github.com/postmodern/jeweler/commit/694f1eade0d614f7cfc52a03bb2c6b5c02b9c041

title: Jeweler uses the old 'yardoc' task.
body:
In YARD 0.4.0 the YARD documentation task was renamed to 'yard'.
http://github.com/lsegal/yard/commit/ad38a68dd73898b06bd5d0a1912b7d815878fae0

I have made the necessary changes in my fork of Jeweler:
http://github.com/postmodern/jeweler/tree/postmodern

What do I need to do?

title: adding the --local option to the install task's call to gem install would speed things up
body: RubyGems (version 1.3.5) contacts the remote repo even when not needed. The result is that jeweler's rake install task takes longer than needed. If the install command (Jeweler::Commands::InstallGem.run) used the --local option it would avoid this and speed up local gem installs.

title: Default rakefile names testing dependency "thoughtbot-shoulda" instead of "shoulda"
body: Apparently no gem answers to the name "thoughtbot-shoulda" anymore, so the default rakefile breaks when it comes down to testing.

title: 'rake gemspec:validate' always fails
body:
I've seen this today in more than one of my current projects, but just to make sure it wasn't my fault, I tried it from scratch:

```
[12:53][~/projects]$ jeweler dummy
    create  .gitignore
    # etc.
Jeweler has prepared your gem in dummy
[12:53][~/projects]$ cd dummy
```

A version file has to exist before a .gemspec can be validated:

```
[12:53][~/projects/dummy(master)]$ rake version:write
(in /Users/steve/projects/dummy)
Updated version: 0.0.0
```

I try to validate the gemspec:

```
[12:54][~/projects/dummy(master)]$ rake gemspec:validate
(in /Users/steve/projects/dummy)
dummy.gemspec is invalid. See the backtrace for more details.
rake aborted!
undefined method `prerelease?' for nil:NilClass

(See full trace by running task with --trace)
```

I run the task with --trace:

```
[12:54][~/projects/dummy(master)]$ rake gemspec:validate --trace
(in /Users/steve/projects/dummy)
** Invoke gemspec:validate (first_time)
** Invoke version_required (first_time)
** Execute version_required
** Execute gemspec:validate
dummy.gemspec is invalid. See the backtrace for more details.
rake aborted!
undefined method `prerelease?' for nil:NilClass
/opt/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.9.1/gems/rubygems-update-1.3.5/lib/rubygems/specification.rb:1317:in `block in <class:Specification>'
dummy.gemspec:9:in `block (2 levels) in parse'
/opt/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.9.1/gems/rubygems-update-1.3.5/lib/rubygems/specification.rb:421:in `initialize'
dummy.gemspec:7:in `new'
dummy.gemspec:7:in `block in parse'
/opt/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.9.1/gems/jeweler-1.4.0/lib/jeweler/gemspec_helper.rb:56:in `eval'
/opt/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.9.1/gems/jeweler-1.4.0/lib/jeweler/gemspec_helper.rb:56:in `block in parse'
```

I've hunted this down to a failure on assigning the version string in the "virtual" (non-file-based) gemspec that gets generated and passed to the `gemspec_helper.parse` method.  It looks like the **ValidateGemspec** command class just isn't doing the same work of adding versions that the **WriteGemspec** command class is.  (The real gemspec used to build the gem works fine.)  

I don't understand the Jeweler infrastructure well enough to figure out which version addition code needs to be put in, however, or when; so I'm simply reporting the issue instead of trying to fork and fix it.

title: Using YARD breaks due to --charset=UTF-8 option
body:
Jeweler always adds the following line to the gemspec regardless of whether RDoc or YARD is selected for documentation:

```
s.rdoc_options = ["--charset=UTF-8"]
```

This throws an error from YARD when the gem is installed:

```
Installing ri documentation for etapper-0.0.5...
Building YARD (yri) index for etapper-0.0.5...
invalid option: --charset=UTF-8

Usage: yardoc [options] [source_files [- extra_files]]
(if a list of source files is omitted, lib/**/*.rb ext/**/*.c is used.)
# ...etc.
```

I've already reported this issue at the YARD repository.  I believe they should keep themselves compatible with every RDoc option.  However, given that they currently do not, I suggest that Jeweler should omit that line or add it to the RDoc optional generator instead of the main workflow.

title: note: git add required before rake build
body:
`rake build` (or `rake gemspec`) does not add files to the gemspec if they are not versioned in git. I have to do a `git add .` before I do `rake build`, otherwise my generated gemspec is not correct.

Why did I create this issue? At the very least, this is confusing and I wanted to share this with others.

To go farther, I would recommend that `rake build` update the gemspec even if a file isn't added to git yet. The tight coupling with git can be annoying in this case. (If you do want some sort of coupling with git, why not just check .gitignore?)

title: setup task to install missing dependencies
body:
It's nice to be able to check out a fresh project and run one command to get all dependencies. For [example](http://gist.github.com/279396#file_rake_setup_task.rb).

`setup` can be `install_dependencies` to align with `check_dependencies`

title: Year is wrong in LICENSE
body: Should be 2010 now, since it's, you know, 2010 ;) Or actually, probably should be <%= Date.today.year %> so you don't have to keep changing it.

title: Remove --gemcutter and --rubyforge from generator
body:
Rubyforge is backed by gemcutter now, so we shouldn't need to choose between them.

Thanks!
    Victor

title: micronaut rake task is broken due to missing ":"
body:
The micronaut rake task is missing a colon so the generator generates Micronaut::RakeTask.new(examples) instead of Micronaut::RakeTask.new(:examples).

http://github.com/bdimcheff/jeweler/commit/f411d7bda008c04078ad7548d787d46e07710dc4

I'm about to send a pull request with the fix.

title: Running rake install modifies the gemspec thus making the git repo dirty
body: I wouldn't expect an action like install to change any part of the gems content. I'm aware that this is no problem at all if .gemspec is added to the .gitignore file, but there are quite some gems (including datamapper and merb) that put the gemspec into the git repo itself. I know that as a rule of thumb one shouldn't include stuff that can be generated into a repo, but still, people do it. Also, there are/were good reasons to do so, think of github gem building and wycats/bundler.

title: Jeweler uses unsupported Ruby code in Gem Specification
body:
Hello, I'm the developer of rake-compiler, a rake helper that provides a glue and simplify the task of creation Ruby C extensions and binary gems across platforms. In my role, I've received several reports of issues integrating Jeweler in the process of packaging and releasing those gems. What rake-compiler does is take the original Gem Specification and duplicate it to allow generation of both pure-ruby gem (the default) and native ones for the platform you're targeting. All this approach worked for scenarios of manually created gemspec or ones created with Hoe, but not Jeweler. After further investigation, it seems Jeweler is defining 3 collection elements in the specification as Rake::FileList, something that is not supported by normal to_ruby code. To simply prove my case, after a 
Jeweler::Tasks.new
block: ``` g = Rake.application.jeweler.gemspec.dup puts g.to_ruby ``` Generates the following output: 

rake aborted!
ruby_code case not handled: Rake::FileList
C:/Users/Luis/Tools/Ruby/ruby-1.8.6-p383-i386-mingw32/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/specification.rb:1025:in `ruby_code'
C:/Users/Luis/Tools/Ruby/ruby-1.8.6-p383-i386-mingw32/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/specification.rb:737:in `to_ruby'
C:/Users/Luis/Tools/Ruby/ruby-1.8.6-p383-i386-mingw32/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/specification.rb:732:in `each'
C:/Users/Luis/Tools/Ruby/ruby-1.8.6-p383-i386-mingw32/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.8/rubygems/specification.rb:732:in `to_ruby'
C:/Users/Luis/Projects/_sandbox/test/clean-gem/Rakefile:56
Which clearly shows the unsafe nature of defining files, test_files and extra_rdoc_files as FileList While Jeweler parses and beautify 
to_ruby
implementation, sanitizing it, the gemspec offered at the execution time is invalid, while the one stored in the gemspec file is. I believe files, test_files and extra_rdoc_files should materialize as arrays in the gemspec sooner than the current delay implemented in your codebase. For the record, the gemspec that is stored in the metadata part of a gem is in YAML format, not Ruby, so marshaling out from it generate the issues. Thank you for your time.

title: Pushing a new version to Gemcutter doesn't tag the version
body: Unless I'm doing something wrong.  This isn't necessarily a bug, but it was nice to have when I was hosting gems on GitHub, and it would be nice to have again.

i.e.:

```
git clone .../package.git
cd package
cd gem
rake release
```

...
s.files = ["fs-snapshot.gemspec", ...]
...

title: Duplicate normalize_files line in gemspec_helper
body:
In gemspec_helper.rb's #to_ruby method:

```
def to_ruby
  normalize_files(:files)
  normalize_files(:files)
  normalize_files(:extra_rdoc_files)
```

I think you want the second line to be normalize_files(:test_files)

title: rake install shouldnt use sudo by default
body:
Using rvm (or homebrew or just managing your own gem dir) the idea is to never use sudo when installing gems. I've been doing this for a while now and its been working out great. Using jeweler though, I cant use the nifty 'rake install' task without having to back out of the task and install myself.  If I wanted to use sudo, shouldnt I just do `sudo rake install` and otherwise it just uses `gem install`. 

I'd be happy to fork and add this myself - more wondering if theres a really good reason I'm not thinking about to always use sudo.

title: Bumping version adds a trailing newline character in VERSION
body:
Bumping version adds a trailing newline character in the VERSION file
If you use the snippet from the generated Rakefile to extract the gem version:

```
version = File.exist?('VERSION') ? File.read('VERSION') : ""
```

..you'll end up with a string that goes like:

```
File.read("VERSION")
# => "0.1.0\n"
```

title: rake install command fails with Rubinius
body:
The following line of code will fail with Rubinius:

http://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/blob/master/lib/jeweler/commands/install_gem.rb#L19

The reason is that Config::CONFIG['RUBY_INSTALL_NAME'] returns the string "rbx", but the code assumes it will be "ruby". A better solution would be to change this line to:

  "#{Config::CONFIG['RUBY_INSTALL_NAME']} -S gem"

Which should work with all ruby implementations, regardless of the name of the binary.

title: release task blows away .svn?
body:
Hi --

I added Jeweler::RubyforgeTasks.new and Jeweler::GemcutterTasks.new to the Rakefile for an existing project, and I was able to use them to release the gem to RubyForge and then to gemcutter (this was before I got the note about pushing to RubyForge being deprecated).  One of the two (sorry, don't know which) seems to have generated a new rdoc directory, and in the process it wiped out the .svn subdirectory that was in the old rdoc.  I'm getting this when I try to commit my changes:

svn: Commit failed (details follow):
svn: Directory '[project path]/rdoc/.svn' containing working copy admin area is missing

I can't revert to a previous version because svn refuses to deal with this directory.  Any suggestions on how to recover?  Will this issue go away if I remove the RubyForge tasks and just use gemcutter in the future?

Thanks.....

title: better support for .document

Was informed on IRC:

> argv[0]: technicalpickles put a '-' on a separate line followed by all the non ruby files, that way yard picks em up properly. rdoc does too ( just checked )

title: Support for gem bundler
body:
Ran into this issue when using bundler with jeweler. Bundler uses the ./bin directory for all its local executables and Jeweler assumes that the old standard that anything in the ./bin file in a gem should be packaged with the gem.

I think a good enhancement to the Jeweler generator would be to either add a flag for --with-bundler and then stub out: `gem.executables = []`

title: jruby -S gem install -> gem will be installed in the RUBY_HOME not JRUBY_HOME
body:

the gem in installed, but not in the jruby gem path, rather in the ruby gem path. 
also forcing sudo is not needed (and not good) for jruby gems. 

is there a work around for this?

title: Rake FileList members in gemspec block should uniq their content
body:
If I include a file to a FileList that is already present in that list, then the file will end up multiple times in the gemspec.

Example:
gemspec.extra_rdoc_files.include 'TODO'

will lead to 'TODO' being present two times in the relevant gemspec section.

title: Don't force sudo for `rake install`
body: The awesome http://rvm.beginrescueend.com/ doesn't like it when gems are installed with sudo. The reason behind that is explained on the homepage. I think jeweler should at least respect an ENV var to turn sudo usage off. I know that probably sudo rake install is no good choice either, because the package task gets invoked with root privileges too, which leads to root owned pkg/ folder. So some ENV var is probably a good option?

if there are files in the ext directory, typically it'll be

   some_other_file.c

I'd move that those

be added as extensions.  Though I suppose the user could add them in manually, now that I think about it...

-r

title: Allow jeweler and gemspec to be agnostic (you can use rake or thor)
body:
Thor is able to wrap Rake tasks, so I can use Jeweler with it. The only downside is that my gemspec keeps a note to Rakefile, which does not exist, since we are using a Thorfile. I've created a small patch that allows it to detect whether a Rakefile or a Thorfile are being used.

http://github.com/josevalim/jeweler

Since I was there, I also removed mention to Github building gems.

Regards!

i.e. something like: http://blog.martiandesigns.com/2008/10/08/creating-a-simple-private-gem-repository/

It would be cool to have a rake gem:release:local task to scp the build gem across and ssh in and run the gem generate_index command.

title: Jeweler is setting some git related environment config that is colliding with our dev task
body:
If you take a glance at http://github.com/rspec/meta/commit/3f97424e1d5eee5b68da7fd3927eade72d5e4e38

The current dev setup is to have all the projects checked out under a given path, so meta, mocks, core, and expectations exist at the same level.  Meta can manage the other repos via a simple rake task the manipulates git.  If we require jeweler and the jeweler gem task the git operations immediately fail as git is locked to the meta repo.

title: Jeweler adding footprint to all Rake tasks
body:
Hey guys,

Today we noticed that just adding Jeweler to the Heroku client gem causes 4 specs to fail.

That seems to be related to Dir.chdir. We change to another dir while running those specs, while Jeweler and Git are also doing something similar. I don't know the exact reason yet, but for some reason when Jeweler is present the chdir in our spec doesn't take effect, and they end up running in the current folder I'm in.

This is certainly an issue itself, but I think the big picture here is Jeweler shouldn't add any footprint until explicitly called; it shouldn't parse my Git repo and build the gem spec if I'm just running my tests.

The patch to make Jeweler rake tasks lazy is here:
http://github.com/pedro/jeweler/commit/320ad5735e4ba72487c549207ea8b0ded26a4d0c

Thanks,
Pedro

```
  output.puts "Executing #{command.inspect}:"

  sh sudo_wrapper(command) # TODO where does sh actually come from!? - rake, apparently
end
...
```

Thanks.

title: Customizable location of the VERSION file and/or updating the VERSION constant.
body:
According to:
http://weblog.rubyonrails.org/2009/9/1/gem-packaging-best-practices

My gem should not rely on resources outside of the lib directory. However, my VERSION constant is built by reading the VERSION.yml file so that it is the single point of truth for version information. So I'd like to store my version file in the lib directory.

Alternatively, I'd be happy to have Jeweler provide a simple way to update the VERSION constant within a ruby file whenever the version is changed.

title: Missing documentation in README for rubyforge projects
body:
In the README, 3 lines are missing to get all the rake tasks required for publishing to rubyforge:

```
Jeweler::RubyforgeTasks.new do |rubyforge|
  rubyforge.doc_task = "rdoc"
end
```

Without them, you don't have the `rake rubyforge:setup`, `rake rubyforge:release:gems` and `rake rubyforge:release:docs` tasks.

Creating a new project with the `--rubyforge` flag correctly defines the RakeFile though.

`/Library/Ruby/Gems/1.8/gems/git-1.2.2/lib/git/lib.rb:700:in `command': git config '--list' '--file' '~/.gitconfig'  2>&1:fatal: unable to read config file ~/.gitconfig: No such file or directory (Git::GitExecuteError)`

My .gitconfig is there, though:

`-rw-r--r--  1 veez  staff  344 Aug  2 19:47 /Users/veez/.gitconfig`

title: Jeweler breaks with the git gem version 1.2.1

If your version of git doesn't have a minor revision number the new git gem is borked.  eg. 1.6.4 instead of 1.6.4.1.  The problems can be found on lines 649 - 665 in the lib.rb of the git gem.  Figured you could atleast lock the gemspec version req to 1.1.1 for now.

title: The Umlaut problem: UTF-8 chars get converted to unicode entities

When using an UTF-8 character (like the german umlaut Ã¼) in the Rakefile, it gets converted to (2!) UTF-8 entities it seems.

For example in Rakefile it reads:
    gem.authors = ["Markus HÃ¼berman"]

And in the resulting gemspec file after releasing it gets converted to:
    s.authors = ["Markus H\303\274berman"]

title: Jeweler can not read my ~/.gitconfig

title: RDoc rake task looks for VERSION.yml but plaintext is now default
body: Minor, but the generated `RDocTask` should be updated to expect the plaintext `VERSION` file.

title: version_required rake task has nonintuitive docstring
body:
Upon creating my first gem with Jeweler, I thought, "Hmm, so there is no version out of the box. Lemme look at these rake tasks I remember being mentioned..." So when running `rake -T` I see "Setup initial version of 0.0.0" and think I'm off to the races. But that's not what it does at all.

```
desc "Setup initial version of 0.0.0"
  task :version_required do
    unless jeweler.version_exists?
      abort "Expected VERSION or VERSION.yml to exist. See version:write to create an initial one."
    end
end
```

So it's just a dependency task. Fine, but why's it in my `rake -T` listing? :-)  This should either bootstrap a `VERSION.yml` with 0.0.0 if needed (preferable), or have the `desc` removed.

title: 'rake release' not idempotent after failure
body:
We just tried to do a deploy. It failed for some non-jeweler reason. So we fixed the problem and tried it again. It failed again, and this time was jeweler's fault. It seemed that jeweler was expecting a "git commit" to succeed, since it had just modified the gemspec file. But it hadnt modified the file, since it was the same version as before, so the contents didn't change, so "git commit" failed. We had to bump up the version number a few times to get this to work right.

I think you can also duplicate this if you specify the wrong VERSION on the rake command line.

title: Support setting description in gemspecs
body:
Hey there - jeweler is great; I'm using it for almost all of my gems now. Thanks.

Eric Hodel has started sending out mail to maintainers of gems that are pushed to Rubyforge without a description in the gemspec. Since I like to avoid getting mail about things like this, I've added support for descriptions to jeweler. It works just like the existing summary support - you can pass a --description option to jeweler to set an explicit description; otherwise, it'll be set to TODO. One less thing to have to fill in later... This is all in my fork if you'd like to pull it in.

title: rubyforge:release failing because rubyforge_project in config is not used
body:
I’m really happy, I was able to release my gem to rubyforge!

I had to manually edit the rakefile in two places for the project name:
 @@@
# In the config (cool)

gem.rubyforge_project = "my_project_name"
# In the rubyforge:release task (not so cool)

remote_dir = "/var/www/gforge-projects/set_to_gem_name_by_default/"
# The latter should use the config’s rubyforge
# I’m not sure how, otherwise I’d do it!

 @@@
Thanks!

Great work with jeweler :-)

title: GitHub Pages - RDoc to Branch
body:
First off - Jeweler rocks. I’m lazy and a noob so anything that takes thinking out of the equation is pretty good by my standards.

I just thought it would be good if Jeweler could automatically generate rdoc (which It can already) and put it in the ’gh-pages’ branch for GitHub.

Cheers,

Bryce

[original LH ticket](http://technicalpickles.lighthouseapp.com/projects/23560/tickets/4)

 This ticket has 0 attachment(s).

title: Cross-platform compilation, gem creation
body:
I currently use echoe and it lets me package up my project (RedCloth) with tasks like:
rake java package
and
rake mingw package

Some sort of support for this would be nice in jeweler.  Probably a "someday maybe" feature request, but it can’t hurt to ask.

[original LH ticket](http://technicalpickles.lighthouseapp.com/projects/23560/tickets/5)

 This ticket has 0 attachment(s).

title: rspec template should require spec_helper differently
body:
The flunking.rb template for rspec projects created by Jeweler has a require statement for ’spec_helper’ that assumes a relative path.  This breaks the ability of autospec to run all tests.  Please change the require in the flunking.rb template to something like the following:

require File.expand_path(File.dirname(**FILE**) + ’/spec_helper’)

Thanks in advance.

[original LH ticket](http://technicalpickles.lighthouseapp.com/projects/23560/tickets/10)

 This ticket has 0 attachment(s).

title: gem install issues
body:
The peterwald-git gem jeweler depends on, isn’t on rubyforge, only on github. So if the user hasn’t added github gems to his local rubygems sources list (gem sources -a "http://gems.github.com"), a pure ’gem install jeweler’ will fail as it won’t install the dependencies.

Adding github gems to local rubygems sources list or installing with sources option set to github gems both solve the problem on the user side.

Releasing peterwald-git on rubyforge will prevent this issue.

[original LH ticket](http://technicalpickles.lighthouseapp.com/projects/23560/tickets/19)

 This ticket has 0 attachment(s).

title: Missleading error message in 'rescue'
body:
The generated Rakefiles have the following rescue-clause.

```
rescue LoadError
  puts "Jeweler not available. Install it with: sudo gem install technicalpickles-jeweler -s http://gems.github.com"
```

The problem here is that all errors are caught, not just a missing jeweler. Adding a 'raise' shows  this:
    $ rake -T
    Jeweler not available. Install it with: sudo gem install technicalpickles-jeweler -s  http://gems.github.com
    rake aborted! 
    no such file to load -- rubyforge
    /home/*Rakefile:5
    (See full trace by running task with --trace)

I suggest you either add the 'raise' or check what exactly is missing. The current solution is very very misleading to newcomers.

Cheers,
Reto

title: remove jeweler tasks' dependence on rake i.e. to allow thor to use the tasks
body:
I saw you (technicalpickles) on irc wishing people would submit issues instead of private messages. Here's your wish come true :p
[My branch](http://github.com/cldwalker/jeweler/tree/master) contains the necessary changes for this request. [Here's a post](http://tagaholic.me/2009/04/08/building-dry-gems-with-thor-and-jeweler.html) explaining some of the motivation for moving my jeweler tasks to thor.

title: Windows Compatibility
body:
To support windows probably should make a change something like this. This assumes the user is running as admin on the windows box. Also added note for sh..

class Jeweler
  module Commands
    class InstallGem
      def run
        cmd_prefix = "sudo " if CONFIG['host_os'] =~ /mswin|windows/i 
        command = "#{cmd_prefix}gem install #{gemspec_helper.gem_path}"
        output.puts "Executing #{command.inspect}:"
        sh command # sh is from Rake FileUtils
      end

```
end
```

  end
end

But... I don't see anything actually get processed. I threw in some debugging into the handler, and it doesn;t seem like that is getting called.

What might I be missing?

title: feat: added regex support for scopes
body:
RegEx support for scopes. This enables support for any project management system to enforce naming conventions in their PRs. 

```
# You can define a list of valid scopes
scopes:
  - scope1
  - /^TASK-(\\d)+$/
  ...
```

body:

This PR allows validating multiple scopes, as in accordance with https://github.com/conventional-changelog/commitlint/pull/901.

title: Require a scope
body:
In a monorepo, [we'd like to _require_ that a scope always be provided](https://github.com/liferay/liferay-frontend-projects/issues/125), to make it easier for us to do things like filter notifications.

However, it seems that the `scopes` configuration can only be used [to detect invalid scopes, not require a scope when none is provided](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/blob/a1d743d558e012952f4d3ab395137487b32afe6e/lib/is-semantic-message.js#L20).

So, just wanted to propose this as a feature request.

title: Allow to configure prefered merge method
body:
Currently, with `titleAndCommits: true`, the check will report â€œready to be squashedâ€ if a PR title is semantic, even if all commits are semantic. This probably makes sense for people who prefer squashing over merging or rebasing.

I prefer rebasing over squashing, so for me, it would be much more useful to read â€œready to be rebasedâ€ if all commits are semantic and the PR title is too. With the current behaviour, if the PR author wrote a semantic PR title, I still have to check all commit messages manually to see if I can rebase.

Proposal: Add a setting like `preferredMergeStrategy`. If it is set to `squash` (should be the default to keep the current behaviour), the check behaves as it does now. If it is set to `rebase` or `merge`, the check will evaluate the commit messages before it evaluates the title, i.e. display â€œready to be merged or rebasedâ€ whenever all commits are semantic.

title: Improve error message
body:
There is one error message which gets cut off in the status check and I wonder if there is something we can do about it.


![Screenshot 2020-09-28 at 12 41 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1393946/94422844-fb1b1180-0187-11eb-81e2-50cc612c998c.png)


A few ideas:

1) Come up with a shorter version
2) Introduce error codes which allows us to document the error in more detail in the README of this repository. 
3) Add a comment with the error to the pull request. This comment should go away automatically if the issue has been addressed.

Release notes

Sourced from node-fetch's releases.

v2.6.1

This is an important security release. It is strongly recommended to update as soon as possible.
